questions.text:
Which of the following can transport a substance against its concentration gradient?
  1. Simple diffusion
  2. Secondary active counter-transport
  3. Secondary active co-transport
  4. Primary active transport
  5. Facilitated diffusion
questions.solution:
Secondary active counter-transport, secondary active co-transport, and primary active transport can transport a substance against its concentration gradient.

Simple diffusion refers to the process of random movement of a substance along its concentration gradient.

Facilitated diffusion: Transporting the molecule from one side of the cell membrane to the other is done with the help of transport proteins called carriers. Molecules move from areas of high concentration to areas of low concentration. No energy input is required when carrier proteins move substances in the direction of their gradients. Glucose transport by the glucose transporter is an example, which moves glucose down its concentration gradient from the ECF to the cytoplasm of the cell.

 

Transporting more than one substance together using a single transport protein against the gradient is known as secondary active transport. An example of one such protein is SGLT 1, the cotransporter of sodium and glucose from the intestinal lumen into mucosal cells.

 

Active transport is the transporting of substances against the gradient and requires energy. Ca2+-ATPase that pumps out calcium out of the cells is an example.

Related Pearl: Characteristics of different types of transport

questions.text: A lesion at the site marked by the red arrow would result in
questions.solution:
A lesion at the occipital lobe would result in homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing.

Homonymous hemianopia (HH) involves loss of vision on the same side of the visual field in both eyes. HH is characteristically seen in lesions involving the visual pathway posterior to the optic chiasma.

HH may be either complete or incomplete. 

  • A complete HH is characterized by loss of entire hemifield on the same side in both eyes.
  • An incomplete HH is characterized by partial loss of visual field on the same side in both eyes. Incomplete HH is further classified as congruous or incongruous, depending on whether the extent of partial loss of visual field in both the eyes is same or different, respectively.

Lesions involving the occipital lobe usually shows macular sparing because macular representation is seperate and quite large as compared to peripheral vision. Moreover, the macular area in the occipital lobe is supplied by both the posterior and middle cerebral arteries. In case of vascular lesions (e.g. stroke) affecting the occipital lobe, it is less likely that both these arteries are involved.

Related Pearl: Lesions in the optic pathway

Transection of the pathways at the locations indicated by the letters causes the visual field defects shown in the diagram above.

  • The fibers from the nasal half of each retina decussate in the optic chiasm, so that the fibers in the optic tracts are those from the temporal half of one retina and the nasal half of the other.
  • A lesion that interrupts the optic nerve causes blindness in that eye.
  • Lesions affecting the optic chiasma destroy fibers from both nasal hemiretinas and produce a heteronymous (opposite sides of the visual fields) hemianopia.
  • A lesion in one optic tract causes blindness in half of the visual field and is called homonymous (same side of both visual fields) hemianopia (half-blindness).
  • Occipital lesions may spare the fibers from the macula because of the separation in the brain of these fibers from the other subserving vision.

questions.text: Perivascular cellular infiltrates, edema, granuloma formation, and cell destruction are characteristic histopathological features associated with which type of hypersensitivity reaction?
questions.solution:
Perivascular cellular infiltrates, edema, granuloma formation, and cell destruction are characteristic histopathological features associated with type IV hypersensitivity reaction.

questions.text: As part of a pretransplant workup, a 59-year-old man with a previous history of MI undergoes cardiac catheterization to determine his cardiac fitness. During estimation of his systolic function, in what phase of the cardiac cycle do expect to see his peak left ventricular pressure?
questions.solution:
Peak ventricular pressure occurs during ventricular ejection

As is clear from Wigger's diagram below, peak pressure in the ventricles in systole corresponds to the ejection phase. 

Isovolumetric contraction occurs when the pressure of the left ventricle goes from the pressure level of the left atrium to that of the aorta, following which the aortic valves open. Isovolumentric relaxation occurs during the reverse process, while the left ventricle's pressure falls.

The Cardiac Cycle:

Diastole 

  • Protodiastole
    Before the semilunar valve closes, even though ventricular muscle is relaxed, blood flow into great vessels is due to the momentum of blood.
  • Iso-volumetric Relaxation
    The ventricular muscle continues to relax, even though the ventricular volume does not change, with all valves closed.
  • Ventricular Filling
    Isovolumetric relaxation ends when the ventricular pressure falls below the atrial pressure and the AV valves open, permitting the ventricles to fill.
  • Atrial Systole
    During the last third of diastole, the atria contract and give additional thrust to the inflow of blood into the ventricles. It correlates with the 'a' wave in JVP.

Systole 

  • Isovolumetric Contraction
    The ventricular muscle continues to contract, even though the ventricular volume does not change, with all valves closed. 
    It correlates with the ‘c’ wave of JVP.
  • Ventricular Ejection
    When the ventricular pressures rise above aortic and pulmonary pressures the valves open, and ventricular ejection begins. Peak pressures in the left and right ventricles are about 120 and 25 mmHg, respectively. 

Related Pearl: JVP waveform and the abnormalities

1) The a-wave corresponds to atrial contraction.

Abnormality Conditions
Prominent a-waves Pulmonary hypertension, right atrial thrombus/ mass, and tricuspid stenosis
Cannon a-waves

Complete AV block, ventricular tachycardia, and premature atrial/ junctional/ ventricular beats
Absent a-waves Atrial fibrillation

 

2) The c-wave corresponds to the bulging of tricuspid valve into right atrium during ventricular contraction.

 

3) The x-descent corresponds to atrial relaxation during atrial diastole.

Abnormality Conditions
Absent x-descent Severe tricuspid regurgitation
Rapid x-descent Cardiac tamponade

 

4) The v-wave corresponds to the venous filling of right atrium.

Abnormality Conditions
Dominant v-waves Tricuspid regurgitation

 

5) The y-descent corresponds to the passive emptying of the right atrium into right ventricle.

Abnormality Conditions
Prolonged y-descent Tricuspid stenosis
Rapid y-descent

Constrictive pericarditis and isolated severe tricuspid regurgitation
Absent y-descent Cardiac tamponade

questions.text: How should you administer adenosine to a patient with SVT for pharmacological cardioversion?

choices.text: 6 mg IV bolus over 2-3 seconds followed by a rapid flush with 20 mL NS
6 mg IV bolus over 2-3 minutes followed by a 20 ml saline flush to avoid line irritation
6 mg slow IV infusion over 20-30 minutes
6 mg slow IV infusion over 20 minutes followed by 12 mg in 40 minutes

questions.solution:
Adenosine should be administered as a 6 mg IV bolus over 2-3 seconds followed by a rapid flush with 20 mL NS

Adenosine is an ultra-short acting drug with a half-life being less than 10 seconds. It activates an inward rectifier K+ current along with inhibition of calcium current. The results of these actions are marked hyperpolarization and suppression of calcium-dependent action potentials.

When given as a bolus dose, adenosine directly inhibits AV nodal conduction but has lesser effects on the SA node. Currently, Adenosine is used for the prompt conversion of paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia to sinus rhythm because of its high efficacy (90–95%) and very short duration of action. It is usually given in a bolus dose of 6 mg followed by a dose of 12 mg if required. Flushing, shortness of breath, and chest burning are some of its adverse effects.

 

Treatment of PSVT: 

In hemodynamically stable patients, carotid massage/Valsalva maneuver should be attempted first. If the vagal maneuvers fail or cannot be performed, intravenous adenosine can be used. It is usually given in a bolus dose of 6 mg followed by a dose of 12 mg if required. If there is no termination of the PSVT, Then the next step is IV ibutilide + AV nodal–blocking agent (or)IV procainamide + AV nodal–blocking agent (or) Cardioversion. In the presence of hypotension with unconsciousness or respiratory distress, QRS-synchronous direct current cardioversion is warranted.

The ECG below shows PSVT.

Related Pearl: Supraventricular tachycardias

questions.text: Which of the following acts as an RNA-directed nuclease?
questions.solution:
CRISPR-Cas9 acts as an RNA-directed nuclease.

Clustered regularly interspaced short palindromic repeats-associated gene 9, or CRISPR-Cas9, is a DNA editing/gene regulatory system. It involves two essential components: Cas9, an endonuclease that causes a double-stranded DNA break, allowing modifications to the genomic DNA to be made; and a synthetic single-guide RNA, or sgRNA, responsible for guiding Cas9 to its target.

Once the sgRNA has directed the Cas9 to the section of the genomic DNA to be edited, the 3’ end of the sgRNA comes to lie across a specific sequence of DNA adjacent to the editing side called the protospacer adjacent motif or PAM. The Cas9 now causes a double-stranded break in the DNA at the PAM site, which is then repaired by a non-homologous end-joining.

The following image shows CRISPR-Cas9 system:

Some important enzymes used in recombinant DNA research

Enzyme 

Reaction 

Primary Use 

Phosphatase

Dephosphorylates 5′ ends of RNA and DNA
  • Removal of 5′-PO4 (phosphate) groups prior to kinase labeling
  • Prevent self-ligation 

DNA ligase 

Catalyzes bonds between DNA molecules 
  • Joining of DNA molecules 

DNA polymerase I 

Synthesizes double-stranded DNA from single-stranded DNA 
  • Synthesis of double-stranded cDNA
  • DNA labeling and nick translation
  • Generation of blunt ends from sticky ends 

Thermostable DNA polymerases 

Synthesize DNA at elevated temperatures (60-80°C) 
  • Polymerase chain reaction (DNA synthesis)
  • Mutagenesis 

DNase I 

Produces single-stranded nicks in DNA, under appropriate conditions
  • Nick translation
  • Mapping of hypersensitive sites
  • Mapping protein-DNA interactions 

Exonuclease III 

Removes nucleotides from 3′ ends of DNA 
  • DNA sequencing
  • ChIP-Exo
  • Mapping of DNA-protein interactions 

RNAse H 

Degrades the RNA portion of a DNA–RNA hybrid 
  • Synthesis of cDNA from mRNA 

S1 nuclease 

Degrades single-stranded DNA 
  • Removal of “hairpin” in synthesis of cDNA
  • RNA mapping studies 

CRISPR-Cas9/C2c2 

RNA-targeted DNA-, or RNA-directed nuclease 

Genome editing and variations modulation

questions.text: As per ACLS, CPR can be considered to be of high quality when ETCO2 is _____.
questions.solution:
As per ACLS, CPR can be considered to be of high quality when ETCO2 is at least 10-20 mmHg.

Failure to maintain ETCO2 at >10 mm Hg during adult CPR is a reflection of poor cardiac output and it is found to strongly predicts unsuccessful resuscitation.

Monitoring ETCO2 during CPR can be used to assess blood flow in 2 ways:

  • To improve chest compression performance if ETCO2 is <10 mm Hg during CPR
  • To consider an abrupt sustained increase to a normal value (35 to 40 mm Hg) as an indicator of ROSC

High-quality cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR):

  • Push hard (at least 5 cm) and fast (100–120/min) and allow complete chest recoil.
  • Minimize interruptions in compressions (10 seconds or less).
  • Avoid excessive ventilation.
  • Rotate the compressor every 2 minutes or earlier if fatigued.
  • If no advanced airway, 30:2 compression- ventilation ratio.
  • Quantitative waveform capnography– If PetCO2 <10 mm Hg, attempt to improve CPR quality.
  • Intra-arterial pressure: If relaxation phase (diastolic) pressure <20 mm Hg, attempt to improve CPR quality.

Effective chest compression in adults:

  • Provide 100–120 compressions per minute (30 compressions for every 15-18 sec).
  • Place your arms, one over the other in the midline, on the lower 1/3rd of the patient's sternum, and lock your arms.
  • Use both arms to press the chest to a depth of 5-6 cm (2–2.4 inches)or more.
  • Press hard and fast
  • Allow for full chest recoil after every compression.

Effective chest compressions in a child older than 1 year and up to puberty:

  • The compression rate is 100–120/min  (30 compressions for every 15–18 sec).
  • One or both palms are placed in the midline.
  • Depth of compression is 2 inches.
  • Press hard and fast
  • Allow for full chest recoil after every compression.

Effective chest compressions in infants (<1 year):

  • 100 to 120 compressions per minute (30 compressions for every 15–18 sec).
  • One provider: Place two fingers, one between the nipple line and the other 1 cm below.
  • Two providers: Encircle the infant's torso with both hands with both thumbs pointing cephalic positioned 1 cm below the nipples over the sternum. 
  • Depth of compressions should be at least 1.5 inches or 1/3 the depth of the infant’s chest.
  • Press hard and fast
  • Allow for full chest recoil after every compression.

Related Pearl: High quality CPR for adults

  • Push hard: 5-6cm depth
  • Push fast: 100-120/min frequency
  • Allow for complete chest recoil
  • Minimize interruptions in compressions <10 seconds
  • Avoid excessive ventilation
  • Rotate compressor every 2 min or earlier if fatigued
  • If no advanced airway, 30:2 compression-ventilation ratio

Attempt to improve CPR quality if :

  • Quantitative waveform capnography - PETCO2 <10mmHg, 
  • Intra-arterial pressure - If relaxation phase (diastolic) pressure <20mmHg

Related Pearl: Adult cardiac arrest algorithm (Updated as per 2020 guidelines)

The adult cardiac arrest algorithm is based on the AHA guidelines as shown below.

questions.text: On being asked "Have you had any trouble sleeping lately?" the patient replies "I usually sleep in my bed, but now I'm sleeping on the sofa." What is this type of response known as?
questions.solution:
As the patient has given a reply that is appropriate to the general topic but does not answer the question exactly; it is tangentiality. The speech moves away from the actual answer.

Circumstantiality: The patient includes irrelevant details and goes on talking in a roundabout manner, but their thought ultimately reaches the answer

Example: Doctor: "How did you get that bruise?"
Patient: "I woke up and had a cup of coffee, read the newspaper, and went for a walk. It was a wonderful day in the park. I returned home and watched the TV. I took a nap in the afternoon after lunch. I slipped and fell in the bathroom. The fall gave me this bruise."

Derailment: A breakdown in both the logical connection between ideas and the overall sense of goal-directedness. The words make sentences, but the sentences do not make sense.

Example: "Some people just don't understand why I had breakfast in America during the first world war"

Desultory thoughts: Speech is grammatically correct; however, sudden unrelated ideas force their way in from time to time.

Example: My actual problem is that the people never understand me and my stomach feels like an empty bucket"

Related Pearl: Classification of disorders of thought

Related Pearl: Disorders of thought and perception

DISORDERS OF THOUGHT

DISORDER OF STREAM OF THOUGHT

(A) Disorder of tempo

(i) Flight of Ideas

Continuous flow of rapid speech that jumps from topic to topic

  • "I like mangoes, the weather is nice, India is great"

(ii) Retardation of thinking

Slow speed of speech and a prolonged latent period before a response

  • "I went to the market (pause)......... the shop was closed"

(iii) Circumstantialities

Inclusion of irrelevant details and going on in a roundabout manner, but their thought ultimately reaches the answer

  • Doctor: "How did you get that bruise?"

  • Patient: "I woke up and had a cup of coffee, read the newspaper and went for a walk. It was a wonderful day in the park. I returned home and watched the TV. I took a nap in the afternoon after lunch. I slipped and fell in the bathroom. The fall gave me this bruise."

(iv) Clang associations

Jumping from one word to another irrelevant rhyming word

  • I am Sam...I like jam...I travel in a tram"

(B) Disorder of continuity

(i) Perseveration

Repetition of out of context words, phrases, or ideas beyond the point of relevance.

  • Q1. What's your name?: "Rahul"

  • Q2. Where are you from?: "Rahul"

  • Q3. How old are you?: "Rahul"

(ii) Thought blocking

A sudden disruption of thought or a break in the flow of ideas

  • "I went to the market (extreme silence)...................."

DISORDER OF FORM OF THOUGHT

(i) Tangentiality

In response to a question, the patient gives a reply that is appropriate to the general topic but does not answer the question exactly. The speech moves away from the actual answer.

  • Doctor: "Have you had any trouble sleeping lately?"
  • Patient: "I usually sleep in my bed, but now I'm sleeping on the sofa"

(ii) Derailment

A breakdown in both the logical connection between ideas and the overall sense of goal-directedness. The words make sentences, but the sentences do not make sense.

  • "Some people just don't understand why I had breakfast in America during the first world war"

(iii) Neologisms

Bringing in new words that do not exist.

  • The world is not 'gooder' for people like me"

(iv) Desultory thoughts

Speech is grammatically correct, however, sudden unrelated ideas force their way in from time to time.

  • My actual problem is that the people never understand me and my stomach feels like an empty bucket"

(v) Word salad

Using a mixture of unintelligible meaningless words and sentences

  • Tree bus rain food home car tiger"

DISORDER OF POSSESSION OF THOUGHT
A. Thought alienation

(i) Thought insertion

Thoughts are being inserted into the patient's mind and they recognize them as being foreign and coming from without any stimulus

  • "I have repeated thoughts of killing my neighbors and I believe aliens are putting these ideas into my head at night"

(ii) Thought withdrawal

Delusion that someone or something is removing from one's mind and the patient has no power over this.

  • "Lately, I am losing all my memories and I believe that the 'government agents' are stealing them when I go to sleep"

(iii) Thought broadcasting

Belief that one's thoughts are quietly escaping from one's mind and that other people might be able to access them and hear or see them.

  • "I believe my exact thoughts appear on the TV and the internet and I think I can broadcast them globally" 

(iv) Thought echo

Patient hears the 'echo' of his own thoughts in the form of a voice after he has made the thought.

  • "I thought of making a sandwich in the morning and surprisingly a voice, from nowhere, told me to make a sandwich out loud" 

 B. Obsessions and Compulsions

1. Obsessions

Recurrent and persistent thoughts, impulses. or images that cause distress to oneself.

  • Fear of dirt or contamination
  • Fear of becoming ill
  • Constant thoughts of a certain number
  • Need for symmetry or exactness
  • Worry about whether something has been done "right"
  • Forbidden sexual or religious thoughts

2. Compulsions

Repetitive behaviors or actions that the person feels driven to perform in response to an obsession

  • Washing hands
  • Blinking eyes
  • Counting items, such as currency
  • Checking to see if doors are locked
  • Arranging items in a certain way
  • Requiring constant approval from people around them

 
 DISORDER OF CONTENT OF THOUGHT

(i) Phobias

Persistent fear of an object or situation, typically disproportional to the actual danger posed, in which the sufferer goes to great lengths in avoiding it

  • Arachnophobia - fear of spider
  • Barophobia - fear of gravity
  • Cynophobia - fear of dogs
  • Hemophobia - fear of blood
  • Nosocomephobia - fear of hospitals

(ii) Religious preoccupations

Thoughts involving religious themes or subject matter.

  • "I get instructions from God on how to make my country great"

(iii) Ideas of hopelessness

Thoughts of complete despair where the patient strongly believes that the circumstances will never get better for him.

  • "I am never going to pass my final exams, no matter how hard I study"

(iv) Antisocial urges

Thoughts of indulging in some behaviors or actions that harm or lack consideration for the well being of others.

  • "I have these urges to go rob a bank or blackmail my neighbors for their money"

(v) Delusions

False beliefs that are strongly held and unchangeable in the face of refuting evidence and that are not consistent with the person's educational, social and cultural background.

The three main criteria for a belief to be considered a delusion are:

  • Certainty (held with complete confidence)
  • Incorrigibility (not changeable by proof to the contrary)
  • Impossibility or falsity of content (implausible, bizarre or patently untrue)
 DISORDERS OF PERCEPTIONS

  • Illusion: Misinterpretation of real external stimuli.

  • Hallucination: False sensory perception, externally.

  • Pseudohallucination: False sensory perception from within and having an insight.

  • Depersonalization: Feeling as if one is disconnected from reality, feeling detached from one's own thoughts and one's own physical body.

    "I sometimes drift into a dream-like state where I lose contact with my own self"

  • Derealization: Alteration in the perception or experience of the external world so that it seems unreal.

    "The world and everything around is nothing but just a dream"

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is true regarding radiological findings of Diffuse Axonal Injury?
  1. CT scan would appear normal in all cases.
  2. MRI is the investigation of choice for assessing the condition
  3. Non-hemorrhagic lesions appear as regions of high FLAIR signal 
  4. Hemorrhagic changes are better picked up by the SWI sequence.
  5. Typical MR spectroscopy findings are elevation of choline peak and reduction of NAA
questions.solution:
Though CT may not show typical changes in the majority of patients with diffuse axonal injury, it is not normal in all patients.

Diffuse axonal injury (white matter shearing) is the result of shearing forces, typically from a rotational acceleration of the brain within the rigid cranium.

This causes damage to microvasculature and disruption of axons in the subcortical parasagittal white matter, cerebellum, fornix, and internal & external capsule.

Most commonly it occurs in high-velocity automobile accidents. Patients are usually unconscious from the moment of impact and remain the same until death.

Diffuse axonal injury is characterized by multiple focal lesions with a characteristic distribution. CT may appear normal in the majority of cases but may show hemorrhagic foci in the corpus callosum and dorsolateral rostral brainstem. Non-hemorrhagic lesions appear hypodense and typically become more evident once edema develops around them. Non-hemorrhagic lesions are often associated with disproportionate cerebral swelling.

MRI is the modality of choice for assessing suspected diffuse axonal injury even in patients with entirely normal CT of the brain. MRI, especially SWI (susceptibility-weighted imaging) & GRE (Gradient Echo) are highly sensitive to paramagnetic blood products. They may demonstrate small regions of susceptibility artifact at the grey-white matter junction, in the corpus callosum, or the brain stem.

Some lesions may be entirely non-hemorrhagic and can be picked up by using high FLAIR signals that they produce. It is important to note that the FLAIR changes may typically get resolved within 3 months, while SWI changes may persist for about a year.

 

Knowing that CT is not normal in all cases of Diffuse Axonal Injury could have helped solve this question by ruling out other choices.

Related Pearl: Diffuse Axonal Injury

The mechanism of diffuse axonal injury (DAI) is primarily a non-impact rotational acceleration-deceleration injury. This leads to the deformation of the axons by stretching them.

Pathology of DAI:

  • Changes in permeability of the axolemma
  • Axonal swelling
  • Intracellular calcium accumulation
  • Proteolysis
  • The collapse of the cytoskeleton
  • 'Retraction balls or globes' - bulbous and clubbed axons. Seen earliest at 12-18 hours. The number of retraction balls begins to decrease after 2-3 weeks after injury and a cluster of microglial cells appears followed by astrocytosis and demyelination.
  • Immuno-histochemistry shows beta-amyloid precursor protein - the most reliable indicator of axon damage. Seen earliest at 2-3 hours. 

Image shows scattered axonal retraction balls stained with Congo Red:

questions.text: Which of the following is used to stain calcium in tissue sections?
questions.solution:
The special stains used for calcium in tissue sections are von Kossa and Alizarin Red. 

Phosphotungstic acid hematoxylin staining is used to demonstrate fibrin in the tissue. Masson–Fontana stain is used to demonstrate melanin. Masson trichrome stain is used to demonstrate collagen in tissue

PTAH (Phosphotungstic acid hematoxylin) Fibrin Gliosis, Ependymomas, Tumours of skeletal muscles, Fibrin deposits
Alcian blue For acid mucins: Positive stain for mucins of the intestinal mucosa and negative stain for mucins of gastric mucosa and Brunner's gland Barrett's esophagus, Gastric disorders
Perl's Prussian blue Demonstrate hemosiderin and iron Hemochromatosis 
Masson–Fontana stain Demonstrate melanin Nevus and malignant melanoma
von Kossa method Demonstrate calcium Calcification of tissues
Van Gieson stain

Demonstrate collagen in; Differentiate amyloid from collagen

Masson trichrome stain Demonstrate collagen and muscle Connective tissue disorders, muscle and fibroblast tumors, liver cirrhosis, neuromuscular diseases

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman in puerperium presents with headache, 1 episode of generalized seizures, and confusion. On examination, she is found to have papilledema. The contrast-enhanced CT of the head is shown below. What is the drug of choice for the acute management of her condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the CECT image showing the empty delta sign are characteristic of cerebral venous thrombosis. IV heparin is the drug of choice in cerebral venous thrombosis.

Cerebral venous thrombosis is the occlusion of the lateral sagittal sinuses (central venous sinus thrombosis) or small cortical veins (cortical venous thrombosis). Symptoms and signs include the following:

  • Headache: most common, with or without vomiting
  • Seizures
  • Intracranial hypertension and papilledema
  • Focal neurological deficits
  • Altered mental status
  • Coma

It is commonly seen in hypercoagulable states. Risk factors include the following:

  • Oral contraceptive pill use
  • Pregnancy and puerperium
  • Inflammatory bowel disease
  • Dehydration
  • Intracranial infections
  • Thrombophilias like antiphospholipid syndrome, polycythemia, sickle cell anemia, protein C, S deficiency, factor V Leiden mutation, antithrombin III deficiency

MRI Brain with MR venography is the most sensitive investigation. Alternatively, CECT brain can also be done. The empty delta sign is a sign of dural venous sinus thrombosis of the superior sagittal sinus, where contrast outlines a triangular filling defect (clot). It is seen with a CECT scan or MRI.

CECT image showing the empty delta sign in the superior sagittal sinus posteriorly, with a large infarct in the left hemisphere causing a midline shift to the right:


Treatment of CVT includes

  • Acute treatment is with IV Heparin or low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH). IV heparin is the drug of choice in cerebral venous thrombosis. It prevents further thrombosis and reduces venous hypertension and ischemia.
  • Maintenance therapy:
    • Anticoagulation is often continued indefinitely if thrombophilia is diagnosed.
    • If there is no underlying hypercoagulable state, treatment with vitamin K antagonists like warfarin for 3–6 months may be initiated and then converted to aspirin, depending on the degree of resolution of the venous sinus thrombus. 
    • In pregnant women:
      • Anticoagulation with LMWH throughout pregnancy and till 8 weeks postpartum.

questions.text: A traveler presents to your OPD with profuse watery diarrhea. You suspect it to be a case of cholera due to the recent outbreak in his hometown. You would recommend isolation of the patient until:

choices.text: A negative stool antigen test is obtained

questions.solution:
The duration of isolation recommended for a patient with cholera is until 3 days of antibiotic therapy.

Vibrio cholerae is a comma-shaped, gram-negative bacillus with darting motility. It has a single polar flagellum. It causes cholera, an acute diarrheal disease. It is marked by painless, profuse, watery diarrhea with flecks of mucus (rice-water stools) associated with effortless vomiting.

Infection is acquired by ingestion of contaminated food and water. The organisms produce an enterotoxin known as cholera toxin (CT). It has 1 A and 5 B subunits. The B subunit (binding units) fixes to the GM1 ganglioside receptors on jejunal epithelial cells. The A subunit dissociates into the A2 fragment, which attaches the A1 fragment to the B subunit. This results in prolonged accumulation of cAMP, which causes an outpouring of large amounts of water and electrolytes into the intestinal lumen. Ultimately, it results in profuse watery diarrhea. 

In addition to the cholera toxin, additional toxins such as zona occludens toxin and accessory cholera toxin are also produced. The former alters intestinal permeability by its action on intestinal epithelial cells. The characteristic darting mobility and its hindrance by antiserum can be used for rapid microscopic diagnosis.

Fluid resuscitation by rice-based ORS is recommended. Antibiotics that can be used include fluoroquinolones, tetracycline, Azithromycin, ampicillin, or Trimethoprim -Sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX).

Related Pearl: Periods of Isolation for Selected Diseases

questions.text: Which of the following EEG findings in a patient would warrant treatment with ACTH?
questions.solution:
ACTH is used in the management of children with infantile spasms. The EEG in image 4 shows the characteristic hypsarrhythmic pattern - high voltage waves with a chaotic background, that is typically seen in infantile spasms. 

 

Disease Typical EEG feature
 West syndrome

Hypsarrhythmia (high-voltage waves with chaotic background)

(Image 4)
Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD)

Periodic biphasic or triphasic sharp-wave complexes seen as spikes.

(Image 1)
Absence seizures

3 Hz spike and slow-wave (spike and dome pattern)

(Image 2)
Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy

4-5 Hz spike

(Image 3)
Lennox-Gastaut syndrome
  • 1-2 Hz spike and slow waves
  • polyspike bursts in sleep
  • slow background in wakefulness

 

Infantile epileptic spasm is an age-specific seizure disorder that predominantly occurs before the age of one. Some cases may be diagnosed late as this condition may be mistaken to be hyperirritability, exaggerated startle responses, and/or colic. 

Clinical features

  • Spasms involve the muscles of the neck, trunk, and extremities
  • They are symmetric and synchronous
  • There is an initial phasic contraction that lasts less than two seconds and involves sudden, brief, contractions of various muscle groups
  • The next phase is a tonic contraction phase that is less intense and lasts up to ten seconds
  • Motor arrest  or a period of attenuated responsiveness may occur following the contraction and lasts up to 90 seconds
  • Deviation of the eyes, nystagmus and change in respiratory pattern may be seen in some patients
  • Most patients develop neurodevelopmental delay
  • The triad of spasms, arrest of psychomotor development, and hypsarrhythmia is known as West syndrome

Diagnosis

  • EEG
    • Interictal: Hypsarrythmia is the defining feature of infantile spasms and is characterized by very high voltage, random, slow waves, and spikes in all cortical areas. These spikes vary in duration and location. This finding may precede the onset of spasms. Hypsarrhythmia is the typical interictal EEG finding, seen between episodes.
    • Ictal: The ictal EEG generally shows a high-voltage slow-wave transient followed by a general attenuation of activity. Electrodecremental response which is generalized attenuation may occur with or without clinical evidence of a seizure
  • Neuroimaging with CT/MRI is recommended in all patients
  • Metabolic and genetic testing may be done to identify the etiology
  • EMG reveals a characteristic rhomboid pattern which may help to distinguish between brief tonic and myoclonic seizures

Treatment

The major options for the treatment of IS include hormonal therapy, mainly corticotropin (ACTH), and antiseizure medication, mainly vigabatrin.

 

CJD is a spongiform encephalopathy caused by a prion. It presents as rapidly progressive dementia and is fatal within 1 year of onset of symptoms. The EEG shows periodic biphasic or triphasic sharp-wave complexes seen as spikes.

Patients present with myoclonus, akinetic mutism, cerebellar or visual disturbances and pyramidal/extrapyramidal dysfunction (hypokinesia). Insomnia, apathy and other behavioral abnormalities may be seen.

Four types of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease have been described:

  1. Sporadic (sCJD): Accounts for 85-90% of cases
    • MRI shows cortical ribbon sign
  2. Variant (vCJD): mad cow disease, Kuru
    • MRI shows hockey stick sign
  3. Familial (fCJD): 10% of cases (these individuals carry a PRPc mutation)
  4. Iatrogenic

CSF analysis shows a positive assay for 14-3-3 protein. Management is mainly supportive.

 

Absence seizures are characterised by sudden, brief lapse of consciousness with preserved postural control and no post-ictal confusion is seen in Absence seizures. Usually, the seizure lasts only a few seconds.

They are predominantly seen in children between four to ten years of age, with a decline in academic performance in school and unexplained 'daydreaming'.

The following subtle motor signs may accompany the episodes

  • Rapid blinking of the eyelids
  • Chewing movements
  • Small-amplitude clonic movement of the hands

EEG shows generalised symmetric 3 Hz spike and wave pattern. Hyperventilation can provokes these EEG discharges and seizures.

MRI appears normal hence not routinely recommended. Laboratory investigations are not specifically useful.

Ethosuximide is the drug of choice for uncomplicated typical absence seizure

Sodium valproate is the first-line therapy for absence seizures in cases associated with secondary GTCS and atypical absence

Drugs like carbamazepine, oxcarbazepine and phenytoin can worsen the absence, myoclonic, tonic and atonic seizures and are therefore avoided

 

Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy is also known as Janz syndrome. This disorder typically first manifests itself between the ages of 12 and 18. It presents with brief episodes of involuntary muscle twitching occurring early in the morning after awakening. They can be provoked by sleep deprivation. Most patients also have generalized seizures that affect the entire brain and many also have absence seizures. Myoclonic seizures are characterized by:

  • Preserved consciousness
  • Preserved postural control
  • Lack of postictal confusion

The EEG shows a bilaterally synchronous spike (4-5 Hz polyspike ) and slow-wave discharges. The drug of choice for juvenile myoclonic epilepsy is valproate (Sodium and calcium channel blocker). Lamotrigine is also useful.

questions.text: While reporting X-Rays in your radiology rotation, you notice a chest X-Ray with a characteristic egg-on-string appearance. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Egg-on-string appearance is the characteristic radiological sign on chest X-rays in transposition of great arteries (TGA). 

Here, the typical chest x-ray shows mild cardiomegaly, a narrow mediastinum (the classic egg-shaped heart or egg on a string appearance), with normal to increased pulmonary blood flow. Egg-on-a-string appearance refers to a globular-shaped heart due to an abnormal convexity of the right atrial border and left atrial enlargement.

ECHO is diagnostic. The size of the interatrial communication and the ductus arteriosus, the degree of mixing assessed, any associated ventricular outflow tract obstruction, or a septal defect, can be assessed by color Doppler examination. 

Pathology of TGA: The deoxygenated blood returning from the body goes inappropriately out the aorta and back to the body again, while oxygenated pulmonary venous blood is returned directly to the lungs. Survival in the immediate neonatal period is due to the mixture of oxygenated and deoxygenated blood provided by the foramen ovale and the ductus arteriosus. 50% of patients also have a ventricular septal defect (VSD).

TGA is the most specific heart disease in infants of diabetic mothers. 

Box-shaped heart is seen in Ebstein's anomaly. There is severe right-sided cardiomegaly due to an elongated and enlarged right atrium which leads to an elevated apex. 

Snowman heart is seen in total anomalous pulmonary venous return. It refers to the configuration of the heart and the superior mediastinal borders resembling a snowman. It is also referred to as the figure of 8 sign.

Boot shaped heart is seen in children with Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF).

 

 

Related Pearl: Radiological findings in some congenital heart defects

Boot shaped heart - Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF)

 

Egg on string appearance - Transposition of Great Arteries (TGA)

 

Snowman's heart appearance or figure of 8 appearance - Supracardiac TAPVC

 

Box Shaped Heart - Ebstein's Anomaly

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs in Congenital Heart Diseases

Anomaly Sign
Tetralogy of Fallot Coeur en sabot
Transposition of great vessels (TGV) Egg on string
Partial anomalous pulmonary venous return Scimitar sign
Total anomalous pulmonary venous return Snowman sign
Endocardial cushion defects Gooseneck sign
Ebstein anomaly Box-shaped heart

questions.text: Popular tactics used by marketing campaigns are based on the concept of priming. Which of the following structures is it dependent on?
questions.solution:
Facilitation of the recognition of words or objects by prior exposure to them is known as priming. Priming is dependent on the neocortex and is a form of implicit memory.

Memory is usually divided into two forms: Explicit or declarative memory is associated with consciousness or awareness. Implicit or nondeclarative memory does not involve awareness and its retention does not usually involve processing in the hippocampus. 

Explicit and many forms of implicit memory involve

  • Short-term memory and
  • Long-term memory.

Short-term memory:

It lasts seconds to minutes; the encoding process for short-term explicit memory involves the hippocampus. It lasts only until the person continues to think about the number or facts.

Working memory is a form of short-term memory that keeps the information available, usually for very short periods of time, until the individual plans actions based on it.

Long-term memory:

It stores memories that can be recollected after years or even for a lifetime. These memories are stored in various parts of the neocortex. The various parts of the memories, such as visual, auditory, and olfactory, are localized to the cortical regions concerned with these functions. All these parts of the memories are brought together by long-term changes in the strength of transmission at relevant synaptic junctions so that all the components are brought to consciousness when that particular memory is recalled.

Neural basis of memory:

The basis of memory is the alteration in the strength of the selected synaptic connections. Second messenger systems contribute to the changes in the neural circuits, which are required for learning and memory. Alterations in the cellular membrane channels also contribute to it. 

 

 

 

Related Pearl: Forms of Memory

From physiologic point of view memory is divided into explicit and implicit forms.

questions.text:
Sequentially arrange the steps involved in the progression of the action potential in a nerve cell.
  1. Na+ channels open in response to depolarizing stimulus.
  2. Sodium conductance decreases.
  3. Na+ channels close and K+ channels open. 
  4. Rapid depolarization occurs.
  5. Repolarization occurs.
  6. The membrane reaches threshold potential.
  7. Both channels are closed. The membrane returns to RMP.
questions.solution:
The sequence of events during the action potential occurs in the following sequence.

1. Resting-state: Both channels are closed

2. Na+ channels open in response to depolarizing stimulus. Sodium enters the cell. The membrane reaches threshold potential.

3. The sodium influx causes the opening of more Na+ channels through a positive feedback mechanism. Rapid depolarization occurs.

4. Sodium conductance decreases.

5. Na+ channels close and K+ channels open. Repolarization occurs.

6. Sodium channels are reset and are ready to respond to another depolarizing stimulus (relative refractory period). During this phase, the K+ channels remain open and slowly return to the closed state causing after-hyperpolarization.

7. Both channels are closed. The membrane returns to RMP.

Related Pearl: Graded potential vs Action potential

Graded Potential

Action Potential

Amplitude proportionate to strength of stimulus. It is graded.

Independent of stimulus intensity – all or none response

Can be depolarising or hyperpolarizing

Depolarizing

Is conducted decrementally - amplitude decreases with distance

Self-propagated unchanged in amplitude

Generated spontaneously or in response to stimuli- physical, chemical

Generated only in response to Membrane Depolarization

Can be summated

Cannot be summated

Has no threshold and refractory period

Has a threshold about 15 mv depolarized relative to the resting potential.

Has a refractory period

Not always followed by some action

Always followed by some action

questions.text:
Prompt surgical management would be indicated in a patient with Sheehan syndrome if there is _______.
  1. Significant visual loss
  2. Progressive visual loss
  3. Cranial nerve palsy
  4. Hypopituitarism
  5. Loss of consciousness
questions.solution:
Significant or progressive visual loss, cranial nerve palsy, or loss of consciousness are considered indications for urgent surgical decompression in patients with Sheehan syndrome (option B- 1, 2, 3, or 5).

Pituitary apoplexy is a hemorrhagic infarction of large pituitary adenomas or pituitary infarction due to traumatic major blood loss. If this blood loss occurs during delivery, it is called Sheehan syndrome. The hyperplastic enlargement of the pituitary, which occurs normally during pregnancy, increases the risk of hemorrhage and infarction. 

Affected women may have persistent hypotension, tachycardia, hypoglycemia, and lactation failure. The most prominent symptoms are lactation failure (due to a deficiency of prolactin) and postpartum amenorrhea (due to a deficiency of gonadotropins). Because deficiencies of some or all pituitary-responsive hormones may develop after the initial insult, Sheehan syndrome can be heterogeneous and may not be identified for years.

The acute presentation of pituitary apoplexy, an endocrine emergency, is characterized by a sudden onset of headache, nausea, visual deficits, and in severe cases, severe hypoglycemia, hypotension and shock, CNS hemorrhage, and death.

Other features are:

  • Loss of pubic and axillary hair
  • Hypothyroidism due to decreased TSH secretion 
  • Adrenal insufficiency due to low ACTH

Treatment is by hormone replacement: First, glucocorticoids and, later, thyroid hormone, sex steroids, vasopressin, and growth hormones are given. If there is evidence of progressive visual loss, cranial nerve involvement, or loss of consciousness, immediate surgical decompression must be carried out.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient with newly diagnosed class II pulmonary hypertension has a positive vasoreactivity test. Which of the following medications is used in the next step of management?
questions.solution:
Nifedipine is used as the next step in the management of a treatment-naive patient with class II pulmonary hypertension and a positive vasoreactivity test.

Pulmonary hypertension is defined as mean pulmonary arterial pressure greater than 20 mmHg with a pulmonary vascular resistance of ≥3 wood units. Exertional dyspnea, chest pain, fatigue, and lightheadedness are common early symptoms. With the progression of the disease, right ventricular dysfunction occurs which can cause syncope, abdominal distention, ascites, and peripheral edema.

Management for pulmonary hypertension:

Vasoreactivity testing involves the administration of inhaled nitric oxide, IV epoprostenol, IV adenosine, or inhaled iloprost. The test is considered positive if the mean pulmonary arterial pressure (mPAH) decreases by ≥ 10 mmHg leading to mPAH ≤ 40 mmHg, without a decrease in cardiac output (CO).

  • Positive vasoreactivity test: Calcium channel blockers are indicated. Long-acting nifedipine, diltiazem, or amlodipine are used.

  • Negative vasoreactivity test:
    • For patients with lower risk (class II, III) based on clinical assessment: Oral therapy with endothelin receptor antagonists like ambrisentan, sitaxsentan, bosentan, or phosphodiesterase 5 inhibitors like sildenafil, tadalafil is the first line of therapy.
    • For patients with higher risk (class IV) based on clinical assessment: Continuous treatment with IV prostacyclins (epoprostenol or treprostinil) would be the first line of therapy recommended.

  • Lung transplantation and/or atrial septostomy are reserved for patients who progress despite optimal medical treatment.

 The image below shows the treatment algorithm for pulmonary hypertension:


The table below provides information on the prognosis of PAH:

Determinants  Low risk  High risk
Clinical evidence of RV failure No Yes
Progression of symptoms Gradual

Rapid
Echocardiography Minimal RV dysfunction Pericardial effusion, significant RV enlargement/dysfunction, right atrial enlargement
WHO functional class  II, III IV
6min walk distance Longer (>400 m) Shorter (<300 m)
BNP Minimally elevated Significantly elevated

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrectly paired?

choices.text: Brenner tumors - Sex cord stromal tumor
Sertoli cell tumor - Sex cord stromal tumor

questions.solution:
Brenner tumor/ transitional cell tumor is an epithelial tumor not a sex cord-stromal tumor

Brenner tumors are uncommon tumors of the ovary. They are typically small to moderate-sized tumors and are mostly benign. However, rarely, if tumors are seen with benign Brenner nests admixed with malignant tumor cells, they are known as malignant Brenner tumors. If it has greater than 50% malignant transitional type epithelium, then it is known as transitional cell carcinomas of the ovary.

Clinically, they may present with vague abdominopelvic pain in postmenopausal women and are mostly detected incidentally as in this patient. Histopathologically, they are characterized by fibrous tissue with interspersed nests of transitional epithelium. These cells may have nuclei with a characteristic longitudinal groove. 

Related Pearl: WHO Classification of Ovarian Tumors

I.  Epithelial tumors (most common)

  • Serous tumors
  • Mucinous tumors
  • Endometrioid tumors
  • Clear cell 
  • Brenner tumors (transitional cell tumors)
  • Seromucinous
  • Undifferentiated carcinoma
II. Sex cord-stromal tumors:

questions.text:
Arrange the following in ascending order of their normal values
  1. Total lung capacity
  2. Vital capacity
  3. Inspiratory capacity
  4. Tidal Volume
questions.solution:
Ascending order of their normal values would be

  • Tidal Volume(TV) - 500–750 mL
  • Inspiratory capacity (IC) - ∼3.5 L (TV+ IRV -Inspiratory Reserve Volume)
  • Vital capacity(VC) - ∼4.5 L (IRV+TV+ERV - Expiratory Reserve Volume) 
  • Total lung capacity (TLC) -∼5.8 L (IRV+TV+ERV+RV) 

While this question can be solved if you know the values by heart, you can also solve this if you know the concepts about lung volumes and capacities well, without recollecting the absolute values. INI-CET often asks such seemingly mundane facts which can also be solved by just having a solid conceptual understanding.

Related Pearl: Lung volumes and capacities

Measurement

Description

Normal Value

Tidal volume (TV)

The amount of air that moves into the lungs with each inspiration (or the amount that moves out with each expiration) during quiet breathing

500–750 mL.

Inspiratory reserve volume (IRV)

The air inspired with a maximal inspiratory effort in excess of the TV

∼3 L

Expiratory reserve volume (ERV)

The volume expelled by an active expiratory effort after passive expiration

∼1.1 L

Residual volume (RV)

The air left in the lungs after a maximal expiratory effort

∼1.2 L

Total lung capacity (TLC)

IRV+TV+ERV+RV

∼5.8 L

Vital capacity (VC)

IRV+TV+ERV

∼4.5 L

Inspiratory capacity (IC)

TV+IRV

∼3.5 L

Expiratory capacity (EC)

TV+ERV

∼1.6 L

Functional residual capacity (FRC)

ERV+RV

∼2.3 L

questions.text: A gardener from the sub-Himalayan region presents to the OPD with the following lesions. On microscopy from tissue biopsy, flower-like clusters of conidia are seen. Which of the following is the drug of choice for the treatment of his condition?
questions.solution:
The presence of multiple vesicles on hand and multiple eruptions along lymphatics in a gardener from the sub-Himalayan region, and the microscopic finding of flower-like clusters of conidia are suggestive of lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis. Itraconazole is the drug of choice for the treatment of lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis.

Sporothrix schenckii causes sporotrichosis, a chronic granulomatous disease, by traumatic inoculation into the skin. This is usually followed by spread along the draining lymphatics and lymph nodes. 

It is a thermally dimorphic fungus. It is in the yeast phase in tissues and in cultures at 37°C, and in the mycelia phase in nature and cultures at 25°C. When it is cultured, the colonies are blackish-brown and fuzzy. The organism produces branching, septate hyphae, and microconidia clustered at the ends of conidiophores. It exists as cigar-shaped yeast cells. Stains used for identifying yeast forms: 

  • Gomori methenamine silver - cell wall appears black
  • Periodic acid-Schiff stain - cell wall appears red 
  • Fluorescent antibody staining

The image given below shows, (A)- (i) culture at 37°C (ii) culture at 25°C. (B) fungi with clustered microconidia with conidiophore.  (C) magnified image showing branching and septate hyphae.

Clinical features: The initial infection develops as a nodule, which may break down to form a necrotic or ulcerative lesion. Untreated, the disease progresses and new nodules develop along the lymphatics leading to a chain of nodules. Less commonly it may also cause systemic infection following inhalation, which causes local pulmonary disease or may lead to widely disseminated lesions in joints, meninges, and skin.

Treatment: Itraconazole is the drug of choice for lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis. 

Other treatment options for lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis:

  • Terbinafine
  • SSKI- Saturated solution of potassium iodide
  • Fluconazole
  • Local hyperthermia

Pulmonary sporotrichosis & osteoarticular sporotrichosis are also treated with itraconazole in mild to moderate cases. But, liposomal amphotericin B can be used in patients that are seriously ill with severe or life-threatening disease.

Meningeal sporotrichosis is treated with amphotericin B, as it is the drug of choice for meningeal sporotrichosis. Itraconazole is used for step-down therapy in these patients. 

 

Related Pearl: Classification of fungus based on morphology

Fungi are classified into 4 types based on their morphology:

  • Yeast
  • Yeast-like
  • Molds
  • Dimorphic fungi

Yeast:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding
  • Oval to round forms
  • Example: Cryptococcus, Saccharomyces.

 

Yeast like:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding or binary fission
  • Spherical or oval forms
  • Pseudohyphae may be seen.
  • Example: Candida, Malassezia furfur.

 

Molds/filamentous fungi:

  • Have hyphae which may be septate or aseptate
  • Aseptate or coenocytic hyphae – Rhizopus, mucor, Lichtheimia.
  • Septate hyphae – Penicillium, Dermatophytes, Aspergillus, fusarium.

 

Dimorphic fungi

  • Filamentous forms in the culture at 220C – 250C and in the environment.
  • Yeast form in the culture at 370C and in tissues.
  • Examples – Histoplasma capsulatum, Blastomyces dermatitidis, Coccidioides immitis, Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, Talaromyces marneffei, Sporothrix schenckii.

questions.text: An ultrasound image of the lung would show a seashore sign in case of a _____.
questions.solution:
An ultrasound image of the lung would show a seashore sign in case of a normal lung.

On M-mode, classical signs for the grayscale imaging are seen:
• Seashore sign: normal lung
• Barcode/stratosphere sign: pneumothorax

The M-mode image in the pneumothorax demonstrates a linear, laminar pattern in the tissue superficial to the pleural line and a similar linear pattern deep to the pleural line. This phenomenon, known as the stratosphere sign or barcode sign, indicates absent lung sliding and suggests the presence of pneumothorax.

The M-mode image of a normal lung demonstrates a linear, laminar pattern in the tissue superficial to the pleural line and a granular or sandy appearance deep to the pleural line. This phenomenon is known as the seashore sign, and it indicates normal lung sliding and excludes pneumothorax at this interspace.

Pleural effusion on ultrasound appears anechoic with an echogenic line at the fluid-lung interface if it is transudate. Exudative and hemorrhagic effusions may appear echogenic with pleural thickening. The fluid shows movement and changes in shape with breathing, along with the presence of septa and fibrous strands.

Consolidation on ultrasound appears hypoechoic with heterogeneous echotexture. It is isoechoic with the liver and is referred to as lung hepatization. 

A collapsed lung under a large effusion will be seen as a hyperechoic wedge-shaped area.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with box car nuclei seen on histopathological examination of the myocytes?
questions.solution:
In hypertensive heart disease, the individual myocytes are enlarged and show nucleomegaly. These nuclei are called box car nuclei.

The most important histologic features of HOCM myocardium are as follows:

  1. Massive myocyte hypertrophy
  2. Haphazard disarray of bundles of myocytes, individual myocytes, and contractile elements in sarcomeres within cells. This is termed myofiber disarray.
  3. Interstitial and replacement fibrosis

Myocyte vacuolization, also called myocytolysis, is associated with subendocardial ischemia.

Dilated cardiomyopathy is also associated with massive myocyte hypertrophy.

The best answer for box-car nuclei on histopathological examination is Hypertension> Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. Box car nuclei are seen in the setting of hypertension resulting in left ventricular hypertrophy even in those without any hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

questions.text: A patient with hypercholesterolemia and type 2 diabetes is advised to take colesevelam. What is the mechanism of action of this drug?

choices.text: Binding of bile acid in the intestine

questions.solution:
Colesevelam is a bile acid–binding resin that binds bile acid in the intestine.

Colesevelam is the only bile acid sequestrant specifically approved for the treatment of type 2 diabetes and is used as an adjunct to diet and exercise. It is also approved for the treatment of hypercholesterolemia. 

Class HMG-CoA reductase inhibitors (statins) Fibrates Niacin Bile acid–binding resins Ezetimibe
Important examples

Lovastatin, atorvastatin, fluvastatin, pravastatin, simvastatin, rosuvastatin, pitavastatin

Gemfibrozil and fenofibrate

 Niacin  

Colestipol, cholestyramine, colesevelam

 Ezetimibe
Mechanism of action

Inhibits HMG-CoA reductase

PPAR-α mediated increased lipolysis

 Decreases the production of VLDLs and decreases the catabolism of HDLs Binds to bile acids in the intestinal lumen and increases excretion. This results in increased conversion of hepatic cholesterol to bile acids, and reduction in hepatic cholesterol content. Inhibits intestinal sterol absorption
Major effects on lipoprotein levels

Reduces LDL levels

Reduces triglyceride levels

A moderate increase in HDL levels

Reduces triglycerides,  LDL, and lipoprotein a levels

Significant increase HDL levels

 Reduces LDL levels 

Reduces LDL cholesterol

Minimal increase in HDL level

Also decreases the absorption of phytosterols
Important side effects Myopathy

Elevations of serum aminotransferase activity

Elevation of creatine kinase activity

Rashes, gastrointestinal symptoms, myopathy, arrhythmias

Hypokalemia, elevated aminotransferases, or alkaline phosphatase 

Cutaneous vasodilation

Elevations in aminotransferases levels

May increase plasma triglycerides

Rarely myositis

questions.text: You must advise for partner treatment of STD while prescribing all of the following kits, except ____.
questions.solution:
Herpetic genital ulcers are managed using the red kit and partner treatment is not necessary.

All partners for the past 3 months need to be treated in those receiving white or blue kits (non-herpetic genital ulcer), while all partners for the past 3 weeks need treatment in case of black kit administration (inguinal bubo).

 

Related Pearl: Syndromic Management of Sexually Transmitted Infections

Partner Management when asymptomatic is not required for Gardenella vaginalis, Candida and Herpes infections.

questions.text: Which of the following pairs of electron microscopy finding and disease is incorrect?

choices.text: Linear deposits along the basement membrane - Goodpasture syndrome
Mesangial and paramesangial dense deposits - IgA nephropathy

questions.solution:
Basket-weave appearance of the glomerular basement membrane (GBM) is seen in the case of Alport syndrome. 

Alport syndrome or hereditary nephritis is a genetic disease caused by mutations in the genes coding for type IV collagen. This is a major component of the basement membranes. The majority of the patients have an X-linked inheritance. Clinical features include hematuria, proteinuria, and sensorineural hearing loss. Ocular manifestations include anterior lenticonus, macular flecks, and corneal dystrophy.

Light microscopy appears normal during the first decade of life. Later glomeruli may have mesangial proliferation and capillary wall thickening. This may lead to progressive sclerosis of the glomerulus. Electron microscopy shows diffuse thickening and thinning along with splitting of glomerular and tubular basement membranes. It is seen as a characteristic basket weaving appearance of lamina densa as shown below.

No specific therapy is recommended to treat Alport syndrome. Proteinuria can be treated with angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors or angiotensin 2 receptor blockers.

Subepithelial deposits are seen on electron microscopy in cases of membranous nephropathy. It typically has a noninflammatory pathology. It presents as a nephrotic syndrome in most patients. Non-nephrotic proteinuria, hematuria, and mild hypertension can be seen in some cases.

Some glomerular diseases may progress from one pattern to another or may present with considerable overlap between them, as a nephritic–nephrotic syndrome; features of nephrotic syndrome can concurrently occur with any form of nephritic syndrome but are most commonly seen with diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis (seen in systemic lupus erythematosus) and membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis.

questions.text: All of the following conditions show the pattern of inheritance that corresponds to the pedigree chart below except:
questions.solution:
The pattern of inheritance shown in the pedigree chart is mitochondrial inheritance. Tuberous sclerosis is inherited in an autosomal dominant manner, not by mitochondrial inheritance. 

The unique feature of mitochondrial inheritance is maternal inheritance. The mitochondrial DNA of the zygote is completely derived from the ovum. Therefore, when the mother is affected and the father is normal, all their children will be affected. 

However, children will not be affected if they are born to a normal mother and an affected father. Only the daughters of the affected mother will further transmit the disease to the next generations.

 

 
Features of mitochondrial inheritance:
  • The mitochondrial DNA encodes enzymes required for oxidative phosphorylation. The organs of the central nervous system, skeletal muscle, cardiac muscle, liver, and kidneys are affected as they are most dependent on oxidative phosphorylation.
  • Heteroplasmy is a phenomenon in which the individual has both wild-type and mutant type of mtDNA. 
  • Threshold effect is defined as a minimum number of copies of mutant mtDNA to be present in the mitochondria that can lead to oxidative dysfunction to manifest the disease.
  • The expression of the disease varies even among different cells of an organ. This is because there is a variable distribution of the normal and mutant mtDNA to the cells.

questions.text: Which of the following occurs during REM sleep?
questions.solution:
Nocturnal penile tumescence occurs during REM sleep.

Somnambulism, night terrors, and nocturnal enuresis occur during NREM sleep.

 

Related Pearl: Events occurring in NREM and REM sleep

Events occurring during NREM stages 3 and 4:

Events

Description

Somnambulism

Sleepwalking

Sleep terror or Night terror

Also called pavor nocturnus.

Awakens with a scream or intense anxiety. Has increased autonomic disturbances.

They do not have a memory of this when they wake up.

Runs in families and seen more frequently in childhood and boys.

Treatment with benzodiazepines is rarely required.

Nocturnal enuresis

Behavioral therapy is the mainstay.

Drugs like desmopressin and imipramine are used.

 

Events occurring in REM sleep:

Events

Description

Nightmares

Fearful sleep without autonomic disturbances that are well remembered in the morning.

TCAs may be used for treatment.

Nocturnal penile tumescence

A normal phenomenon that can be used to differentiate between psychogenic and organic impotence.

Narcolepsy

A disorder of the REM sleep characterized by disturbed sleep in the night, leading to excessive sleep in the morning.

Associated with symptoms such as cataplexy, hypnogogic and hypnopompic hallucination, and sleep paralysis.

 *Hypnogogic hallucinations are those that occur at the start of sleep and hypnopompic hallucinations are those that occur at the end of sleep.

 

Others:

Events

Description

Bruxism (teeth grinding)

Occurs in stage 2 NREM sleep.

Frontal lobe epilepsy

Occurs in stage 2 NREM sleep.

Sleep talking

Occurs in all stages of sleep and may accompany night terrors and sleepwalking.

Common in children.

No treatment is necessary.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a contraindication for performing the following procedure in a patient with pancreatic carcinoma?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the Whipple procedure. It is not contraindicated in pancreatic carcinoma patients with peripancreatic lymph node involvement.
 
Contraindications for resection:
  • Liver metastases of any size
  • Celiac lymph node involvement
  • Peritoneal implants
  • Hepatic hilar lymph node involvement

Findings that are not considered contraindications for resection:

  • Duodenum or distal stomach invasion
  • Peripancreatic lymph node involvement
  • Involvement of Lymph nodes along the porta hepatis that can be swept down with the specimen 
 
The Whipple procedure is a complex surgery done for carcinomas involving the head of the pancreas.

The following structures are removed during the Whipple procedure:

  • Distal stomach
  • Duodenum
  • Head of the pancreas
  • Gallbladder
  • Common bile duct (CBD)
  • Regional lymphatics

questions.text: What is the drug of choice for the treatment of the severe form of the disease, caused by the organism whose life cycle is shown below?
questions.solution:
The life cycle shown in the above image is suggestive of leptospirosis. Severe form of leptospirosis should be treated with IV penicillin administration.

It is caused by contact with the urine or blood of an infected organism. It is a zoonotic disease, with rats being the most well-known reservoirs. 

Illness is classically biphasic after an incubation period of up to 1 month. The stages are: 

  • Acute leptospiremic phase- organism can be cultured from blood.
  • Resolving immune phase- organism can be cultured from urine.

The stages may not be clinically distinguishable.

Most cases are asymptomatic, but a few may present with severe manifestations. Clinical features include: 

  • High-grade fever
  • Hepatic dysfunction 
  • Renal impairment
  • Hemorrhages- gastrointestinal, pulmonary (most common), petechiae and purpura

The severe form is known as Weil's disease, with a triad of hemorrhage, jaundice, and acute kidney injury. 

Treatment of Leptospirosis

  • Mild leptospirosis
    • Doxycycline (100 mg PO bid), or
    • Amoxicillin (500 mg PO tid), or
    • Ampicillin (500 mg PO tid)
  • Moderate/severe leptospirosis
    • Penicillin (1.5 million units IV or IM q6h) or
    • Ceftriaxone (2 g/d IV) or
    • Cefotaxime (1 g IV q6h) or
    • Doxycycline (loading dose of 200 mg IV, then 100 mg IV q12h)
  • Chemoprophylaxis
    • Azithromycin (250 mg PO once or twice a week), or
    • Doxycycline (200 mg PO once a week)

Unlike the usual Marrow Image above, the image in the question has lesser clarity so that users get a bit of a taste of the actual INI-CET Exam. This is an image from a previous INI-CET exam and the image was not zoomable in the exam. Those who saw the spirochete-like appearance, rat, and rice field narrowed down the organism by elimination and marked the correct answer. So, pay attention to detail and watch out for any information that you can get from an image to answer questions, even if the image is not clear.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the role of urea in renal function?

choices.text: A high-protein diet increases the  kidneys ' ability to concentrate urine
High vasopressin increases the urea deposition in the medullary interstitium
Urea is transported by urea transport proteins (UT-A) by secondary active transport
A low-protein diet reduces the kidneys’ ability to concentrate urine

questions.solution:
Urea is transported by urea transport proteins (UT-A) by facilitated diffusion.

Urea is essential for the establishment of an osmotic gradient in the medullary pyramids and for forming concentrated urine in the collecting ducts. 

During antidiuresis, high vasopressin increases urea deposition in the medullary interstitium, thus increasing the kidney's concentrating capacity.

The amount of urea in the medullary interstitium and, consequently, in the urine varies with the amount of urea filtered by the glomerulus, which is dependent on the dietary intake of protein. Therefore, a high-protein diet increases the kidney's ability to concentrate urine and a low-protein diet reduces the kidneys’ ability to concentrate urine.

questions.text: A man from Bihar presented with normoanesthetic hypopigmented lesion as shown below. He had a remote history of admission for fever. No thickened nerves are present. What is the best-suited management?
questions.solution:
The case scenario suggests a diagnosis of post-kala-azar dermal leishmaniasis (PKDL). According to the NVBDCP, miltefosine is the preferred first-line drug for the management of PKDL.

Post-kala-azar dermal leishmaniasis (PKDL) is a condition when Leishmania donovani is found in the skin and manifests as dermal lesions. It is usually seen in the kala-azar-endemic zones, i.e., Bihar, Jharkhand, U.P, and West Bengal (Northeastern states of India).

These patients present with erythematous rash and hypopigmented macules similar in appearance and distribution to those of lepromatous leprosy but normally less than 1cm. After a variable period of years or months, diffuse nodulation begins to develop in these macules. The rash is progressive over many years and seldom heals spontaneously.

Miltefosine is a relatively safe oral drug for the treatment of PKDL. Oral miltefosine treatment is administered to adults weighing more than 25 kg as 50 mg twice daily for 12 weeks. 

The image below shows post-kala-azar cutaneous leishmaniasis.

questions.text:
Sequentially arrange the following steps involved in the production of antibodies using the hybridoma technique.
  1. Culture in HAT medium
  2. Immunization of mice with the target antigen & wait for few weeks
  3. Antibody-producing spleen cell & myeloma cell fusion
  4. Blood sample analysis to analyze serum target antibody levels
  5. Mice euthanization & spleen removal
  6. Harvesting of monoclonal antibodies
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of steps involved in the production of antibodies using the hybridoma technique is as follows:

  1. Immunization of mice with the target antigen & wait for few weeks
  2. Blood sample analysis to analyze serum target antibody levels
  3. Mice euthanization & spleen removal
  4. Antibody-producing spleen cell & myeloma cell fusion
  5. Culture in HAT medium
  6. Harvesting of monoclonal antibodies

Hybridoma technology is a method for producing large numbers of identical antibodies (monoclonal antibodies).

Hybridomas are somatic cell hybrids produced by fusing the antibody-forming spleen cells with myeloma cells. The resultant hybrid thus has both the antibody-producing ability of the B-cell and the ability to multiply indefinitely of the myeloma.

The following are the steps involved in hybridoma technology:

  • Mice are immunized with an antigen.
  • After several weeks of immunization, blood samples are obtained from mice for measurement of serum antibodies.
  • When the antibody titer is high enough, mice are commonly boosted by injecting antigen without adjuvant, intraperitoneally or intravenously.
  • Then the mice are euthanized and their spleens removed for in vitro hybridoma cell production.
  • Fusing antibody-producing spleen cells, which have a limited life span, with myeloma cells (derived from an immortal tumor of lymphocytes) results in a hybridoma that is capable of unlimited growth.
  • The cells are cultured in a medium containing hypoxanthine, aminopterin, and thymidine (HAT medium) which allows only the fused cells to survive in culture.
  • Monoclonal antibodies are then harvested.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases occurs as a consequence of genomic imprinting?
questions.solution:
The phenomenon of a differential effect of the same gene from different parents is called genomic imprinting. Prader-Willi syndrome occurs as a result of genomic imprinting.

Genomic imprinting refers to gene silencing/ inactivation. Here either the maternal or the paternal allele is inactivated resulting in only one functional allele. It occurs via the process of epigenetics, where gene expression is lowered by:

  • DNA methylation
  • Histone deacetylation

Genomic imprinting is best illustrated by two uncommon genetic disorders: Prader-Willi syndrome and Angelman syndrome.

  Prader-Willi syndrome  AngelMan syndrome

Deletion 

(most common)

Paternal chromosome 15

Maternal chromosome 15

Uniparental disomy 

(less common)

 Maternal disomy (duplication)  Paternal disomy (duplication) 
Clinical features

Elevated ghrelin levels - hyperphagia

Truncal obesity

Severe hypotonia

Short stature

Small hands and feet with hypotonia

Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism

Cognitive impairment

Short stature

Severe mental retardation with a lack of speech

Stiff arm movements

Spastic, uncoordinated walk (ataxia)

Seizures

Inappropriate outbursts of laughter (happy puppets)

The image given below is a child with Prader-Willi syndrome.

 

The image given below is a child with Angelman syndrome.

 

Diagnosis of these syndromes is based on the assessment of the methylation status of marker genes and fluorescence in-situ hybridization (FISH).

Mnemonic:

Prader–Willi Syndrome: Paternal gene deletion - P for P
Angelman syndrome: Maternal gene deletion (Mothers are Angels, Maternal gene deletion leads to Angelman syndrome)

 

 

  • Patau syndrome - Trisomy 13- Atrial septal defect, ventricular septal defect, valve abnormalities
  • Cri du chat - Partial aneuploidy/ deletion of chromosome 5p15.2- Atrial septal defect, ventricular septal defect, tetralogy of Fallot
  • Noonan syndrome - Pulmonic stenosis, atrial septal defect, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy

questions.text: Which of the following women would not be diagnosed as having polycystic ovarian syndrome as per the  Rotterdam criteria?

choices.text: 29-year-old woman with Alopecia & acne and cycles of length 40 days
31-year-old woman with an ovary measuring 12 cm and cycles of length 42 days
23-year-old woman with ovaries showing 7 follicles of 1-2 mm diameter and hirsutism
27-year-old-woman with severe hirsutism, acne and a cycle length of 38 days

questions.solution:
Polycystic ovaries is defined as ≥ 12 follicles measuring 2‐9 mm in diameter and/or an ovarian volume > 10 mL in at least one ovary as per the Rotterdam criteria.

Polycystic ovarian syndrome is the most common endocrine disorder in a reproductive-age woman. Rotterdam criteria is used to diagnose PCOS. It is an algorithm and diagnosis is made only after excluding other causes. To diagnose both of the following criteria should be present:

1) Irregular menstrual cycles is defined as

  • normal cycles in the first year post menarche (due to pubertal transition).
  • < 21 or > 45 days in 1-3 years post menarche
  • < 21 or > 35 days or < 8 cycles per year > 3 years post menarche to perimenopause.
  •  > 90 days for any one cycle > 1-year post menarche
  • Primary amenorrhea by age 15 or > 3 years post thelarche (breast development).

2) Clinical/Biochemical hyperandrogenism characterised by alopecia, acne, hirsutism

If only one of the criteria can be established, then an endovaginal/transabdominal ultrasound to demonstrate polycystic ovaries should be done (confirmatory).

PCOS can increase the risk for:

  • Cardiovascular disease 
  • Obstructive sleep apnea
  • Gestational and type 2 diabetes mellitus
  • Endometrial cancer
  • Hirsutism
  • Acanthosis nigricans

Related Pearl: Endocrinological changes of PCOD

  1. Elevated Estrone/E1 levels.
  2. LH level is raised over 10 IU/mL. FSH level remains normal to low, but FSH/LH ratio falls.
  3. Testosterone and epi-androstenedione levels rise.
    • Testosterone elevated but < 200 ng/dL (normal range 20 -80 ng/dL)
    • Testosterone > 200 ng/dL suggests androgen-secreting ovarian tumor
    • DHEA-S values may be normal or slightly elevated
    • DHEA >700 ng/mL suggests adrenal tumour
  4. Serum SHBG is reduced.
  5. Triglyceride level >150 mg/dL-hyperlipidaemia HDL <50 mg/dL.
  6. Fasting blood glucose/fasting insulin <4.5 suggests insulin resistance
  7. Prolactin is mildly raised in 15% cases
  8. Fasting insulin is more than 10 mIU/L in PCOS in 50–70%cases
  9. Thyroid function tests may be abnormal (hypothyroidism)
  10. 17-a-hydroxyprogesterone in the follicular phase >300 ng/dL suggests adrenal hyperplasia due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency.
  11. Urinary cortisol <50 μg/24 h.

Related Pearl: Management of PCOD

Complaint Management  
Irregular periods OCPs
Obesity Lifestyle modification
Insulin resistance Metformin
Hirsutism /acne OCPs with cyproterone acetate
Infertility Clomiphene

Note: Letrozole is as effective as Clomiphene in treating infertility in PCOD with fewer side effects. However, it's pending FDA approval and is used off-label.

questions.solution:
Image 3 shows a brick-shaped virus corresponding to the poxvirus. Tobacco mosaic virus is rod-shaped, as shown below

 

 

Option B - Adenovirus contains double-stranded DNA. They have an icosahedral symmetry with structures known as fibers extruding from the vertices. 

Option A - Rotaviruses appear as cartwheel-shaped structures with short spokes radiating from them.
