questions.text: Which of the following suturing techniques would yield the best cosmetic results?
questions.solution:
Subcuticular suturing, seen in image 4, would yield the best cosmetic results.

Subcuticular sutures: 

It is used for a better cosmetic appearance. It is also employed in situations where the edges of the wound are easily approximated. In this technique, small bites of the subcuticular tissues are taken on alternate sites of the wound, and then, they are gently pulled together. This causes approximation of the wound edges without the risk of the cross-hatched markings of interrupted sutures.

Both absorbable and non-absorbable suture materials can be used in this technique. A buried knot is secured with the ends of absorbable sutures when used. When non-absorbable sutures are used, a collar and bead are used to secure the ends of the suture.

In interrupted sutures, the needle should be inserted at right angles to the incision and should exit at a right angle with the skin. The needle should be rotated through the tissue and should not be dragged through to avoid unnecessary enlargement of the needle hole. If 'x' is the depth of the wound, then the distance from the entry point of the suture to the edge of the wound must be 'x'. Distance between 2 consecutive sutures must be '2x'. 

The following image shows interrupted suture:

Continuous suture technique: The first suture is inserted in a manner identical to that in an interrupted suture. The remaining sutures are inserted in a continuous manner until the far end of the wound is reached. Care should be taken to maintain the tension of the suture to avoid excessive tension or leaving it too slack; hence, the use of an assistant is warranted. An Aberdeen knot is used to secure the end of the suture.

The image below shows continuous sutures:

Mattress sutures: They can be vertical or horizontal and are used to create either an eversion or inversion of the wound edges. The initial suture is inserted in the same way as an interrupted suture, but then, the needle either moves horizontally or vertically and traverses both edges of the wound once again, as seen in the figure. The main advantage of the mattress suture is that it produces an accurate approximation of wound edges, especially in settings where the edges are not easily approximated.

The following image shows the mattress suture technique:

questions.text:
Sequentially arrange the following structures that are involved in the production & conduction of otoacoustic emissions(OAEs).
  1. Outer hair cells
  2. Basilar membrane
  3. Oval window
  4. Perilymph
  5. Ossicles
  6. Tympanic membrane
questions.solution:
The structures involved in the production & transmission of otoacoustic emission in order of their involvement are:

  • Outer hair cells
  • Basilar membrane
  • Perilymph
  • Oval window
  • Ossicles
  • Tympanic membrane
  • Ear canal

Otoacoustic emissions (OAE) are used in the universal neonatal hearing screening protocol. Universal Newborn Hearing Screening (UNHS) has become a standard practice in most developed countries. The identification of all newborns with hearing loss before 6 months has become an attainable and realistic goal. The goal is to screen newborn babies before 1 month of age, diagnose hearing loss before 3 months of age and start intervention as early as possible, or by 6 months of age.

Related Pearl: OAEs - Otoacoustic emissions

It is an objective test that records the low-intensity sounds produced by the outer hair cells of a normal cochlea.

It is of two types:

  • Spontaneous type- it is generated spontaneously and is present in 50% of normal individuals.
  • Evoked types- also called Kemp echoes or cochlear echoes, are generated in response to sound stimulus and found in all individuals with normal hearing. The two subtypes are transient evoked and distortion product.

The applications are as follows:

  • Screening test for neonates, infants, and small children for deafness due to inner ear causes.
  • Helps to differentiate cochlear and retrocochlear hearing loss- normal OAE indicates normal cochlea and hence retrocochlear pathology in a patient with sensorineural deafness.
  • Early detection of noise-induced hearing loss- since it is generated by outer hair cells that are prone to damage by noise trauma.

Related Pearl: BERA (Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry) or ABR (Auditory Brainstem Response)

It is an objective test that records electrical activity occurring in the auditory pathway.

Normally, 7 waves are produced in the first 10ms. 

  • Wave I – distal part of the cochlear nerve
  • Wave II –proximal part of the cochlear nerve
  • Wave III – cochlear nucleus
  • Wave IV – superior olivary complex
  • Wave V – lateral lemniscus
  • Wave VI & VII – inferior colliculus

Findings:

  • Conductive or cochlear pathology- delayed wave-I but inter-peak latency of I-V is normal
  • Retrocochlear pathology- wave-I present, rest of the waves absent
  • Acoustic neuroma or vestibular schwannoma- increased inter-peak latency of wave I-V and increased inter-aural latency of wave V > 0.2ms.

Uses:

  • To objectively find hearing threshold- wave-V appears 10dB above the hearing level obtained through PTA
  • Best audiometric test for:
    • Confirming hearing loss in infants
    • Diagnosing acoustic neuroma
    • Differentiating cochlear and retro-cochlear hearing loss
    • Diagnosing non-organic hearing loss.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding hematological changes in pregnancy is false?

choices.text: Protein C, protein S, and antithrombin decrease
Clotting time and bleeding time are unaffected.
The normal albumin: globulin ratio of 1.7:1 is diminished to 1:1

questions.solution:
The viscosity of blood decreases due to relative hemodilution.

Pregnancy is a hypercoagulable state. This is in order to control bleeding and help in hemostasis after placental separation. Hematological changes in pregnancy include:

  • All clotting factors are increased, except factors 11 and 13. The levels return to normal within 2 weeks of delivery.
  • Anticoagulants protein C, protein S, and antithrombin decrease during pregnancy.
  • Fibrinogen levels are also increased by 50 %.
  • Clotting time and bleeding time are unaffected.
  • The viscosity of blood decreases due to relative hemodilution (relatively higher increase in plasma volume as compared to the increase in RBC mass).
  • ESR is raised due to an increase in fibrinogen and globulin levels.
  • Because of a marked fall in albumin level and only a slight rise of globulin, the normal albumin: globulin ratio of 1.7:1 is diminished to 1:1.
  • Platelet counts remain the same or fall by a small amount (15%).

The most common cause of decreased platelet count in pregnancy is benign gestational thrombocytopenia. This is due to hemodilution and increased platelet consumption and the women are generally asymptomatic.

Related Pearl: Cardiovascular changes in pregnancy

  • The resting pulse rate increases by 10 beats/min
  • The apex is moved laterally 
  • Cardiac output remains elevated throughout (maximum in the immediate postpartum period)
  • X-Ray shows a larger cardiac silhouette (due to benign pericardial effusion and shifted apex)
  • ECG: Slight left axis deviation

Heart sounds:

  • First heart sound: Loud with an exaggerated split
  • Second heart sound: Normal but loud
  • Third heart sound: Loud and easily heard

Murmurs:

  • A systolic murmur that was intensified during inspiration or expiration
  • A soft diastolic murmur (in 20%)
  • Continuous murmur arising from the breast vasculature (in 10%)

questions.text: Which of the following finding is unlikely to be seen in a patient with radial nerve injury due to elbow dislocation?

choices.text: Loss of extension of the metacarpophalangeal joints of the hand
Weakness of thumb extension and retroposition

questions.solution:
In a patient with radial nerve injury due to elbow dislocation,  wrist extension is preserved because the branch to the extensor carpi radialis longus arises proximal to the elbow.

 

Radial nerve injuries

In very high lesions like the lesions around the shoulder joint & axilla and crutch palsy - there is loss of extension of the elbow, wrist, and hand.

In high lesions like fractures of the humerus and prolonged tourniquet pressure, there is wrist drop, due to weakness of the radial extensors of the wrist, as well as inability to extend the metacarpophalangeal joints and and inability to elevate the thumb. They will also have a sensory loss on the skin over the anatomical snuff box.

Low lesions occur due to the fracture or dislocations of the elbow. The wrist and elbow extension are preserved but the patient cannot extend the metacarpophalangeal joint. There is also a weakness in extension and retroposition of the thumb. These patients have a radial deviation of the wrist due to the lack of balancing action of the extensor carpi radialis brevis.

questions.text: What is the characteristic nail examination finding that would be seen in a patient whose peripheral smear shows microcytic hypochromic anemia, poikilocytes,  elliptocytes, and target cells?
questions.solution:
Microcytic hypochromic cells will be seen on the peripheral smear of patients with iron-deficiency anemia (IDA). The characteristic nail finding associated with this condition is koilonychia. 

Iron deficiency is the most common nutritional disorder in the world. IDA results from dietary deficiency, impaired absorption, increased requirement, and chronic blood loss. The cause of IDA in an older man or post-menopausal woman is always gastrointestinal cancer, until proven otherwise.

Clinical presentation may include fatigue, pallor, dyspnea, cheilosis (fissures at the corners of the mouth), and koilonychia (spooning of the fingernails).

Peripheral smear in IDA shows

  • Microcytic hypochromic red blood cells with an enlarged zone of central one-third pallor.
  • Poikilocytes: pencil-shaped RBCs and, target cells.

The image given below shows a microcytic hypochromic blood picture in a peripheral smear:

IDA is treated by giving oral, parenteral and packed cell transfusions depending on the severity of anaemia.

For oral iron replacement therapy,

  • Up to 200mg of elemental iron is given.
  • According to the Anemia Mukt Bharat initiative, adult women need to take 60 mg elemental iron + 500 mcg folic acid tablets once a week.

For parenteral iron therapy, the amount of iron needed by an individual is calculated by the formula:

Body weight(kg) x 2.3 x (15 - patient's hemoglobin, g/dL) + 500 or 1000mg (for stores)

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding maple syrup urine disease?

choices.text: Urine, sweat, and cerumen have a characteristic burnt sugar odor
Strict dietary methionine restriction is advised on diagnosis
It is inherited in an autosomal dominant manner
Untreated individuals have motor delay, but otherwise normal IQ levels.

questions.solution:
Urine, sweat, and cerumen have a characteristic burnt sugar odor/maple syrup-like odor in maple syrup urine disease (MSUD).

Only branched-chain amino acids need to be restricted; hence, methionine does not need any restriction in diet.

Branched-chain amino acids are

  • Leucine (L)
  • Isoleucine (I)
  • Valine (V)

MSUD is an autosomal recessive disorder in which there is a partial or complete deficiency of branched-chain alpha-ketoacid dehydrogenase complex (BCKD). This impairs the metabolism of branched-chain amino acids. These amino acids, particularly leucine and its metabolite accumulate in the blood, causing toxic effects on the brain. Features include feeding problems, vomiting, ketosis, and a characteristic burnt sugar odor/maple syrup-like odor found in urine, sweat, and cerumen.

Infants with untreated classic maple syrup urine disease have significant developmental delay and die within the first few months of life.

Laboratory investigations will show increased levels of branched-chain amino acids in the plasma and urine. Leucine levels are usually higher than isoleucine and valine levels.

Treatment involves restricted intake of branched-chain amino acids using commercially available formulas and judicious supplementation of isoleucine and valine. Very high levels of leucine are removed by hemodialysis.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the first-dose phenomenon seen with alpha-1 blockers usage is false?

choices.text: Occurs within 30-90 minutes of administration first dose
Subsequent dose increases will not cause this effect
Occurs in upto 50% of patients, especially in those with concomitant diuretic intake
Initiating low doses at bedtime helps minimise this phenomenon

questions.solution:
Subsequent dose increases will also be associated with this effect.

Prazosin is a selective alpha-1 antagonist. It acts by blocking the alpha-1 receptors in the arterioles and veins, thereby decreasing peripheral vascular resistance. It has little or no alpha-2-blocking effect.

First-dose phenomenon: 

Within 30–90 minutes of the initial dose of prazosin or when the dosage is increased, there is marked orthostatic hypotension or syncope. This is known as the first-dose phenomenon. After a few initial doses, tolerance develops to this adverse effect. Initiating low doses at bedtime is recommended to minimize this phenomenon. 

Uses of prazosin:

  • Hypertension
  • Congestive cardiac failure
  • Benign prostatic hyperplasia
  • In vasospastic disorders like Raynaud's disease

Other adverse effects are headache, dizziness, and asthenia.

questions.text:
While assisting the chief medical examiner during the autopsy of victims of a mass casualty event, you are asked to collect blood samples for biochemical examination. Arrange the blood collection site that you can use, in descending order of preference.
  1. Heart
  2. Root of aorta
  3. Femoral vessels
  4. Subclavian vessels
  5. Pulmonary artery
  6. Superior vena cava
questions.solution:
The sites for collection of blood samples for biochemical analysis in descending order of preference are:

  1. Femoral vessels
  2. Subclavian vessels
  3. Root of aorta
  4. Pulmonary artery
  5. Superior vena cava
  6. Heart

Blood sample collection for volatile substances should be done using small glass bottles that are aluminum foil lined. These should be filled up to the brim and stored at 4°C. CSF can be collected by lumbar puncture or cisternal puncture. The samples are best collected within 4-6 hours after death, but no later than 12 hours.

 

Related Pearl: Autopsy Techniques

  • Virchow's technique: Organs are removed one by one from the body to be examined. Here the cranial cavity is opened first, then the spinal cord, followed by thoracic, cervical, and abdominal organs in that order.
  • Ghon's technique: Here the organs are removed 'en bloc'. The thoracic, cervical, pelvic, and abdominal organs are removed as organ blocks.
  • Rokitansky's technique: This is characterized by 'in situ' dissection in part combined with en bloc removal like Ghon's technique. The dissection begins at the neck and slowly works its way down the body and the organ is removed as a bloc. A cut is first made at the larynx to separate the esophagus from the pharynx. The larynx and trachea are pulled downward and using a scalpel, the chest organs are cut. The diaphragm is cut to expose the abdominal organs. Other organs like the bladder and rectum are separated from the body by using a scalpel to cut the pelvic ligaments.
  • Letulle's technique: Thoracic, cervical, abdominal, and pelvic organs are removed 'en masse' meaning as one big organ block. It allows the body to be made available for examination in less than 30 minutes as the process of removing the organs is much quicker.

Related Pearl: Autopsy: Types Of Incision

Type of incision Procedure Indication Advantage
I-Shaped Incision Extends from symphysis menti to symphysis pubis, taking a curve towards the left around the umbilicus. It is used routinely in practice It is simple and convenient.
Y-Shaped Incision Commences at the acromial process on the shoulder on either side of the chest, runs downwards and anteriorly beneath the breasts as to meet at the xiphisternum and then run downwards as in the "I"-shaped incision   Preferred in females It prevents cutting of the chest skin in the midline.
Modified Y-Shaped Incision Commences at the angle of mandible on either side, brought forwards, downwards to meet at the suprasternal notch . It is then run downwards as a midline incision up to the pubic symphysis. Preferred when a detailed study of neck structures required, e.g. asphyxial death due to neck compression.  It has better exposure and allows the study of neck structures. 
Elongated X-shaped Incision Used to dissect out subcutaneous structures in the back to identify and evaluate the extent of blunt injuries.  Should be practiced in cases of custodial death.  Helpful in the reconstruction of events prior to death.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presents with a pelvic fracture following blunt abdominal trauma. No blood is seen at the meatus. Catheterization does not produce significant urine output. The radiological image is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of blunt abdominal trauma, minimal urine output on catheterization, and the pattern of contrast extravasation in the given image indicates extraperitoneal bladder rupture. 

Extraperitoneal bladder rupture leads to extravasation of the contrast material into the perivesical space and the fascial planes anterior to the peritoneum. The image shows extraperitoneal bladder rupture, with contrast material in the perivesical and the retro-pubic space (no contrast can be seen within the peritoneal cavity).

Bladder rupture may be extraperitoneal or intraperitoneal. The type of bladder rupture depends on the location of the injury and its relationship with the peritoneal reflection. 

As seen in the image below, the bladder is related to the peritoneum only on its superior surface. Therefore, if the bladder rupture is towards the superior surface, the urine leaks into the peritoneal cavity, i.e. urine extravasation will be intraperitoneal. Whereas, bladder rupture due to injury to the anterior or lateral surfaces does not rupture the peritoneum. In such cases, the urine leaks into the perivesical space but does not enter the peritoneum, i.e. urine extravasation will be extraperitoneal.

Intraperitoneal bladder rupture is caused by a blow or fall on the distended bladder. Intraperitoneal bladder rupture manifests as sudden severe pain in the hypogastrium and syncope. There will be an associated increase in BUN and creatinine levels due to systemic absorption of the extravasated urine, and it may also lead to chemical peritonitis.

Investigations:

CT scan can be done to diagnose bladder rupture. A plain erect X-ray may show a ground-glass appearance. Intravenous urography (IVU) may confirm a leak. Retrograde cystography will confirm the diagnosis. 

Intraperitoneal bladder rupture leads to extravasation of the contrast material into the peritoneal cavity, around the bowel loops and paracolic gutters. Hence, the outline of bowel loops can be seen.

The image below shows intraperitoneal bladder rupture, with arrows showing contrast material in the peritoneal cavity:

Treatment : 

  • Extravesical injury– catheter drainage for 10 days
  • Intraperitoneal injury– laparotomy, repair, and bladder drainage (suprapubic and urethral catheter). Laparoscopic approaches are also now being used.

questions.text:
Sequentially arrange the following fractures in ascending order of their severity as per the Gustilo-Anderson classification for open fractures.
  1. A 16 cm open wound with comminuted fractures but intact soft tissue coverage
  2. A 14 cm open wound with comminuted fractures that require concomitant soft tissue reconstructive surgery
  3. A 11 cm open wound with comminuted fracture and arterial injury requiring vascular repair
  4. A 6 cm open wound with a moderately comminuted fracture and some muscle damage.
questions.solution:
As per Gustilo and Anderson's classification, the respective grades are

A 16 cm open wound with comminuted fractures but intact soft tissue coverage - IIIA
A 14 cm open wound with comminuted fractures that require concomitant soft tissue reconstructive surgery - IIIB
A 11 cm open wound with comminuted fracture and arterial injury requiring vascular repair - IIIC
A 6 cm open wound with a moderately comminuted fracture and some muscle damage - II

Gustilo and Anderson's classification is the most commonly followed classification for open fractures. An open fracture, with an arterial injury, that requires repair regardless of the size of the soft tissue wound, belongs to classification IIIC.

Related Pearl: Gustilo and Anderson classification for open fracture

Gustilo-Anderson's classification for open injuries

II >1 cm Moderate Moderate; some muscle damage Moderate comminution
IIIA usually >10 cm High Severe with crushing Usually comminuted; soft tissue coverage of bone possible
IIIB usually >10 cm High Very severe loss of cover Bone cover poor; usually requires soft tissue reconstructive surgery
IIIC usually >10 cm High Very severe loss of cover; vascular injury requiring repair Bone cover poor; usually requires soft tissue reconstructive surgery


Management according to Gustilo-Anderson's classification:

Types Methods of fixation
Grade  I                                A technique that is suitable for closed fracture management i.e, debridement and internal fixation by intramedullary nail and plate  
Grade II, IIIA

Within 6hr same as grade I and after 6hr same as IIIB, IIIC
Grade IIIB, IIIC

Debridement and external fixation

questions.text: What is the drug of choice for prophylaxis of chronic cluster headaches?
questions.solution:
The drugs used in the prophylaxis of chronic cluster headaches are:

  • Verapamil - drug of choice
  • Prednisone
  • Lithium
  • Topiramate
  • Gabapentin
  • Melatonin
  • Greater occipital nerve injection with lidocaine and glucocorticoids

Cluster headache is a periodic headache characterized by daily attacks of short-duration unilateral headache lasting 8-10 weeks a year. It presents as severe, unilateral retro-orbital pain with autonomic features, such as unilateral lacrimation, nasal congestion, and conjunctival injection. The pain, though severe, is characteristically brief (15-180 minutes). Patients are usually perfectly well in between episodes.

The most suitable treatment is pharmacologic prevention of future bouts of headaches. An acute episode can be treated with 

  • Sumatriptan 6 mg subcutaneous injection
  • 100% O2 at 10 -12 L/min for 15 - 20 mins
  • Sumatriptan (20 mg) and zolmitriptan (5 mg) nasal spray.
  • Noninvasive vagus nerve stimulation (nVNS) is also approved by the FDA for the treatment of acute episodes of cluster headaches.

Other options:

Oral sumatriptan is not effective for the treatment or prevention of acute cluster headaches. The nasal spray form of sumatriptan is used in the management of acute attacks. Gabapentin is not the drug of choice, though it has a role in prophylaxis of cluster headaches. 

 

Related Pearl: Trigeminal Autonomic Cephalalgia

Types of trigeminal autonomic cephalalgia:

  • Cluster headache
  • Paroxysmal hemicranias
  • Short-lasting unilateral neuralgiform headache with conjunctival injection and tearing (SUNCT)
  • Short-lasting unilateral neuralgiform headache attacks with cranial autonomic features (SUNA)
  • Hemicrania continua
   Cluster headache Paroxysmal hemicrania   SUNCT/SUNA
Gender  Males>females Female=Males Female=Males
Character of pain  Stabbing /boring Throbbing pain /stabbing /boring Burning /stabbing/sharp
Severity of pain  Excruciating  Excruciating Severe to excruciating
Site of pain  Orbit, temple Orbit, temple Periorbital
Attack frequency  1-8 /day 1-20/day 3-200/day
Duration 15min-3 hours 2-30 min 5-240seconds
Migraneous feature  Yes  Yes  Yes
Alcohol trigger  Yes No No
Cutaneous trigger No No Yes
Response to indomethacin No Yes No
Abortive treatment

100% oxygen

Sumatriptan injection

No effective treatment

IV lidocaine 
Prophylaxis

Chronic cluster

  • Lithium
  • Verapamil
  • Methysergide

Episodic cluster 

  • Steroids 
  • Verapamil
  • Methysergide
  • Indomethacin
  • Lamotrigine
  • Topiramate
  • Gabapentin
  • Indomethacin is effective in paroxysmal hemicrania,hemicrania continuum, and primary sexual/ exercise headache
  • Cutaneous trigger is also seen in trigeminal neuralgia, however, trigeminal neuralgia is a separate entity and not a part of trigeminal autonomic cephalalgia

questions.text: In which of the following conditions do you see a 'headlight-in-fog' appearance, as seen below?
questions.solution:
The "headlight-in-fog' appearance is seen in toxoplasmosis. 

Toxoplasmosis is a parasitic infestation due to Toxoplasma gondii. It primarily affects the central nervous system and retina. In humans, it occurs as congenital, acquired, or recurrent.

Toxoplasmosis has a variable presentation. Congenital toxoplasmosis is acquired by the transplacental route. Infants are usually born with inactive disease. Iridocyclitis can be granulomatous or non-granulomatous. There is focal superficial necrotizing retinochoroiditis along with vitritis, which gives the 'headlight-in-fog' appearance as in the image in question. Fundoscopy shows deep retinitis and papillitis with granulomas. 

Old choroid lesions of toxoplasmosis are punched-out lesions with pigmented borders as in the image below. Bilateral healed punched-out chorioretinal lesions in the macular area are usually seen. In acquired toxoplasmosis, punched-out lesions similar to congenital toxoplasmosis are seen. In addition, punctate outer retinal toxoplasmosis (PORT) may also be seen. 

 

Other options:

Option A - Posterior staphyloma is used to describe a bulge in the sclera with the choroid behind the equator. On ophthalmoscopy, there is an excavated area with retinal vessels dipping in it. 

Option B - Fundal coloboma occurs due to a defect in the closure of the embryonic cleft. It appears as a comet-shaped defect with the apex towards the disc which may or may not be involved. A few choroidal or retinal vessels may also be seen on the surface. 

Option C - Congenital rubella typically produces a salt and pepper appearance of the fundus.

questions.text: Which of the following factors causes an increase in the minimum alveolar concentration of an inhaled anesthetic agent?
questions.solution:
Minimum alveolar concentration (MAC) increases in hypernatremia (total serum sodium level: >145 mmol/L)

MAC is defined as the inhaled anesthetic atmospheric pressure required to prevent movement in response to a defined noxious stimulus in 50% of subjects. MAC is unique to each inhaled anesthetic. It is used to express the potency of anesthetic agents. Thus, the lower the MAC, the higher the potency. 

 

Hyperthyroidism and hypothyroidism have no effect on MAC.

Related Pearl: Factors affecting Minimum Alveolar Concentration (MAC)

Factors increasing MAC Factors decreasing MAC No change in MAC
Hyperthermia >42°C Acute alcohol intoxication  Hyperthyroidism
Chronic alcohol abuse Hypothermia and hyperthermia up to 42°C Hypothyroidism
Acute amphetamine use  Older age (>6 months MAC decreases 6% per decade)  
Drugs: Cocaine, Ephedrine Chronic amphetamine abuse  
Hypernatremia  Drugs: Opioids, Ketamine, Barbiturates, Benzodiazepines, Sympatholytics   
Young age (<6 months; MAC is maximum at 6 months) Hyponatremia, Hypercalcemia  
  Hypotension  
  Hypercarbia, Hypoxia, Metabolic acidosis  
  Pregnancy   

 

Related Pearl: Minimum alveolar concentration (MAC)

Minimum alveolar concentration (MAC) is the minimum concentration of an inhaled anesthetic at 1 atm of pressure that prevents skeletal muscle movement in response to a surgical incision in 50% of patients. 

MAC of inhaled anesthetics

Anesthetic Agents

MAC (Potency)

Blood-gas coefficient (Solubility)
Halothane 0.75  2.4
Isoflurane 1.2 1.4 
Enflurane 1.7 1.9 
Sevoflurane 2 0.65 
Desflurane 6 0.42 
Nitrous oxide 104 0.47 

MAC is an indicator of potency. The lower the MAC, the higher is the potency.

questions.text: Difficulty in eversion of the upper lid seen in Graves ophthalmopathy is known as _________
questions.solution:
Difficulty in eversion of the upper lid seen in Graves ophthalmopathy is known as Gifford's sign.

Graves ophthalmopathy: Most frequently affected extra ocular muscle in Grave's ophthalmopathy is Inferior Rectus.

Classification: Acronym ‘NOSPECS’:

  • Class 0 : No signs and symptoms
  • Class 1 : Only signs, no symptoms. Signs are limited to lid retraction with or without lid lag and mild proptosis
  • Class 2 : Soft tissue involvement with signs of class 1 and symptoms including lacrimation, photophobia, lid or conjunctival swelling
  • Class 3 : Proptosis is well established
  • Class 4 : Extraocular muscle involvement (limitation of movements and diplopia)
  • Class 5 : Corneal involvement (exposure keratitis)
  • Class 6 : Sight loss due to optic nerve involvement with disc pallor or papilloedema

EARLY Graves : class 1 and 2

Late Graves : class 3 to 6

Related Pearl: Signs in Grave’s ophthalmopathy

Sign Feature
Dalrymple's sign Retraction of the upper lids
von Graefe's sign Lid lag, i.e., when the globe is moved downward, the upper lid lags behind
Griffith Sign Lower lid lag on upward gaze
Enroth's sign Fullness of the eyelids
Stellwag's sign Infrequent blinking
Gifford's sign Difficulty in eversion of the upper lid
Mobius’ sign Convergence weakness
Joffroy’s sign Lack of wrinkling of the forehead on superior gaze
Jellinek's Sign Abnormal pigmentation of the upper lid

The image given below shows Dalrymple's sign in the right eye.

questions.text: Which of the following pairs of sphingolipidoses and deficient enzymes is incorrect?

choices.text: Sandhoff disease - Hexosaminidase A and B

questions.solution:
Fabry disease is due to the deficiency of α-galactosidase. β-Galactosidase deficiency results in Krabbe disease.

Fabry disease is an X-linked, multisystem, lysosomal storage disorder caused by the deficiency of α-galactosidase. This leads to the accumulation of globotriaosylceramide. It is seen in both men and women (less severe). It usually manifests in childhood or adolescence, with symptoms of severe agonizing pain in the palms of hands, soles of feet, and proximal extremities called acroparesthesia.

Angiokeratomas, as seen in the image below are present, which are lesions that are dark-red to blue-black, flat or slightly raised, punctate, and usually seen between the umbilicus and the knees (called the 'bathing suit area') and the trunk.

Late presentations include renal failure, and cardiovascular or cerebrovascular disease, which are the leading causes of death in these patients. Urinalysis shows proteinuria and Maltese cross structures. An enzyme assay, genetic testing, or a skin or kidney biopsy showing glycolipid deposits helps establish the diagnosis. Treatment is with enzyme replacement therapy (recombinant alpha-Gal A or migalastat).

Krabbe disease or globoid cell leukodystrophy is a neurodegenerative disorder with severe myelin loss and the presence of globoid bodies in white matter. It is an autosomal recessive leukodystrophy due to the deficiency of galactocerebroside β-galactosidase. β-galactosidase helps in the catabolism of galactocerebroside to ceramide and galactose.

As a result, an alternative catabolic pathway shunts galactocerebroside to galactosylsphingosine. Elevated levels of these compounds are cytotoxic and cause the destruction of oligodendroglia. The onset of symptoms is between 3 and 6 months of age, dominated by motor signs such as stiffness and weakness. They often do not survive beyond the age of 2 years. The brain shows loss of myelin and oligodendrocytes with a similar process affecting the peripheral nerves.

The aggregation of engorged macrophages called globoid cells in the brain parenchyma and around blood vessels is the characteristic and diagnostic feature of Krabbe disease.

questions.solution:

questions.text: A patient with a history of multiple abdominal surgeries is taken up for a laparoscopic procedure. Your senior resident asks you to insert the port at the palmer's point. Where would you insert the Veress needle?

choices.text: 3 cm below the left costal margin at the mid-clavicular line
7 cm below the left costal margin at the mid-clavicular line
3 cm below the left costal margin at the mid-axillary line
7 cm below the right costal margin at the mid-clavicular line

questions.solution:
Palmer's point is 3 cm below the left costal margin at the mid-clavicular line.

Most common site of insertion of port for creation of pneumoperitoneum is infraumbilical. But in patients with multiple adhesions, this is not preferred due to suspected adhesions.

In routine laparoscopy, there are two methods for establishing abdominal access during laparoscopic surgeries. One is the direct puncture technique and the other is the direct peritoneal access technique. Veress needle is used in direct puncture laparoscopy.

Direct puncture laparoscopy, the abdominal wall is grasped with towel clips or fingers to elevate the abdominal wall away from the underlying structures. Then a small incision is made in the umbilicus and insufflation is done with a veress needle. While introducing the veress needle, two distinct pops can be felt as the needle pierces the abdominal wall fascia and the peritoneum.

The umbilicus is the preferred location for introducing a veress needle because the abdominal wall is thin at this location. Laparoscopic surgeries can be done under general anesthesia or local anesthesia however, general anesthesia is preferred. Carbon dioxide(CO2) gas is usually used and the maximum pressure is in the range of 14-15 mm Hg. But N2O is used if the procedure is done under local anesthesia. Insufflation with N2O is stopped at a pressure of 10 mmHg or when 2L of gas is insufflated.

The direct peritoneal access technique (Hasson technique) is done only occasionally. It is preferred for patients who have undergone previous abdominal surgeries as the small bowel may be adherent to the undersurface of the abdominal wound in such cases.

questions.text: What is the intermediate host for the organism shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
The given image shows Ascaris lumbricoides (roundworm). It has no intermediate host.

It is the most common of human helminths and is distributed worldwide. Adult worms live in the small intestine (85% in the jejunum and 15% in the ileum). It is the largest nematode parasite in the human intestine.

The adult worms are large cylindrical worms, with tapering ends, the anterior end being more pointed than the posterior end. Man is the natural host. There is no intermediate host.

Infection occurs through food or water contaminated with nightsoil or human feces containing eggs of Ascaris. The eggs contain the infective rhabditiform larva.

questions.text: Which of the following is a serotonin partial agonist–reuptake inhibitor (SPARI)?
questions.solution:
Vilazodone is a novel antidepressant that is considered a serotonin partial agonist–reuptake inhibitor (SPARI).

The antidepressant effect of vilazodone is due to its enhancement of serotonergic activity in the CNS through selective inhibition of serotonin reuptake. It binds with high affinity to the serotonin reuptake site but not to the norepinephrine or dopamine reuptake site. As a result, vilazodone potently and selectively inhibits the reuptake of serotonin.

Vilazodone is also a partial agonist at serotonergic 5-HT1A receptors. The result of this activity on serotonergic transmission also plays a role in its antidepressant effect.

Thus it offers a novel combination of selective serotonin reuptake inhibition (SSRI) and serotonergic (5-HT1A) receptor partial agonist activity. Because of these characteristics, vilazodone has been termed a serotonin partial agonist–reuptake inhibitor (SPARI).

Vilazodone is never combined with a monoamine oxidase (MAO) inhibitor or given within 14 days of discontinuing or initiating MAO inhibitor therapy due to the serious risk of serotonin toxicity.

Other options:

Option A: Lurasidone is a second-generation antipsychotic that is a 5-HT2A and D2 receptor antagonist. it is used in the treatment of schizophrenia and bipolar depression (as monotherapy or as an adjunct).

Option C: Asenapine is a second-generation antipsychotic which is also a 5-HT2A and D2 receptor antagonist, used in the management of schizophrenia and acute mania.

Option D: Blonanserin is a second-generation antipsychotic, which acts as an antagonist at D2, D3, and 5-HT2A receptors. Blonanserin has a low affinity for 5-HT2C, adrenergic α1, histamine H1, and muscarinic M1 receptors, but displays a relatively high affinity for 5-HT6 receptors. It is used in the management of schizophrenia.

questions.text: Clinical examination of a patient with suspected anterior dislocation of the shoulder reveals that the vertical circumference of the axilla on the side of suspected dislocation is greater than that on the contralateral side. Which of the following tests gives this result?
questions.solution:
In a patient with anterior dislocation of the shoulder, the vertical circumference of the axilla on the side of dislocation is greater than that on the contralateral side. This is the Callaway test.  

Four tests can be used to diagnose anterior dislocation of the shoulder:

  • Bryant's test
  • Dugas test
  • Hamilton ruler test 
  • Callaway test   

Related Pearl: Tests for anterior shoulder dislocation

Bryant’s test: Anterior axillary fold is at a lower level on the dislocated side.

 

Dugas test: The patient is made to place the hand on the opposite shoulder. The examiner then applies gentle pressure on the flexed elbow to make it touch the chest. In shoulder dislocation, the elbow cannot be made to touch the chest. 

 

Hamilton ruler test: In a normal shoulder, a ruler (scale) placed on the lateral side of the arm will not touch the lateral condyle of the humerus and the acromion at the same time.

In anterior shoulder dislocation, the ruler will simultaneously touch the lateral condyle of the humerus and the acromion. 

 

 

Callway Test: The vertical circumference of the axilla is increased on the dislocated side as compared to the normal side.

questions.text: During the analysis of a crime scene in a bathroom, you notice a fingerprint impression made on a soap bar. What would this type of fingerprint be called?
questions.solution:
A fingerprint impression made on a soft surface such as soap would be called plastic print.

Types of fingerprints:

  • Latent print/Chance print are invisible or barely visible fingerprint impressions that are left on a smooth surface.
  • Visible prints are clearly seen fingerprints that are formed by fingers stained with blood or ink or other similar media.
  • Plastic print is a fingerprint impression made on a soft surface. Examples of such soft surfaces include:
    • Soap
    • Cheese
    • Mud
    • Candles
    • Thick dried blood
    • Adhesives

 

Dactylography/Fingerprint system/Dermatoglyphics/Galton system is the most reliable method in establishing the identity of an individual. It was first used in India by William Herschel and systematized by Sir Francis Galton.

Fingerprints can be obtained up to a depth of 0.6 mm from the surface of the skin. The pattern is not inherited and hence, paternity cannot be proved with the help of fingerprints, and are not even similar in identical twins (Quetelet’s law of biological variation).

Permanent impairment of fingerprints is seen in leprosy, electric injury, and irradiation, while atrophy of the ridges is seen in celiac disease and dermatitis.

Patterns of fingerprints:

  • Loops (60–70%)
    • Radial
    • Ulnar
  • Whorls 
    • Concentric
    • Spiral
    • Double spiral
    • Almond shaped
  • Arches 
    • Plain
    • Tented
  • Composite
    • Central pocket loop
    • Lateral pocket loop
    • Twinned loop
    • Accidentals

The image given below shows the different patterns of fingerprints. 

 

Classification of fingerprints into different patterns is based on delta and core formation. Delta is a triangular arrangement formed where three separate ridge line flows come together. Core is the centermost portion of a ridge flow pattern. 

 

Edgeoscopy is a method of identification through the examination of the unique details and characteristics found along the edges of individual fingerprint ridges. 

Methods of identification using different prints:

  • Dactylography - evaluation of fingerprints
  • Poroscopy - evaluation of sweat pore openings on fingerprint ridges
  • Cheiloscopy - evaluation of lip prints
  • Podography - evaluation of foot prints
  • Rugoscopy - evaluation of palatal rugae
  • Ridgeology - evaluation of friction ridges on fingerprints

Dactylography or dermatoglyphics is the study of fingerprint patterns. The first fingerprint bureau in India was established in Kolkata.

questions.text: How would you manage a case of pedunculated umbilical adenoma presenting for the first time?

choices.text: Tie a firm ligature around the base of the peduncle

questions.solution:
Tying a firm ligature around the base of the peduncle is the best management for a case of pedunculated umbilical adenoma presenting for the first time.

Umbilical adenoma is also known as a raspberry tumor. It is due to a partially unobliterated vitellointestinal duct. It is mostly seen in infants. The prolapsing mucosa gives a raspberry appearance, and it bleeds on touch.

A ligature is tied around its base, and it falls off after a few days. Recurrent cases can be treated by umbillectomy.

questions.text:
Which of the following measures are recommended for the delivery room thermoregulation management of very preterm neonates?
  1. Maintain delivery room temperature of at least 26°C 
  2. Prewarm the radiant warmer to 50% heater output for at least 5 minutes prior to delivery
  3. Use polythene bags/ wraps for all neonates 
  4. Do not dry the neonate
  5. Do not remove plastic bag wrap until the neonate is transferred to the NICU and normal temperature is recorded
  6. Do not cover the head of the baby
questions.solution:
Very preterm refers to babies delivered between 28 to 32 weeks of gestation.

The measures that are recommended for the delivery room thermoregulation management of very preterm neonates are as follows:

  1. Maintain delivery room temperature of at least 26°C for all deliveries.
  2. Prewarm the radiant warmer to 100% heater output for at least 10 minutes prior to delivery.
  3. Use polythene bags/ wraps for all neonates.
  4. Do not dry the neonate.
  5. Do not remove the bag until the neonate is transferred to the NICU and normal temperature is recorded.
  6. Cover the head of the neonate with a plastic bag/ hat.
  7. Use a transport incubator to transfer neonates from DR to NICU. Prewarm the baby boundaries and the transport incubator prior to use.

The axillary temperature of the neonate should be recorded within 10 minutes of NICU admission of the baby.

questions.text: A child with nephrotic syndrome is started on steroid therapy. She would be classified as steroid-resistant if

choices.text: There is no remission despite 2 weeks of weekly-once steroid therapy
There is no remission despite 4 weeks of daily steroid therapy
There is no remission despite 4 weeks of weekly-once steroid therapy
There is no remission despite 2 weeks of daily steroid therapy

questions.solution:
No remission despite 4 weeks of daily steroid therapy is considered as steroid resistance.

Important definitions regarding steroid therapy in nephrotic syndrome:

  • Response: Attainment of remission within the initial 4 weeks of corticosteroid therapy.
  • Remission: It consists of a urine protein:creatinine ratio of < 0.2 or < 1+ protein on urine dipstick testing for 3 consecutive days. 
  • Relapse: It is an increase in the first-morning urine protein:creatinine ratio > 0.2 or reading of 2+ and higher for 3 consecutive days on urine protein testing.
    • Frequently relapsing: It is two or more relapses within 6 months after the initial therapy or four relapses in a 12-month period.
  • Steroid dependence: It is a relapse during steroid tapering or relapse within 2 weeks of the discontinuation of therapy.
  • Steroid resistance: It is the inability to induce remission within 4 weeks of daily steroid therapy.

Related Pearl: Glomerular Pathology in Renal Diseases

Note:

  • Anionic antigens form subendothelial deposits.
  • Cationic antigens form subepithelial deposits.
  • Neutral antigens form mesangial deposits.

questions.text: Which of the following findings would you not see in a patient with central cord syndrome?

choices.text: Marked upper extremity weakness compared to the lower extremities
Loss of vibration sense over the shoulders, lower neck, and upper trunk
Loss of pain and temperature sensations over the shoulders, lower neck, and upper trunk
Preservation of light touch, and joint position sense over the shoulders, lower neck, and upper trunk

questions.solution:
In central cord syndrome, there is preservation of light touch, joint position sense, as well as vibration sense over the shoulders, lower neck, and upper trunk (cape distribution).

This condition affects the cervical cord producing arm weakness > leg weakness. A dissociated sensory loss, i.e. loss of pain and temperature with preservation of light touch, joint position, and vibration sensations, is seen over the shoulders, lower neck, and upper trunk (cape distribution).

It results from selective damage to the gray matter nerve cells and the decussating spinothalamic tracts surrounding the central canal. These decussating fibers carry crude touch, pain, and temperature sensations.

Spinal trauma, syringomyelia, and intrinsic cord tumors are the main causes.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is not useful for the treatment of a  patient with graft rejection?
questions.solution:
Cyclosporine is not useful in the treatment of a patient with graft rejection. It can only be used for prophylaxis against graft rejection. Once graft rejection has set in, management would require agents that can act on activated lymphocytes.

Calcineurin is a calcium/calmodulin-dependent phosphatase required for the induction of T cell lymphokine production and proliferation. Cyclosporine is an immunomodulatory drug that inhibits calcineurin activity by forming a complex with cyclophilin, a cytoplasmic-receptor protein present in target cells, to form a cyclosporine-cyclophilin complex.

This drug-receptor complex specifically and competitively binds to and inhibits calcineurin, a calcium and calmodulin-dependent phosphatase. This, in turn, inhibits the translocation of a family of transcription factors (NF-AT), leading to reduced transcriptional activation of cytokine genes for interleukin (IL)-2, tumor necrosis factor (TNF)-alpha, IL-3, IL-4, CD40L, granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor, and interferon-gamma. Ultimately, the proliferation of T lymphocytes is reduced, resulting in immunomodulation.

Its uses are as follows:

  • In solid organ transplantation, to prevent organ rejection in kidney, liver, and heart allogeneic transplants
  • In patients with rheumatoid arthritis, when the disease has not adequately responded to methotrexate
  • It is approved to treat amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS or Lou Gehrig disease) and its variants.
  • In nephrotic syndrome, to treat focal segmental glomerulosclerosis not responding to corticosteroids

Adverse effects of cyclosporine include a decrease in glomerular filtration rate (GFR) and metabolic disturbances like hypomagnesemia, hyperkalemia, dyslipidemia, gynecomastia, hypertrichosis; neurotoxicity in the form of convulsions. There is an increased risk of developing skin and lymphoproliferative malignancies in cyclosporine-treated psoriasis patients.

 

 

Alemtuzumab is a monoclonal antibody directed against the CD52 antigen. Muromonab is a monoclonal antibody that acts on T cell–receptor complex, blocking antigen recognition.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman presented with yellowish discoloration of the toenails. The discoloration spread proximally as a streak in the nail, and later, the entire nail separated from the nailbed, prompting a diagnosis of onychomycosis. What is the site of action of the drug of choice for her?
questions.solution:
The drug of choice for onychomycosis is oral terbinafine, which acts by inhibiting ergosterol synthesis. 

Terbinafine acts as a non-competitive inhibitor of squalene epoxidase, an early step enzyme in the synthesis of fungal ergosterol. This results in the accumulation of sterol squalene, which is toxic to the organism.

The efficacy of terbinafine in onychomycosis is improved when combined with amorolfine 5% nail lacquer.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of Antifungal drugs

questions.text: Your newlywed friend asks you for advice regarding what dose of folic acid supplements she should take, as she is planning her first pregnancy. As per the Anemia Mukt Bharat Program, what should you recommend?
questions.solution:
As per the Anemia Mukt Bharat Program, during the period of pre-conception up to the first trimester, women are advised to have 400 mcg of folic acid tablets daily to reduce the incidence of neural tube defects in the fetus.

Note that, non-pregnant, non-lactating Women of reproductive age (20–49 years) who are not actively planning a pregnancy in near term should receive 1 iron and folic acid tablet containing 60 mg elemental iron + 500 mcg folic acid. 

Related Pearl: Prophylactic Iron and Folic Acid (IFA) Supplementation

According to the Anemia Mukt Bharat 2018 scheme, giving IFA to children, adolescents, women of reproductive age, and pregnant women, irrespective of their anemia status, is a key intervention.

Note 1: Prophylaxis with iron should be withheld in case of acute illness (fever, diarrhea, pneumonia, etc.) and in a known case of thalassemia major/ history of repeated blood transfusion. In cases of children with severe acute malnutrition (SAM), IFA supplementation should be continued as per the SAM management protocol.

Note 2: All women in the reproductive age group in the pre-conception period and up to the first trimester of the pregnancy are advised to have 400 mcg of folic acid tablets, daily, to reduce the incidence of neural tube defects in the fetus.

questions.text: A 35-year-old farmer presented with a 6-month history of soft tissue swelling on the right jaw. On examination, a discharging sinus was found as seen below. On microscopic examination of the pus, sulfur granules appearance was seen. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A farmer with a lumpy jaw & discharging sinuses, with the pus having a sulfur granule appearance is characteristic of cervicofacial actinomycosis.

Actinomycosis typically presents as a painless nodule that indurates, with purulent discharge that contains sulfur granules. Sulfur granules are composed of a matrix of bacteria, calcium phosphate, and host tissue. It is an indolent, slowly progressive, suppurative, and granulomatous infection that produces pyogenic lesions, with interconnecting sinus tracts that contain sulfur granules.

It is caused by anaerobic or microaerophilic bacteria, primarily of the genus Actinomyces. It presents as one of the following clinical types:

  • Cervicofacial actinomycosis- (most common site) fluctuant mass in the jaw area producing draining fistulas. (lumpy jaw)
  • Thoracic actinomycosis- pulmonary infection with fever, cough, and purulent sputum. 
  • Abdominal actinomycosis- following ruptured appendix or ulcer. It may involve multiple organs.
  • Pelvic actinomycosis- due to the colonization of intrauterine contraceptive device.
  • Actinomycosis can spread to bones and surrounding tissue, and produce multiple discharging sinuses.

Diagnosis:

  • Gram staining of sulfur granules shows a dense network of thin gram-positive filaments, surrounded by club-shaped structures (Sunray appearance).
  • Culture shows a molar tooth appearance of the colonies.

The image below shows the molar tooth appearance of Actinomyces colonies.

 

Image below shows gram-positive filaments of Actinomyces. 

 

The given image shows a patient with multiple cutaneous lesions caused by actinomycosis:

Treatment:

  • Penicillin G is the drug of choice.
  • Duration of therapy: 6-12 months.
  • Other drugs that can be used: Amoxicillin, Erythromycin, Tetracycline, Doxycycline, Clindamycin, Minocycline.

Other options:

Option B: Chromoblastomycosis is commonly seen in tropical areas among agricultural workers and woodcutters who walk barefooted. Traumatic implantation is the mode of infection. Patients present with warty cauliflower-like cutaneous nodules on the feet and lower legs. Species of the fungal genera Fonsecaea are implicated as the causative agents. Diagnosis is by demonstration of sclerotic bodies (copper-penny bodies) in tissue sections. Sclerotic bodies appear as round or irregular, dark brown bodies with septae.

Option C: Bacillus anthracis infection manifests as cutaneous anthrax. The typical lesion has a characteristic central black eschar with marked edema. Microscopy shows Gram-positive rods and culture on blood agar produce non-hemolytic gray to white, tenacious colonies with a ground-glass appearance. Comma-shaped outgrowths may project from the colony.

Option D: Sporotrichosis caused by the dimorphic fungus Sporothrix schenckii, is commonly seen in gardeners following minor trauma. Patients present with skin nodules or lymph node ulceration. Microscopy shows asteroid bodies. It can be seen as an oval, basophilic structure with eosinophilic radiation.

questions.text: A patient who is being worked up for suspected laryngeal carcinoma is asked to undergo a direct laryngoscopy to visualize the hidden areas of the larynx. All of the following are considered hidden areas of the larynx, except
questions.solution:
Hidden areas of the larynx are infrahyoid epiglottis, anterior commissure, subglottis, and ventricle.

Direct Laryngoscopy is done during the workup of patients with laryngeal ca to see the hidden areas of the larynx and to determine the extent of disease. Hidden areas may not be clearly seen by laryngeal mirror examination making direct laryngoscopy essential.

Indirect laryngoscopy is done using a laryngeal mirror, which appears as below:

Structures that are seen during indirect laryngoscopy (in order):

  • The base of the tongue (posterior one-third of the tongue)
  • Vallecula
  • Median and lateral glossoepiglottic folds
  • Epiglottis
  • Pharyngoepiglottic folds
  • Aryepiglottic folds
  • Arytenoids
  • False vocal cords
  • True vocal cords

A posterior rhinoscopy mirror has two bends in the shaft and is bayonet shaped and appears as below.

The structures seen in posterior rhinoscopy are:

  • Adenoids
  • Posterior ends of nasal turbinates
  • Opening of the eustachian tube
  • The posterior border of the nasal septum
  • Fossa of Rosenmuller
  • Torus tubarius
  • The upper surface of the soft palate

questions.text: A pregnant woman has delivered a baby in the middle of a flood zone with limited medical help. According to WHO, what dose of misoprostol is recommended for use in such a setting for the prevention of postpartum hemorrhage?
questions.solution:
400 mcg/ 600 mcg of misoprostol administered per oral is recommended for the prevention of PPH in such a setting. The administration of oral misoprostol can be done by community health workers or even lay health workers.

To effectively prevent PPH, the WHO recommends the use of only one of the following uterotonic agents:

  • Oxytocin - (10 IU - IM/IV)
  • Carbetocin - (100 μg - IM/IV)
  • Misoprostol - (400 μg or 600 μg, per-oral)
  • Ergometrine/methylergometrine - (200 μg - IM/IV)
  • Oxytocin and ergometrine fixed-dose combination - (5 IU,500μg - IM)

Of these, oxytocin is used as the first-line agent in preventing postpartum hemorrhage. When oxytocin is not available, the other drugs mentioned above can be used based on the clinical condition and availability of the drug.

questions.text: A 19-year-old girl is wheeled into the emergency following blunt trauma to the abdomen while traveling on her 2-wheeler.  CECT reveals the presence of splenic vascular injury with active bleeding extending well into the peritoneum. As per the AAST Spleen Injury Scale, you would grade this injury as?
questions.solution:
Any injury in the presence of splenic vascular injury with active bleeding extending beyond the spleen into the peritoneum is considered grade V as per the AAST Spleen Injury Scale.

This or a shattered spleen are both considered Grade V injuries and require splenectomy.

Management of Splenic trauma:

Grade I and II injuries:

  • They are usually hemodynamically stable and are managed non-operatively.
  • Initially, these patients are managed conservatively with regular monitoring of vitals and serial CECT.
  • If the grade of injury is found to increase, then angiography and embolization of the bleeding vessel are done to achieve hemostasis.
  • If angiography and embolization fail to achieve hemostasis, or if the patient becomes hemodynamically unstable or if there is a contrast blush, then a splenorrhaphy is done.

Grade III injuries that are hemodynamically stable are managed like that of Grades I and II, while those that are hemodynamically unstable are managed like that of Grades IV and V.

Grade IV and V injuries: These patients are usually hemodynamically unstable and splenectomy is done.

 

Related Pearl: American Association for the Surgery of Trauma (AAST) Spleen Injury Scale

Related Pearl: Indications for Selective Non-Operative Management (SNOM) in splenic trauma

Indications :

  • Patient younger than 55 years
  • Grade I, II, or III (in selective cases) splenic injury
  • Physiologic stability, as indicated by normal blood pressure, lack of tachycardia, absence of physical examination findings indicating shock, and absence of metabolic acidosis.

questions.text:
Match the following variants of Reed-Sternberg cell with the corresponding subtype of Hodgkin's lymphoma.
  1. Lacunar
  2. L&H Popcorn cells 
  3. Pleomorphic
  4. Mononuclear
  1. Nodular sclerosis
  2. Lymphocyte predominant
  3. Lymphocyte depleted
  4. Mixed cellularity and lymphocyte rich
questions.solution:
The correctly matched pairs are as follows:

  1. Lacunar - Nodular sclerosis
  2. L&H popcorn cells - Lymphocyte predominant
  3. Pleomorphic - Lymphocyte depleted
  4. Mononuclear - Mixed cellularity and lymphocyte rich

 

Reed-Sternberg cell (RS cell) is the characteristic tumor giant cell of Hodgkin Lymphoma. It is derived from the germinal center B cell. It has a classic owl-eyed appearance due to the presence of a symmetric or mirror-image bilobed nucleus, with prominent nucleoli surrounded by a clear space. It has the following variants:

  • Lacunar
  • Classic 
  • L&H popcorn cells 
  • Pleomorphic
  • Mononuclear

RS cells should be present in a background of non-neoplastic inflammatory cells like lymphocytes, plasma cells, and eosinophils, to make a diagnosis of Hodgkin’s lymphoma.

The image given below shows the diagnostic Reed-Sternberg cell, with two nuclear lobes, large inclusion-like nucleoli, and abundant cytoplasm, surrounded by lymphocytes, macrophages, and an eosinophil.

The image below shows Reed-Sternberg cell, mononuclear variant.

The image below shows Reed-Sternberg cell, lacunar variant. This variant has a folded or multilobated nucleus and lies within an open space, which is an artefact created by disruption of the cytoplasm during tissue sectioning.

The image below shows the Reed-Sternberg cell, lymphohistiocytic variant. Several such variants with multiple infolded nuclear membranes, small nucleoli, fine chromatin, and abundant pale cytoplasm are present.

Related Pearl: Important Features of the Different Types of Hodgkin's Lymphoma (HL)

Classic subtypes

  • Nodular sclerosis 
  • Mixed cellularity 
  • Lymphocyte-rich
  • Lymphocyte depletion

Non-Classical subtype

  • Lymphocyte predominant

Note: Mixed cellularity is most commonly associated with HIV due to its high incidence. 

Related Pearl: Variants of Reed Sternberg Cells

Variant Reed–Sternberg cells and the corresponding subtype of Hodgkin's Lymphoma

  • Lacunar Variant: Nodular Sclerosis
  • Mononuclear variant: Mixed cellularity and Lymphocyte rich 
  • Pleomorphic/Necrotic/Mummified Variant: Lymphocyte depleted 
  • L&H/Lymphohistiocytic/Popcorn Variant: Lymphocyte predominant

questions.text: The following deformity is seen in a patient with a history of spinal tuberculosis. What is this deformity called as?
questions.solution:
The skeletal deformity seen in the patient above with significant sagittal curvature of the thoracic spine is kyphosis.

Spinal tuberculosis may present with the following skeletal deformities:

Deformity Mechanism Description
Knuckle Collapse of a single vertebra Prominence of a single spinous process
Gibbus/Kyphus Collapse of 2-3 vertebral levels Sharp posterior angulation
Kyphosis Collapse of anterior vertebral bodies Exaggerated curvature of the vertebral column
Concertina collapse / vertebra plana Collapse of the entire vertebral body Seen in tuberculosis of the central vertebral body

 

Tb spine occurs secondary to a pulmonary or gastrointestinal primary and spreads through the Batson's plexus of veins (paravertebral plexus). It most commonly involves the dorso-lumbar region. 

Types of vertebral tuberculosis:

  • Paradiscal - contiguous areas of two adjacent vertebrae and the middle intervening disc are affected. This is due to the high oxygen requirements of tubercular bacteria and the corresponding high blood supply in this region by the segmental vessels.
  • Central - the body of the vertebra is involved leading to collapse (causing wedging or concertina) of the affected vertebra. This leads to spinal deformities such as kyphosis and gibbus.
  • Anterior - the anterior part of body is affected and spreads through anterior longitudinal ligament.
  • Posterior - the posterior complex (pedicle, lamina, spinous process and transverse process) is affected.

Image showing various parts and patterns of involvement in Pott's spine. 

Clinical features of spinal tuberculosis:

  • Back pain, stiffness and reduced movements are the usual early complaints
  • Cautious gait - a person with spinal TB will walk carefully with short steps to avoid pain resulting from movement
  • Pott's paraplegia
  • Cold abscess
  • Concertina collapse - a type of compression fracture without involvement of the interverterbral disc
  • Deformity - kyphus and gibbus (gradually increasing prominence).

Images showing concertina collapse and the deformities seen TB spine.

The image below shows gibbus

questions.text: The cell marked in the image below predominantly plays a role in which of the following hypersensitivity reactions?
questions.solution:
The cell marked in the image is a mast cell stained with toluidine blue. Mast cells play an important role in type-I hypersensitivity reactions.

Mast cell granules contain acid proteoglycan that binds basic blue such as toluidine blue. Mast cells may be difficult to differentiate from lymphocytes in routine, hematoxylin, and eosin-stained sections, and special metachromatic stains (toluidine blue or Giemsa) are used to visualize their granules.

Mast cells are a part of innate immunity and are widely distributed in connective tissues. They play an important role in immediate hypersensitivity and both acute and chronic inflammation.

Mast cells express a receptor on their surface that binds to the Fc portion of the IgE antibody. When an antigen binds to IgE antibodies on the surface of the mast cell, they get activated and degranulate. This results in the release of the following:

  • Granule contents: Histamine, chymase, tryptase, heparin.
  • Lipid mediators: Leucotriene C4, D4, prostaglandin D2, platelet-activating factor.
  • Cytokines: Tumor necrosis factor, interleukin-1

These mediators released from mast cells play an important role in the pathogenesis of immediate/type 1 hypersensitivity.

The image given below shows the sequence of events in immediate (type 1) hypersensitivity.

Some of the important disorders associated with mast cell activity are bronchial asthma, urticaria, mastocytosis, interstitial cystitis and neurofibroma.

Related Pearl: Mechanisms of Hypersensitivity Reactions

Type

Immune Mechanisms

Histopathological lesions

Immediate
 hypersensitivity
(type I)

  • Anaphylaxis
  • Allergies
  • Bronchial asthma
  • Atopic dermatitis

Production of IgE antibody →immediate release of vasoactive amines from mast cells

Vascular dilatation, edema, smooth muscle contraction, mucus production, tissue injury, inflammation

Antibody-mediated hypersensitivity
(type II)

  • Autoimmune hemolytic anemia
  • Goodpasture syndrome

Production of IgG, IgM → binds to antigen on target cell or tissue → phagocytosis or lysis of target cell by activated complement or Fc receptors; recruitment of leukocytes

Phagocytosis and lysis of cells; inflammation;

Immune complex-mediated hypersensitivity
(type III)

  • SLE
  • Serum sickness
  • Arthus reaction

Deposition of antigen-antibody complexes → complement activation →recruitment of leukocytes by complement products and Fc receptors → release of enzymes and other toxic molecules

Inflammation, necrotizing vasculitis (fibrinoid necrosis)

Cell-mediated hypersensitivity
(type IV)

  • Contact dermatitis
  • Multiple sclerosis
  • Type 1 diabetes
  • Tuberculosis

Activated T lymphocytes →

1. Release of cytokines, inflammation, and macrophage activation

2. T-cell-mediated cytotoxicity

Perivascular cellular infiltrates; edema; granuloma formation; cell destruction

Related Pearl: Various stains and their applications in Pathology and Microbiology

Staining technique Cells/inclusions stained Disorders
H&E Most common stain used in routine histopathology Commonly used for all slides

questions.text: Autoantibodies against Dsg3 would typically be seen in patients with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Autoantibodies against Dsg3 would typically be seen in patients with pemphigus vulgaris.

In pemphigus vulgaris, Anti-Dsg 3 antibodies predominate. As Dsg 3 is present in all the layers of the mucosa, but is found only in the basal and immediate suprabasal layers of skin, the oral epithelium is primarily affected with relative sparing of skin remaining.

In the case of pemphigus foliaceus, Anti-Dsg1 antibodies predominate. Hence, the skin is primarily affected with sparing of oral mucosa.

questions.text: All of the following result in the change of gene frequencies in a population except:
questions.solution:
In a Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium state, there is no change in gene frequencies. 

The Hardy-Weinberg law states that the relative frequencies of each gene allele tend to remain constant from generation to generation in the absence of forces that change the gene frequencies. A population in Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium would not have any change in the gene frequencies.

But, this is a theoretical concept, and in practice, the human population is never in an equilibrium state because of the action of the following forces that result in the change of gene frequencies from generation to generation:

  • Mutation
  • Natural Selection
  • Population movements
  • Breeding structure resulting in nonrandom mating
  • Public health measures

Related Pearl: Hardy-Weinberg Law

  • The Hardy-Weinberg Law is related to population genetics.
  • It is based on the principle founded by G.H. Hardy and Wilhelm Weinberg.
  • The law states that the relative frequencies of each gene allele tends to remain constant from generation to generation in the absence of other evolutionary influences.
  • It is also called the Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium or principle.
  • It is only applicable for infinitely large, static populations which randomly mate.
  • This law fails in the following conditions:
    • Small and dynamic populations
    • Non random or assortative mating
    • Mutations
    • Gene outflow and genetic drift
    • Migration

questions.text: What type of MRI image is given below?
questions.solution:
The image shown is a proton density (PD)-weighted image as the CSF fluid appears similar in density to fat.  

A PD-weighted image is based on the number of nuclei in the area that is imaged. In PD-weighted imaging, tissues with a higher density of protons produce stronger signals and appear brighter. PD-weighted images can be identified by comparing fluid with the fat signal: fluids in these images appear greyish white, similar or the appearance of fat in the body.

Other options:

Susceptibility-weighted imaging is a form of MRI sequence that is especially sensitive to substances that distort the local magnetic field. Compounds with diamagnetic, paramagnetic, and ferromagnetic properties will interact with the local magnetic field and produce distraction. This would lead to a loss of signal in these areas.

Deoxyhemoglobin, hemosiderin, and ferritin are paramagnetic. Bone minerals and dystrophic calcifications are diamagnetic in nature. The main clinical use is the identification of microhemorrhages/blood products or calcium that are not detected in other MRI sequences.

The image shown below is a susceptibility-weighted image (SWI) as it clearly demonstrates microhemorrhages as hypointense foci.

Gradient echo sequences (GRE): 

It uses gradient fields to generate transverse magnetization. In areas of hemorrhage, the iron that is present in the hemoglobin produces its own local magnetic field and dephases the spinning nuclei. This is useful to identify hemorrhagic contusions in the brain and pigmented villonodular synovitis.

Inversion recovery sequences:

This MRI sequence is used to selectively null certain tissues. It can be

  • Short tau inversion recovery (STIR) where fat is nulled. Fluids appear bright and fat appears dark in these images.
  • Fluid attenuated inversion recovery (FLAIR) or double inversion recovery (DIR), where fluid is nulled. The fluid (CSF) normally appears dark and lesions appear to be brighter in these images.

FLAIR image:

questions.text:
During the antenatal assessment of a mother, you would suspect probable fetal asphyxia if the biophysical profile score is ________.

AFI- Amniotic fluid index
questions.solution:
Fetal asphyxia would be suspected when the biophysical profile (BPP) score is 4/10.

BPP is a multi-parametric, screening test to assess uteroplacental insufficiency. It consists of five components/ variables and the observations are made in a 30-minute time period.

Components of BPP: (Mnemonic: BATMaN)

  • B - Breathing movements of the fetus
  • A - Amniotic fluid volume (AFI)
  • T - Tone of the fetus
  • M - Movements of the fetus
  • N - Non-stress test (NST)

Each parameter has a maximum score of 2 and a minimum score of 0. So the total maximum score will be 10. A score of 4 or less indicates fetal acidemia.

Interpretation of the BPP scores and the corresponding management:

BPP score Fetal asphyxia Management
10
No

Repeat test weekly 

8 
with
normal
AFV

 No

Repeat test weekly 
8
with decreased AFV		 Suspicion of chronic asphyxia Deliver, if 
≥36 weeks
6
with 
normal
AFV		  Equivocal Deliver, if ≥37 weeks,
if <37 weeks, repeat test in 24 hours
6
with decreased AFV
 Possible

Deliver, if 36-37 weeks
4 Probable  Deliver, if 
≥32 weeks
0-2 Almost certain  Delivery 

 

BPP is directly related to fetal pH and fetal outcome. A lower BPP score is associated with a poor outcome (stillbirth, perinatal mortality) and lower APGAR scores at birth.

A score of 8-10 is associated with a normal pH and a score of 0 is associated with significant fetal acidemia.

Note: The modified biophysical score has only 2 components i.e NST and amniotic fluid index only. It is considered abnormal (nonreassuring) when the NST is non-reactive and/or the AFI is <5.

Related Pearl: Change in the amniotic fluid volume through gestation

38-39 weeks plateaus at 1000 mL
40 weeks  800

Note: The average volume increases with gestational age, peaking at 800-1000 mL, which coincides with 36-37 weeks' gestation.

questions.text:
A 19-year-old trekking enthusiast embarks on a month-long trek across the Himalayas. Which of the following physiological adaptations would you expect to see in him at high altitudes following acclimatization?

 

  1. Erythropoietin secretion increases 
  2. Tissue mitochondria increase in number
  3. Tissue myoglobin decreases
  4. Tissue content of cytochrome oxidase also increases
  5. pH of blood increases
questions.solution:
Myoglobin increases to facilitate the movement of O2 into the tissues in high altitudes following acclimatization.

Compensatory mechanisms that are carried out to increase altitude tolerance are called acclimatization. 

Following are the physiological changes that occur during acclimatization:

  • Hyperventilation leads to respiratory alkalosis and shift of the oxygen–hemoglobin dissociation curve to the left (and shifts to right after aclimitization).
  • Increased erythropoietin secretion, leading to an increase in circulating red blood cells
  • Increased number of mitochondria
  • Increased myoglobin to facilitate the movement of O2 into the tissues
  • Increased tissue cytochrome oxidase
  • Increased sympathetic tone
  • Renal suppression of carbonic anhydrase and excretion of dilute alkaline urine brings the pH of the blood to normal.
  • Decreased maximal exercise capacity (by ~1% for every 100 meters gained above 1500 meters)

questions.text:
Match the following radionuclide dye with its indication:
1. Tc-99m DTPA (diethylene-triamine-pentaacetate) A. CEA-expressing cancers
2. Tc-99m DMSA (dimercaptosuccinic acid) B. Vesicoureteral reflux
3. Tc-99m pertechnetate C. Renal structure and morphology
4. Tc-99m Arcitumomab D. Direct measurement of GFR
questions.solution:
The correctly matched pairs are 1-D, 2-C, 3-B, 4-A.

Radionuclide dye Indication
Tc-99m DTPA (diethylene-triamine-pentaacetate) Direct measurement of glomerular filtration rate (GFR)
Tc-99m DMSA (dimercaptosuccinic acid) Renal structure and morphology
Tc-99m pertechnetate Vesicoureteral reflux
Tc-99m Arcitumomab CEA-expressing cancers


Tc-99m DTPA (diethylene-triamine-pentaacetate) is cleared only via glomeruli with no tubular excretion and hence used for direct measurement of GFR.

Tc-99m DMSA (dimercaptosuccinic acid) is used in renal imaging to evaluate renal structure and morphology, particularly in pediatric imaging for the detection of scarring and pyelonephritis. DMSA is an ideal agent for the assessment of the renal cortex as it binds to the sulfhydryl groups in proximal tubules at the renal cortex with longer retention than other agents. It allows for a better assessment of differential renal function. It is a static scan as opposed to dynamic DTPA or MAG3 scans.

Assessment of VUR can be done by direct isotope cystography using 99m Tc-pertechnetate. Other uses of Tc-99m pertechnetate:

  • Thyroid imaging for thyroid nodules and ectopic thyroid
  • Salivary gland imaging
  • Meckel scan
  • Gastric emptying studies, intestinal and rectal functional studies.
  • Vesicoureteral reflux imaging.

99mTc-Arcitumomab, which is formed by the conjugation of 99mTc with a murine anti-carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) monoclonal antibody (MAb) Fab fragment, can be used for imaging CEA-expressing cancers.
