questions.text: According to the 2020 revised CEAP classification, C6r is used to denote a patient with ____.
questions.solution:
Recurrent active venous ulcer is classified as C6r according to the recent 2020 update in the Clinical-Etiology-Anatomy-Pathophysiology (CEAP) classification system. 

Varicose veins are subcutaneous dilated, tortuous veins with diameter of 3 mm or more. They commonly present with a sensation of dragging pain, heaviness, itching, or burning over the affected area or the whole limb, and swelling of the feet. These symptoms increase throughout the day or with prolonged standing and are relieved by elevation or compression hosiery.

Risk factors:

  • Female gender
  • Increasing age
  • Increasing body mass and height
  • Pregnancy
  • Family history
  • Smoking
  • Occupations involving prolonged standing

 According to the CEAP classification, venous disease is classified as follows:  

  • C0: No signs of venous disease
  • C1: Telangiectasia or reticular veins
  • C2: Varicose veins
  • C2r: recurrent varicose veins 
  • C3: Edema
  • C4: Skin changes due to chronic venous disease
  • C4a: Pigmentation or eczema (including malleolar flare)
  • C4b: Lipodermatosclerosis or atrophie blanche
  • C4c: Corona phlebectatica 
  • C5: Healed venous ulcer
  • C6: Active venous ulcer
  • C6r: Recurrent active venous ulcer

The images below show C5 and C6—healed and active venous ulcers, respectively.

Telangiectasia/thread veins/spider veins (C1) are intradermal venules with diameter < 1 mm.

A reticular vein (C1) is a subdermal vein with diameter 1–3 mm.

Atrophie blanche (C4b) refers to localized areas of white, atrophic skin, often surrounded by telangiectasia and pigmentation.

The image below shows atrophie blanche:

Lipodermatosclerosis (C4b) is pigmentation, chronic inflammation, and induration of the skin and subcutaneous tissues in the calf and around the ankle. Champagne bottle sign/inverted beer bottle sign is seen in lipodermatosclerosis, as shown in the image below:

Malleolar flare/Corona phlebectatica (C4c) is fan-shaped telangiectasia on the ankle or foot.

Duplex ultrasound is the investigation of choice for varicose veins.

Management of varicose veins

Incompetence Management
Great saphenous vein (GSV) and saphenofemoral (SFJ) 
  • Endothermal ablation (gold standard treatment for varicose veins). It includes:
  • Endovenous laser ablation (EVLA)
  • Radiofrequency ablation (RFA)
  • Trendelenburg procedure (Flush Ligation of Saphenofemoral Junction (SFJ) after ligation of 6 tributaries) ± stripping (retrogradely up to the knee, to prevent saphenous nerve injury.)     
Short saphenous vein (SSJ) and saphenopopliteal (SPJ)
  • Flush ligation of SPJ (Stripping is not done to prevent sural nerve injury)
  • Endothermal ablation:
  • Endovenous laser ablation (EVLA)
  • Radiofrequency ablation (RFA)
Perforator 
  • Dodd and Crockett surgery - Multiple subfascial ligations
  • Subfascial endoscopic perforator surgery (SEPS) - smaller incision, so cosmetically better
  • Endothermal ablation:
  • Endovenous laser ablation (EVLA)
  • Radiofrequency ablation (RFA)

New treatment modalities:

  • Foam sclerotherapy - The Tessari method is a widely used method to prepare foam for sclerotherapy. Sclerosant: air ratio taken is 1:3 or 1:4.
  • Endovenous glue therapy - endoluminal application of cyanoacrylate adhesive 
  • TriVex - Transilluminated powered phlebectomy

questions.text: Which of the following tests is useful for detecting bile salts in urine?
questions.solution:
Hay's test is used for the detection of bile salts in urine. Normally, bile salts (sodium salts of taurocholic acid and glycocholic acid) are not present in urine. Thus, positive Hay's test indicates an obstructive pathology in the biliary system, leading to the backflow of bile into the circulation. This obstruction may be associated with either obstructive jaundice or hepatic jaundice.

Fouchet's test is used for detecting the presence of bile pigments in urine. Here, urine is heated with barium sulfate, which adsorbs bilirubin. Ferric chloride is added, which oxidizes the adsorbed bilirubin to biliverdin which produces a green color. Principle for all tests to detect bile pigments: Oxidizing agents readily oxidize bilirubin to biliverdin to form a green color.

Ehrlich's test is used to determine urinary and fecal urobilinogen. Porphobilinogens form a red aldehyde compound with Ehrlich reagent, which is insoluble in chloroform. A red color remaining after chloroform extraction is indicative of porphobilinogens. This test is positive in acute intermittent porphyria and hemolytic jaundice. It is negative in hepatic jaundice (later stages) and obstructive jaundice. The earliest sign of recovery in obstructive jaundice is the re-appearance of urobilinogen in urine.

Rothera’s test by nitroprusside reagent is a specific test used to detect whether acetone or acetoacetate is present in the given sample of urine. A purple ring at the junction of two liquids indicates a positive test. Rothera's test does not detect β-hydroxybutyrate.  

The other test used for the purpose of detecting acetoacetate only is the ferric chloride test. It shows a burgundy red color that is graded from +1 to +4. False-positive results occur with drugs like salicylates and phenols. 

The image below shows the purple ring formed by a positive Rothera test.

Related Pearl: Rothera's Test Procedure

Rothera's test, positive for ketone bodies.

questions.text: What is the most common ocular manifestation of SLE?
questions.solution:
The most common ocular manifestation of SLE is Sicca syndrome.

The most common manifestations of different systems involved in SLE are:

  • Musculoskeletal- arthritis and arthralgia
  • Skin- photosensitivity
  • Kidneys- proteinuria
  • Neurologic- cognitive impairment
  • Cardiac- pericarditis
  • Pulmonary- pleuritis
  • Hematologic- anemia

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding prophylaxis in contacts of a patient with leprosy?

choices.text: Prophylaxis is recommended for pregnant females also
Prophylaxis is contraindicated if contact is confirmed with TB
Prophylaxis is contraindicated if contact has possible signs and/or symptoms of TB
Chemoprophylaxis must be initiated only 4 weeks after initiation of treatment for the patient

questions.solution:
Prophylaxis is contraindicated during pregnancy. Chemoprophylaxis with single-dose rifampicin can be administered after delivery.

Chemoprophylaxis for leprosy should be given to the following contacts:

  • A person who has been in close contact with the index case for 20 hours or more per week for more than 3 months.
  • Close contact if the age is more than 2 years

Chemoprophylaxis cannot be given if there is/are:

  • Possible signs of leprosy
  • Signs or confirmed tuberculosis
  • Liver or kidney disease
  • Pregnancy
  • Received rifampicin in the last 2 years

A single dose of rifampicin is used in chemoprophylaxis. Chemoprophylaxis must be initiated only 4 weeks after treatment for leprosy has begun in the patient so as to ensure the patient is non-infectious.

Dose of rifampicin in chemoprophylaxis of leprosy
Age Dose
Children 2-5 years 10-15 mg/kg
Children 6-9 years (less than 20kg) 150 mg
Children 6-9 years (more than 20kg) 300 mg
10-14 years 450 mg
15 years and above 600 mg

questions.text:
Starting a patient on propranolol would be contraindicated if he has a history of ______.
  1. Migraine
  2. Asthma
  3. Uncompensated congestive heart failure
  4. Essential tremor
  5. Hypertrophic Subaortic Stenosis
questions.solution:
Asthma & uncompensated congestive heart failure are contraindications for starting a patient on propranolol, a non-selective beta-blocker.

Migraine, essential tremor, and hypertrophic subaortic stenosis are indications for which propranolol can be prescribed. Other labeled indications of propranolol are as follows:

  • Hypertension
  • Angina
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • Myocardial infarction
  • Supraventricular arrhythmia

Contraindications of propranolol include:

  • Asthma, COPD
  • Severe sinus bradycardia or second- or third-degree heart block without a pacemaker
  • Cardiogenic shock
  • Uncompensated congestive heart failure

 

Note:

Portal hypertension and prevention of variceal bleeding is an off-label indication for propranolol, not a labeled indication.

questions.text:
Which of the following arteries are usually the branches of the mandibular part of the maxillary artery?
  1. Middle meningeal
  2. Masseteric artery
  3. Infra-orbital artery
  4. Inferior alveolar
  5. Deep auricular 
  6. Anterior tympanic arteries.
questions.solution:
Branches from the mandibular division of the maxillary artery:

  1. Middle meningeal
  2. Inferior alveolar
  3. Deep auricular 
  4. Anterior tympanic arteries

The masseteric artery is a branch of the pterygoid part, and the infra-orbital artery is a branch of the pterygopalatine part.

Related Pearl: Divisions of Maxillary Artery and Its Branches

1st part/Mandibular part: 

  • Extend - Neck of the mandible to lower border of Lateral pterygoid
  • Common Pattern - All branches from this part enter the bone.
  • Branches
    • middle meningeal,
    • accessory meningeal,
    • inferior alveolar,
    • deep auricular 
    • anterior tympanic arteries.

2nd part/Pterygoid part:

  • Location - In the infratemporal fossa
  • Common Pattern - All are muscular branches.
  • Branches
    • Artery to lateral pterygoid,
    • medial pterygoid,
    • Masseteric artery
    • 2 deep temporal arteries.

3rd part/Pterygopalatine part:

  • Location - pterygopalatine fossa
  • Branches
    • Artery of pterygoid canal,
    • Infra-orbital artery,
    • Greater palatine,
    • Sphenopalatine artery,
    • pharyngeal artery,
    • posterior superior alveolar artery.

questions.text: The absence of fetal pole in a gestational sac of diameter 35mm would be termed as
questions.solution:
The absence of a fetal pole in a gestational sac of diameter 35mm would be termed as a blighted ovum/ silent miscarriage

Blighted ovum (silent miscarriage) occurs when a fertilized egg implants in the uterus but doesn't develop into an embryo. It is a sonographic diagnosis where there is an absence of a fetal pole in a gestational sac with a diameter of 3 cm or more.

questions.text: What is the time taken for peak response in IgM-mediated immune response?
questions.solution:
Primary immune response is IgM mediated. This peaks at 7-10 Days. 

An immune response occurs as a result of an antigenic stimulus. It is of two types: Humoral or antibody-mediated response, and cellular or cell-mediated response. The response to the antigenic stimulus can be primary or secondary. The features of the primary and secondary immune responses are:

Features Primary immune response Secondary immune response
1. Lag period 4-10 days

1-3 days
2. Peak response time  7-10 days

3-5 days
3. Antibody response  Depends on the antigen More potent than the primary immune response
4. Isotype generate IgM IgG
5. Antigens Both thymus-dependent and independent Depends only on the thymus
6. Antibody affinity Lower Higher

questions.text: Which of the following depicts the life cycle of Diphyllobothrium latum?
questions.solution:
Image 1 corresponds to the life cycle of Diphyllobothrium latum.

Diphyllobothrium latum infection is acquired by eating raw or undercooked fish, containing third-stage plerocercoid larva. The organism usually causes diphyllobothriasis (transient abdominal discomfort, diarrhea, nausea, weakness, weight loss) and vitamin B12 deficiency by absorbing large quantities of vitamin B12 and interfering with the ileal absorption.

  • Definitive hosts: Man, dog, and cat; Man is the optimal host.
  • First intermediate host: Cyclops or Diaptomus
  • Second intermediate host: Freshwater fish (salmon, trout, etc.).

Treatment for D. latum infection is Praziquantel.

The image below shows the life cycle of Diphyllobothrium latum: 

Paragonimus westermani (lung fluke) infection is acquired by consuming freshwater crab/crayfish containing metacercariae. It causes pulmonary symptoms similar to pulmonary tuberculosis (coughing and hemoptysis).

  • Definitive host: Man, cats, tigers, leopards, foxes, dogs, pigs, beavers, and domestic animals
  • First intermediate host: Freshwater snail
  • Second intermediate host: Freshwater crab or crayfish

The adult worms live in the respiratory tract of the definitive host in cystic spaces surrounded by a fibrous capsule formed by the host tissues. Unembryonated eggs escape into the bronchi and are coughed up and voided in sputum or swallowed and passed in feces.

Praziquantel (25 mg/kg TDS for 1–2 days) is the drug of choice.

The given image shows the life cycle of Paragonimus westermani:

Fasciola hepatica is a liver fluke that resides in the liver and the lumen of the biliary passages and causes fascioliasis. It mainly affects sheep and other domestic animals. Infection in sheep and man is acquired by ingestion of metacercariae encysted on aquatic vegetation.

  • Definitive host: Sheep, goat, cattle, and man.
  • Intermediate host: Snails of the genus Lymnaea and Succinea. Encystment occurs on aquatic plants, which act as the second intermediate host.

Oral triclabendazole (10 mg/kg once) is the treatment of choice

Life cycle of Fasciola hepatica:

Brugia malayi causes filariasis in man. The intermediate hosts of Brugia are vectors of genera Mansonia, Anopheles, and Aedes. In India, the main vectors are Mansonia annulifera and Mansonia uniformis.

Diethylcarbamazine is the drug of choice. It is given orally in a dose of 6 mg/kg body weight daily, for a period of 12 days.

Life cycle of Brugia malayi:

questions.text:
Which of the following structures pass through the marked foramen?
  1. Inferior petrosal sinus
  2. Spinal accessory nerve
  3. Vagus nerve
  4. Hypoglossal nerve
  5. Middle meningeal branch of the occipital artery
  6. Deep petrosal nerve
questions.solution:
The marked foramen is the jugular foramen. Option B is the correct answer. The structures passing through it are as follows:

  1. Inferior petrosal sinus
  2. Meningeal branch of ascending pharyngeal artery
  3. Glossopharyngeal Nerve - IX
  4. Vagus Nerve - X 
  5. Spinal Accessory Nerve - XI
  6. Sigmoid Sinus continuing as internal jugular vein
  7. Middle meningeal branch of the occipital artery

 The hypoglossal nerve passes via the hypoglossal canal.

The deep petrosal nerve carries postganglionic sympathetic fibers from the pterygopalatine ganglion. It then joins with the greater petrosal nerve to form the nerve of the pterygoid (Vidian) canal.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions warrants treatment with oral corticosteroids?
questions.solution:
The only indication for using systemic steroids in psoriasis is generalized pustular psoriasis in pregnancy (impetigo herpetiformis). In fact, the drug of choice for impetigo herpetiformis is systemic steroids. 

Impetigo herpetiformis typically presents during the last trimester of pregnancy. It may persist until the delivery of the child; however, it may even persist longer. Clinical features include the following:

  • Characteristic erythematous patches with marginal grouped sterile pustules
  • Flexures affected, symmetrical
  • Centrifugal extension from the inguino-genital region
  • Grouping of areas of pustulation
  • Erosions and crusts may be present
  • Residual reddish-brown pigmentation as healing occurs.
  • Nail, mucosal lesions in tongue, mouth, and oesophagus
  • May be associated with hypothyroidism and hypocalcemia

The mainstay of treatment is systemic corticosteroids. If the patient is unresponsive to corticosteroids, cyclosporine may also be started. Antibiotics like cephalosporins are found to be effective as an additive treatment, even though the pustules are sterile. Narrowband UVB is considered another safe treatment when there is no adequate response to steroids.

Complications like IUGR, PROM, and placental insufficiency are also seen. Death of the mother may occur due to cardiac or renal failure. Recurrence is common.

Related Pearl: Drug of choice for different types of psoriasis

Erythrodermic Psoriasis Methotrexate

Pustular Psoriasis Acitretin

Impetigo Herpetiformis

1. Systemic Corticosteroids

2. Cyclosporine

questions.text: Cardiac edema and neuropathy are seen to be present in a patient with suspected nutritional deficiency.  Which of the following biochemical assays would you advise?
questions.solution:
Cardiac edema and neuropathy are associated with a deficiency of thiamine (vitamin B1). Measurement of erythrocyte transketolase provides an index of vitamin B1 nutritional status. 

Thiamine diphosphate (Vit B1) is the cofactor of transketolase which is involved in the pentose phosphate pathway, pyruvate dehydrogenase which is involved in carbohydrate metabolism, α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase which is involved in the citric acid cycle, and branched-chain keto acid dehydrogenase which is involved in the metabolism of leucine, isoleucine, and valine.

Wet beriberi (cardiac) is associated with tachycardia, cardiomegaly, cardiac failure, and edema. It is commonly seen in the refugee camps where people consume polished rice-based monotonous diets. Diagnosis of thiamine deficiency can be established by erythrocyte transketolase activity assessment.

Dry beriberi is associated with neurological deficits such as peripheral neuropathy, optic atrophy, ataxia, and irritability. Complications include lactic acidosis and Wernicke encephalopathy in adults.

questions.text: Which of the following infants would not be considered high risk as per the NACO guidelines?

choices.text: An infant born to HIV-positive mother who is not on ART
An infant born to a mother with maternal viral load not done after 32 weeks of pregnancy
An infant born to a mother with maternal viral load not suppressed after 32 weeks of pregnancy
An infant born to a mother who is newly identified as HIV-positive 11 weeks after delivery

questions.solution:
An infant born to a mother who is newly identified as HIV-positive within 6 weeks of delivery should be considered as high risk, as per the NACO guidelines.

 High-risk infants include

  • infants born to HIV-positive mothers who are not on ART
  • maternal viral load not done after 32 weeks of pregnancy
  • maternal viral load not suppressed after 32 weeks of pregnancy
  • mother is newly identified HIV-positive within 6 weeks of delivery

Low-risk infants are infants born to mothers with suppressed viral load (<1000 copies/mL) done any time after 32 weeks of pregnancy up to delivery

According to the National AIDS Control Organization (NACO), antiretroviral therapy (ART) should be given to all pregnant women, including during labor hours and breastfeeding. They are started on a triple-drug ART. ART should be given irrespective of the CD4 count and clinical stage, and treatment should be continued lifelong.

Immediate care of HIV-exposed infants includes wiping of baby's mouth and nostrils, handling of infants with gloves, immediate cord clamping, and initiation of feeding. An infant born to an HIV-positive mother should be breastfed exclusively or by replacement feeds exclusively for 6 months of age.

Infants should receive ARV prophylaxis. A single drug or dual drug regimen is followed depending on the risk of transmission, which can be low or high risk.

  • Low-risk infants are those born to mothers with a low viral load which is detected after 32 weeks of pregnancy till delivery. 
  • High-risk infants are those born to HIV-positive mothers, not on ART, with viral load not estimated beyond 32 weeks, viral load not suppressed after 32 weeks, or diagnosed with HIV within 6 weeks of delivery.
HIV Risk  ARV prophylaxis Duration
Low-risk infants Syrup nevirapine or Syrup zidovudine

 Birth to 6 weeks of age irrespective of feeding 
High-risk infants Syrup nevirapine + syrup zidovudine

If exclusive replacement feeding: Birth to 6 weeks

If exclusive breastfeeding: Birth till 12 weeks

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with fever, joint pain, and a lesion over his hand, as seen in the image below. Histopathological examination would most likely reveal?

choices.text: Perimysial CD4+ cellular infiltrates, perivascular infiltrates and perifascicular atrophy
Endomysial CD8+ cellular infiltrates  and perivascular infiltrates
Perivascular infiltrates with amyloid inclusion bodies and rimmed vacuoles
Perimysial CD8+ cellular infiltrates with amyloid inclusion bodies and rimmed vacuoles

questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the patient has arthritis and skin lesions pointing to Gottron's papules and highly suggestive of dermatomyositis. Perimysial CD4+ cellular infiltrates, perivascular infiltrates, and perifascicular atrophy are characteristic histopathological findings that would be seen in this condition.

Dermatomyositis (DM) is an autoimmune disorder predominantly affecting the skin and skeletal muscle. The following are various manifestations of dermatomyositis:

  • Gottron's papules: Violaceous, erythematous papules overlying the dorsal interphalangeal or metacarpophalangeal, elbow, or knee joints, as shown in the image below
  • Gottron's sign: Symmetric, non-scaling, violaceous, erythematous macules or plaques, often atrophic, in the same distribution as Gottron's papules.
  • Shawl sign/V-sign: Fixed macular erythema across the shoulders and outer arms(Shawl distribution)
  • Periungual telangiectasias: Dilated capillaries of the nail folds
  • Mechanic's hand: Roughening and cracking of the skin of the tips and sides of the fingers, resulting in irregular, dirty-appearing lines that resemble those of a mechanic or manual labourer
  • Proximal myopathy: Patients have trouble performing everyday activities like climbing stairs, getting up, and lifting their arms above their heads.
  • Less common manifestations include: Facial swelling, malignancy, erythroderma, lichen planus

Laboratory evaluation of patients with dermatomyositis will reveal elevated serum creatinine kinase and antinuclear antibodies. Electromyography will reveal features of myopathy. Histology will show perifascicular atrophy. Immunohistochemical staining will reveal myxovirus resistance protein A, a sensitive and specific marker. 

Treatment of dermatomyositis includes:

  • Immunotherapy with high-dose glucocorticoids - first-line drug
  • Methotrexate - second-line drug. Indications include -
    • When a patient presents with severe weakness or other organ system involvement
    • Patients with a risk of steroid complications, like patients with diabetes, osteoporosis, or postmenopausal women
    • Patients who do not show improvement after 2-4 months of treatment with prednisone or those who cannot be maintained on a low dose 
  • Triple therapy with intravenous immunoglobulin or rituximab may be required

Related Pearl: Antibodies in Dermatomyositis

  • Anti-Mi2 antibodies (directed against a helicase implicated in nucleosome remodeling) show a strong association with prominent Gottron papules and heliotrope rash.
  • Anti-Jo1 antibodies (directed against the enzyme histidyl t-RNA synthetase) are associated with interstitial lung disease, nonerosive arthritis, and a skin rash described as “mechanic’s hands.”
  • Anti-P155/P140 antibodies (directed against several transcriptional regulators) are associated with paraneoplastic and juvenile cases of dermatomyositis.

Related Pearl: Inflammatory myopathy

questions.text: What is the action of the muscle supplied by the structure marked in the image?
questions.solution:
The arrow in the given image shows the trochlear nerve (CN IV). It is identified easily as it is the only cranial nerve to emerge from the dorsal surface of the brainstem. It supplies the superior oblique muscle. The actions carried out by the superior oblique muscle are intorsion, depression, and abduction.

questions.text: While explaining the side effects of sulfasalazine to a patient with rheumatoid arthritis, you would be correct to mention all of the following, except _____.

choices.text: In males, it decreases the number and motility of sperm in a reversible manner.
Most common side effects are headache, dyspepsia and skin rash.
In females, it does not cause any impairment of fertility.
It does not cross the placenta, but harms the fetus due to impaired folate absorption.

questions.solution:
Sulfasalazine crosses the placenta, but has not been shown to harm the fetus. It is associated with impaired intestinal folate absorption, because of which it is generally administered with folate.

Sulfasalazine is a prodrug. In the distal GI tract, it is metabolized to 5-aminosalicylic acid (5-ASA) and sulfonamide. Oral sulfasalazine is effective in patients with mild or moderately active ulcerative colitis. It is also used as add-on therapy in the case of moderate to severe rheumatoid arthritis. 

Adverse effects of sulfasalazine:

  • Headache, dyspepsia, and skin rash are the most common side effects. 
  • Side effects of sulfasalazine are mostly related to the sulfa moiety. Allergic reactions include:
    • Rash
    • Fever
    • Stevens-Johnson syndrome
    • Hepatitis
    • Pneumonitis
    • Hemolytic anemia
    • Bone marrow suppression
  • Sulfasalazine reversibly decreases the number and motility of sperm but does not impair female fertility.
  • Sulfasalazine inhibits intestinal folate absorption and is usually administered with folate.
  • Nephrotoxicity may rarely be seen. So, renal function monitoring is recommended in all patients receiving it.
  • Though sulfasalazine and its metabolites cross the placenta, they have not been shown to harm the fetus.

Related Pearl: Important drugs for rheumatoid arthritis

1) NSAIDs - analgesic and anti-inflammatory, used as adjunctive for management of uncontrollable symptoms and in acute flares.

2) Glucocorticoids - used in acute flare for rapid control and as initial therapy before the onset of action of DMARDs. Chronic administration of low doses is needed in patients with inadequate response to DMARDs.

  • Prednisolone - oral

  • Triamcinolone - intraarticular
     

3) DMARDs - disease-modifying anti-rheumatoid drugs:

 

- Conventional DMARDs:

  • Methotrexate (MTX)- is an antifolate drug. The DMARD of choice and the anchor drug for combination therapy. Regular LFT monitoring is required.
  • Hydroxychloroquine- is used as monotherapy for early and mild disease and in combination with other DMARDs for severe cases.
  • Sulfasalazine- is a salicylate. It reduces the radiographic progression of the disease.
  • Leflunomide- is a pyrimidine synthase inhibitor used as an alternative to MTX.

- Biologicals:

  • TNF-α antagonists- used in combination with MTX. Has a risk of serious bacterial infections, opportunistic fungal infection & reactivation of latent TB. The TNF-α inhibitors are adalimumab, golimumab, etanercept, infliximab, and certolizumab.
  • Abatacept- a T-cell costimulation inhibitor, used in combination with MTX, leflunomide, etc.
  • Rituximab- an anti-CD20 antibody. Used in refractory disease in combination with MTX.
  • Anakinra- an IL-1 receptor antagonist. It should not be combined with anti-TNF alpha.
  • IL-6 receptor antagonists- tocilizumab and sarilumab are used as monotherapy or combination therapy in moderate to severe disease.  

- Small molecules: 

  • Janus kinase inhibitors: Tofacitinib, baricitinib, and upadacitinib are used as monotherapy or combination therapy.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding monkey pox is false?

choices.text: Patient needs to wear a triple layer mask during isolation.
Contact monitoring must be done for a period of 21 days from day of contact.
During ambulance transfer, the accompanying personnel should wear long-sleeved gowns, N95 Mask, gloves, and goggles.
It is caused by an enveloped, single-stranded DNA virus.

questions.solution:
All the statements mentioned above are true about monkeypox, except that it is caused by an enveloped, single-stranded DNA virus.

Monkeypox is caused by an enveloped double-stranded DNA virus, which belongs to the Orthopoxvirus genus of the Poxviridae family.

The natural reservoir is unknown. The incubation period can range from 5 to 21 days. The period of communicability is 1–2 days prior to the onset of the rash until all scabs fall off/ subside. Both human-to-human and animal-to-human transmission is known to occur.

People with monkeypox get a rash that may be located on or near the genitals (penis, testicles, labia, and vagina) or anus and could be on other areas like the hands, feet, chest, face, or mouth.

At first, the rash may resemble acne or blister and may be painful or itchy. Before the rash heals, it will go through a number of stages, including scabs.

The image given below shows the stages of the monkeypox lesion.

Other signs and symptoms of monkeypox include fever with chills, enlarged lymph nodes, back, and muscle aches, headache, and respiration symptoms like sore throat, nasal congestion, or cough.

Management includes patient isolation, protection of compromised skin and mucous membranes, rehydration therapy, and nutritional support.

Patient Isolation

  • Isolate the patient in a room with separate ventilation.
  • The patient should wear a triple-layer mask.
  • Cover skin lesions as much as possible, with measures such as using long sleeves and long pants, to minimize the risk of contact.
  • Continue isolation until all lesions resolve and scabs completely fall off.

Contact monitoring

  • Contact monitoring must be done for a period of 21 days from the day of contact.
  • Asymptomatic exposed health workers do not need to be excluded from work but should be under active surveillance for 21 days.

During ambulance transfer, accompanying personnel should wear long-sleeved gowns, N95 masks, gloves, and goggles.

questions.text: An incidentally found Meckel's diverticulum can be left alone if

choices.text: it has a wide mouth and is not thickened
it has a narrow mouth and is not thickened
it has a narrow mouth and is thickened
it has a wide mouth and is thickened

questions.solution:
If an incidentally found Meckel's diverticulum has a wide mouth and is not thickened, it can safely be left alone.

 When Meckel's diverticulum is found in the course of abdominal surgery,

  • In cases of narrow-mouthed, thickened Meckel’s diverticulum, resection of the diverticulum is the treatment of choice.
  • If it has a wide mouth and is not thickened, it can safely be left alone.

As there is the risk of stricture and of leaving heterotopic epithelium behind, a broad-based Meckel’s diverticulum should not be amputated at its base and invaginated like the procedure done for an appendix. The diverticulum should be excised either by resecting it and suturing the defect at its base or with a linear stapler-cutter.

Rarely, Meckel's diverticulum is complicated by a meso-diverticular band, which is believed to be a remnant of a vitelline artery. In such symptomatic cases, the treatment is diverticulectomy with the removal of associated bands connecting the diverticulum to the abdominal wall or intestinal mesentery.

Segmental resection of the ileum that includes both the diverticulum and the adjacent ileal peptic ulcer should be performed if

  •  There is bleeding from the diverticulum,
  •  The base is inflamed or perforated, and/or
  •  The diverticulum contains a tumor.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding varenicline?

choices.text: It is an antagonist at α4β2 receptor
It interacts with nicotinic ACh receptors
Its use is associated with mood and behavioral changes
It is useful in decreasing craving

questions.solution:
Varenicline is a partial agonist at the α4β2 receptor, not an antagonist.

Nicotine is the principal constituent of tobacco responsible for its addictive behavior. One of the newest agents introduced to aid in smoking cessation is varenicline.

Varenicline works by blocking the effects of nicotine on the brain. It blocks α-4, β-2 nicotinic acetylcholine receptor subtypes.

It inhibits dopaminergic activation produced by smoking through its partial agonism and decreases the craving and withdrawal syndrome that occurs with cessation attempts. It prevents nicotine stimulation of the mesolimbic dopamine system associated with nicotine addiction, thus helping to occlude the "rewarding" effect of smoking.

Varenicline is prescribed only to patients 18 years or older. Varenicline is taken orally at a starting dose of 0.5 mg once daily on days 1 to 3, which is increased to 0.5 mg twice daily on days 4 through 7, followed by 1 mg twice daily after day 8 for 11 weeks. Therapy should start one week before the target quit date. It can be continued for another 12 weeks (1 mg BD) to maintain abstinence.

The adverse effects include nausea, which can be mitigated by starting at lower doses and gradually increasing the dose. Other symptoms include disturbed sleep, sleepwalking, agitation, drowsiness, and constipation; it may also increase the risk of pancreatitis. Varenicline has also been implicated in specific skin syndromes such as Stevens-Johnson syndrome, erythema multiforme, and photosensitivity. Varenicline can cause renal failure and kidney stones, and therefore, renal function must be monitored.

The FDA has issued a warning about mood and behavioral changes associated with its use, and there is some evidence of increased cardiovascular risk.

questions.text: A patient who is set to travel to a typhoid endemic region in 10 days seeks your advice on vaccination. What should you recommend?

choices.text: Either Vi Polysachharide vaccine or Ty21a Vaccine
Ask the patient to delay the travel plan, as both vaccines need at least 28 days for conferring protection

questions.solution:
Vi Polysaccharide vaccine should be recommended for this patient as it requires only one injectable dose and confers protection 7 days after the injection. 

Vi Polysaccharide vaccine is composed of purified Vi capsular polysaccharide from the Ty2 Typhi strain. The vaccine is administered subcutaneously or intramuscularly. It is licensed for use in ages >2 years. Revaccination is recommended every 3 years to maintain protection.

This vaccine can be co-administered with other vaccines relevant for international travelers, such as yellow fever and hepatitis A, as well as with vaccines of the routine childhood immunization programs.

Ty21a is a live-attenuated oral vaccine for individuals ≥5 years of age. The regimen is 1st, 3rd, and 5th day - 3 doses. Here, protective immunity is achieved 7 days after the last dose (i.e. 5+7 = 12th Day).

Repeat doses are recommended every 3 years for endemic areas, and every year for traveling individuals. Not recommended in:

  • Patients on antimitotic drugs and immunosuppressants
  • Acute febrile illness
  • Acute intestinal infestation
  • Congenital or acquired immunodeficiency

Ty21a vaccine can be administered in an HIV-positive asymptomatic patient as long as the CD4+ count is >200/ cubic mm. Proguanil and antibacterial drugs should be stopped from 3 days before to 3 days after the vaccine.  The vaccine is unlikely to be effective if it is administered at the time of ongoing diarrhea.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding Ewing's sarcoma?

choices.text: Histopathological examination would reveal Homer-Wright rosettes.
It has a slight female predominance.
Immunohistochemistry is positive for synaptophysin and mic-2.

questions.solution:
Ewing's sarcoma has a slight male preponderance.

Ewing's sarcoma is the 2nd most common bone sarcoma in children. The majority of the patients affected are usually <20 years of age. It has a slight male predominance. 

It commonly involves the diaphysis of the long bones, like the femur, tibia, fibula, and humerus, and flat bones of the pelvis. The majority of Ewing's sarcomas have a balanced translocation between the EWSR1 gene on chromosome 22 and the FLI1 gene on chromosome 11. 

Patients present with painful enlarging mass, fever, and anemia. The affected area is usually tender, swollen, and warm. Laboratory findings may show an elevated WBC count and erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR). 

A histopathological examination of Ewing's sarcoma shows sheets of uniform, round cells arranged in Homer-Wright rosettes. These cells are of neuroectodermal origin and have minimal cytoplasm and abundant glycogen. When they are arranged around a central fibrillary core in the form of clusters, the appearance is termed Homer-Wright rosettes. Immunohistochemistry is usually positive for synaptophysin and mic-2.

Given below is the histopathological appearance of Ewing's sarcoma. 

The tumor cells stain positive for periodic acid–Schiff (PAS) stain, as they are rich in glycogen, but they stain negatively for reticulin.

The image given below shows PAS staining done in Ewing's sarcoma:

Radiological examination of Ewing's sarcoma shows a destructive lesion in the diaphysis of long bones. Deposition of periosteal reaction in layers gives an onion-peel appearance (shown below).

questions.text:
All of the following are new components that have been added to the MELD 3.0 scoring system except

MELD- Model for end-stage liver disease

choices.text: An upper bound for creatinine at 3.0 mg/dL.

questions.solution:
Serum bilirubin as a variable was present even in the previously recommended MELDNa scoring system.

The Model for End-Stage Liver Disease (MELD) is used as an indicator of short-term survival in patients with end-stage liver disease, and to determine organ allocation priorities for liver transplantation. According to the previous model, MELDNa, the components of the scoring system were:

  • Serum creatinine
  • Serum bilirubin
  • Serum sodium, and
  • INR (international normalized ratio)

The updated MELD 3.0 scoring system has made the following major changes: 

  • Additional variables of female sex and serum albumin,
  • Interactions between bilirubin and sodium and between albumin and creatinine, and
  • An upper bound for creatinine at 3.0 mg/dL

The addition of these two components and certain adjustments made in the other components has led to a better scoring system. MELD 3.0 allows for a more accurate prediction of mortality than the previous MELDNa scoring system. An important improvement is that it addresses factors that can affect wait-list outcomes such as sex disparity. MELD 3.0 is able to correctly reclassify almost 9% of patients to a higher MELD tier, giving them a much better chance of transplantation, particularly in women. 

It is estimated that almost 20 waitlist deaths can be reduced per year with the new MELD 3.0 scoring system.

Related Pearl: Revised Model for End-stage liver disease (MELD) scoring system: MELD 3.0

MELD 3.0 score has the following components (Mnemonic F BASIC)

  • Female sex
  • Bilirubin
  • Albumin
  • Serum sodium (mEq/L)
  • INR (International Normalized ratio)
  • Creatinine

Uses:

  • Predict short-term prognosis in patients undergoing transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS) insertion
  • Assess and prioritize patients awaiting liver transplantation
  • Assess prognosis in cirrhosis

questions.text: Artificial insemination is least likely to be useful in _______.

choices.text: Antispermal antibodies in the cervical mucus

questions.solution:
Among the given options, artificial insemination is least likely to be useful in non-obstructive azoospermia.

 

Related Pearl: Indications for various procedures in Infertility treatment

Indications of artificial insemination with husband's semen:

  • Chronic medical disorder
  • Oligospermia after sperm washout
  • Impotency or ejaculatory failure
  • Premature ejaculation, retrograde ejaculation
  • Hypospadias
  • Antisperm antibodies in the cervical mucus
  • Unexplained infertility
  • Frozen sperm: If the husband needs to undergo radiotherapy or chemotherapy or is not available at the time of ovulation
  • X–Y fractionation of sperms for sex selection, in a genetic and chromosomal abnormality
  • HIV positive male or female

Indications for Intra-cytoplasmic sperm injection (ICSI) and gamete intra-fallopian transfer (GIFT):

  • Sperm count of less than 5 million/mL
  • Absent or reduced sperm motility
  • Abnormal sperm morphology
  • Previous failed IVF
  • Unexplained infertility
  • Failure to penetrate zona by sperm as seen in IVF

Related Pearl: Causes of Male Infertility

Pre-testicular causes:

Endocrine cause

  • Gonadotropin deficiency
  • Thyroid dysfunction
  • Hyperprolactinemia

Psychosexual

  • Impotence
  • Erectile dysfunction

Drugs

  • Antihypertensives
  • Antipsychotics

Genetics

  • 47XXY
  • Y chromosome deletions

Testicular causes:

  • Immotile cilia syndrome
  • Cryptorchidism
  • Orchitis (mumps, Tb, gonorrhoea, traumatic)
  • Toxins(Drugs,radiation)
  • Primary testicular failure
  • Sertoli cell-only syndrome
  • Oligoasthenoteratozoospermia

Post-testicular causes:

Obstruction of efferent duct 

Congenital

  • Absence of Vas deferens
  • Youngs syndrome

Acquired (Inflammatory block)

  • Tuberculosis
  • Gonorrhea

Surgical

  • Vasectomy

Others

  • Ejaculatory failure
  • Bladder neck surgery
  • Retrograde ejaculation

questions.text: Which of the following statements about sugammadex is false?

choices.text: Sugammadex is a reversal agent for rocuronium and vecuronium.
Sugammadex does not reverses the effect of succinylcholine.
It is safe for use in patients with renal impairment
Side effects include dysgeusia and rarely hypersensitivity

questions.solution:
Sugammadex is essentially eliminated unchanged via the kidneys. It is not recommended for use in patients who have severe renal impairment. 

Sugammadex is a reversal agent for rocuronium and vecuronium. Sugammadex is a cyclodextrin. It is the first selective relaxant binding agent. It exerts its reversal effect by forming tight complexes in a 1:1 ratio with steroidal non-depolarizing agents (rocuronium > vecuronium >> pancuronium). Since rocuronium is a steroidal agent, it is specifically bound by sugammadex.

Sugammadex binds to plasma rocuronium and thus decreases the plasma concentration of rocuronium. This forms a concentration gradient of rocuronium due to which it moves from the neuromuscular junction back into the circulation where it is quickly bound by free sugammadex. 

Sugammadex is essentially eliminated unchanged via the kidneys. It is not recommended to be used in patients who have severe renal impairment. Side effects include dysgeusia and, rarely, hypersensitivity.

questions.text: A 21-year-old student presents with ocular redness, foreign body sensation, and excessive tearing, following the use of a contact lens. An interface contrast microscopy from his corneal scraping is shown below. Which of the following is false regarding the treatment of this condition?

choices.text: Topical steroid therapy should be started immediately to prevent scarring
Debridement of epithelium is done to help penetration of eye drops
Topical polyhexamethylene biguanide (PHMB) and chlorhexidine are used
Oral NSAIDs can be administered for pain management

questions.solution:
The given clinical history of redness, watering and foreign body sensation in a contact lens wearer along with the demonstration of polygonal cysts in interface contrast microscopy are suggestive of amoebic keratitis caused by acanthamoeba. Topical steroids should be avoided if possible.

If there is persistent inflammation even after 2 weeks after starting anti-amoebic treatment, low-dose steroid therapy may be useful. But, it is important to note that amoebicidal treatment should be continued in simultaneously with and for several weeks after steroids.

Acanthamoeba is an opportunistic protozoan pathogen. It exists as a trophozoite form and resistant cystic form. Both these forms are infective. The trophozoite is large and characterized by spine-like pseudopodia called acanthopodia.

Human beings acquire the infection by inhalation of cysts or trophozoites, directly through traumatized skin or eyes, or ingestion of cysts.

It chiefly presents as two chronic conditions:

  • Acanthamoeba keratitis
  • Granulomatous amoebic encephalitis

Acanthamoeba keratitis is an infection of the eyes that typically develops from the entry of the amebic cyst through abrasions on the cornea. Most of the cases are associated with the use of contact lenses. 

Patients usually present with photophobia, excessive tearing, redness, and foreign body sensation and it can be bilateral in contact lens users.

Diagnosis of amoebic keratitis is made by the demonstration of the cyst in corneal scrapings by wet mount, histology, and culture. The cysts are smaller (12–25 micrometer) and polygonal or star-shaped.

Management:

  • Debridement of the involved epithelium may facilitate eye drop penetration.
  • Administer topical biguanides or chlorhexidine, with or without diamidine agents.
  • Oral NSAIDs can be used for pain management
  • In severe cases, penetrating keratoplasty can be done.

The below image shows the ring lesion seen in acanthamoeba keratitis.

Related Pearl: Clinical differential diagnosis of corneal ulcer

  Bacterial Fungal Viral Parasitic

Contact lens wear

Trauma

Chronic steroid use

Anesthetic cornea

Dry eyes

Exposure keratopathy

Low immunity

Recurrent attacks

Contact lens wear

Exposure to contaminated water (acanthamoeba)

 
Clinical features

Hypopyon is fluid and mobile

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is likely to have a rapid course, with deep corneal necrosis.

Less pain and watering compared to the extent of vision loss and signs. 

Tend to be indolent but progressive

Hypopyon is thick, immobile.

Relatively more pain and watering compared to the extent of vision loss and signs. 

Recurrences are characteristic.

Disproportionately severe pain is a characteristic feature.

Indolent course and in initial stages, often mistaken to be viral/ fungal infection, leading to a delay in diagnosis

questions.text: While prescribing which of the following antidiabetic drugs should you warn the patient about the risk of weight gain?
questions.solution:
While prescribing the antidiabetic drug glyburide, a sulfonylurea, the doctor should warn the patient about the risk of weight gain.

By inhibiting the activity of a specific location on the β cell K ATP channel complex in the cell, sulfonylureas promote the release of insulin. Inhibiting KATP channels results in cell membrane depolarization and the series of events that trigger the production of insulin.

First-generation sulfonylureas: tolbutamide, tolazamide, and chlorpropamide (rarely used now in the treatment of diabetes) 

Second-generation sulfonylureas: glyburide (glibenclamide), glipizide, and glimepiride

Important side effects are hypoglycemia and weight gain. They can induce a disulfiram-like reaction.

Other options:

Option A: Metformin is considered weight neutral. Other advantages of this drug are that it does not cause hypoglycemia and is inexpensive. Side effects may include diarrhea, nausea, and lactic acidosis. Prolonged use leads to vitamin B12 deficiency.

Option B: Empagliflozin is an SGLT-2 inhibitor and is known to cause mild weight loss. It also causes blood pressure reduction and does not cause hypoglycemia. They increase the risk of urinary tract infections and can increase the risk of fractures.

Option C: Pramlintide is an amylin agonist. It reduces postprandial glycemia and leads to weight loss.

questions.text: Which of the following is a cause of exudative pleural effusion?
questions.solution:
Dressler syndrome causes exudative pleural effusion.

Transudative Pleural Effusion Exudative Pleural Effusion
Alteration in systemic factors that influence the formation and absorption of pleural fluid. Alteration in local factors that influence the formation and absorption of pleural fluid.
Causes include congestive cardiac failure, cirrhosis, nephrotic syndrome, peritoneal dialysis, SVC obstruction, myxedema. Causes include neoplastic conditions like mesothelioma; infectious diseases like tuberculosis; pulmonary embolization; GI conditions like esophageal perforation, pancreatic diseases; collagen vascular diseases like SLE; asbestosis, sarcoidosis; drug-induced; hemothorax and chylothorax, etc.

Related Pearl: Types of pleural effusion

Transudative Pleural effusion

  • Congestive heart failure (most common)
  • Cirrhosis
  • Nephrotic syndrome
  • Myxedema 
  • Peritoneal dialysis
  • Urinothorax
  • Hypoalbuminemia
  • Constrictive pericarditis
  • Superior vena cava obstruction

Exudative Pleural effusion 

  • Infections: Tuberculosis, pneumonia, intraabdominal abscess (like- liver abscess)
  • Malignancy: Pleural mesothelioma, metastasis, lymphoma
  • Connective tissue diseases: SLE, rheumatoid arthritis
  • Drugs: Amiodarone, bromocriptine, dantrolene, dasatinib, methysergide, nitrofurantoin
  • Others:
    • Pancreatitis
    • Asbestosis
    • Pulmonary embolism
    • Hemothorax
    • Chylothorax
    • Meigs' syndrome 
    • Dressler syndrome (post-myocardial infarction or cardiac surgery)
    • Yellow nail syndrome 

Related Pearl: Causes of predominantly unilateral pleural effusion

Predominantly right-sided pleural effusion

questions.text: Which of the following investigations is considered the gold standard for diagnosing sphincter of Oddi dysfunction?
questions.solution:
The gold standard for diagnosing sphincter of Oddi dyskinesia or dysfunction (SOD) is ERCP with manometry of the biliary and pancreatic sphincters.

SOD is a clinical syndrome in which pain, biochemical abnormalities, and the dilatation of the bile duct and/or pancreatic duct are attributed to abnormal function of the sphincter of Oddi.  It may be a result of stenosis of the sphincter or dysfunction of the sphincter. There are two clinical types of SOD:

  • Biliary SOD: characterized by a mix of biliary pain, abnormally raised liver enzymes, dilation of the bile duct & evidence of delayed emptying on biliary scintigraphy. It may be a cause of persistent post-cholecystectomy symptoms.
  • Pancreatic SOD: characterized by recurrent episodes of acute pancreatitis

HIDA scan may be used to demonstrate delayed biliary transit.

But, the gold standard for diagnosing SOD is ERCP, with manometry of the biliary and pancreatic sphincters.

questions.text:
Match the following drugs-receptor combination with their respective graphical representations.
  1. Salbutamol at beta-2 receptor
  2. Naloxone at opioid receptors
  3. Buprenorphine at opioid receptor
  4. β-Carboline at benzodiazepine site of GABA-A receptor
questions.solution:
The correctly matched pairs are as follows:

  • Salbutamol at beta-2 receptor - Graph 1
  • Naloxone at opioid receptors - Graph 3 
  • Buprenorphine at opioid receptor - Graph 2
  • β-Carboline at benzodiazepine site of GABA-A receptor - Graph 4

 

Graph 1 represents the agonist: An agonist is an agent which initiates the normal physiological response when combined with a receptor.
Example: Salbutamol is a beta-2 receptor agonist.
 
Graph 2 represents a partial agonist: An agent which produces a submaximal or partial effect when combined with a receptor.
Example: Buprenorphine and butorphanol are partial agonists at opioid receptors.
 
Graph 3 represents the competitive antagonist: An agent which blocks or reduces the action of an agonist on a receptor, but does not have any effect of its own.
Example: Naltrexone and naloxone are antagonists at opioid receptors
 
Graph 4 represents an inverse agonist: An agent which activates a receptor to produce an effect in the opposite direction to that of the agonist.
Example: β-Carboline is an inverse agonist at benzodiazepine site of GABA-A receptor.

questions.text: A patient recovered from hepatitis B infection. Which of the following curve represents antibodies seen 4 weeks post-recovery?
questions.solution:
The serological marker marked in the image is anti-HBs antibody. In typical cases of resolving hepatitis B, HBsAg becomes undetectable 1-2 months after the appearance of clinical features. After this, anti-HBs becomes detectable in the serum.

After a person is infected with the hepatitis B virus (HBV), the first serologic marker to increase in level is HBsAg. It becomes detectable in the serum between 1-12 weeks. It becomes undetectable 1–2 months after the onset of jaundice and rarely persists beyond 6 months. Once the HBsAg becomes undetectable, anti-HBs antibody starts rising in serum and remains detectable indefinitely thereafter. The gap between the disappearance of HBsAg and the appearance of anti-HBs antibodies is called the window period. 

HBcAg is located inside the cells and is usually enclosed within an HBsAg coat when present in the serum. As a result, HBcAg is not commonly detectable in the serum of patients with HBV infection since naked core particles are not found in the bloodstream. Conversely, anti-HBc can be detected in the serum shortly after the emergence of HBsAg, usually within 1-2 weeks. Anti-HBc may be the only serologic marker useful for the identification of HBV infection during the window period. 

HBeAg appears shortly after the appearance of HBsAg. Its appearance correlates with high levels of virus replication. Anti-HBe correlates with a period of lower infectivity.

questions.text: A 30-year-old athlete injures his leg. He complains of pain in his knees. The following technique has been employed to alleviate his pain. Activation of which of the following types of nerve fibers near the site of injury is done by this method?
questions.solution:
The given image shows transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS) used for pain relief. It is based on the gate control theory of pain. This method uses electrodes to activate Aα and Aβ fibers near the injury to relieve pain.

Gate control theory is based on the inhibition of the pain pathways in the spinal cord. Various sensory inputs from a particular dermatome reach the dorsal horn of the spinal cord. The pain is transmitted via A-delta and C fibers, whereas, A-beta fibers carry tactile sensations (touch, pressure) and A-alpha fibers carry proprioception.

When these large-diameter A-beta/A-alpha fibers are stimulated, they inhibit the pain pathway in the spinal cord. This inhibition is thought to result from the local lateral inhibition of interneurons in the spinal cord.

Gate control theory operates at the substantia gelatinosa of the dorsal horn of the spinal cord.

The given image depicts the gate control theory of pain:

questions.text: Which of the following adverse effects is not encountered with the use of the agent that is considered the specific reversal agent for dabigatran?
questions.solution:
Idarucizumab is considered the specific reversal agent for dabigatran. It is associated with hypokalemia, not hyperkalemia.

Idarucizumab is a humanized monoclonal antibody fragment and is indicated in patients treated with dabigatran when reversal of anticoagulant effects is needed:

  • For emergency surgery/urgent procedures
  • In life-threatening or uncontrolled bleeding

The most frequently reported adverse reactions are:

  • Hypokalemia
  • Delirium
  • Constipation
  • Pyrexia
  • Pneumonia

Specific reversal agents for anticoagulants:

  • Heparin: protamine sulfate
  • Warfarin: vitamin K
  • Rivaroxaban and other oral Xa inhibitors: andexanet alfa
  • Dabigatran: idarucizumab

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding auramine-rhodamine staining used for acid-fast bacillus?

choices.text: After staining with auromine-rhodamine stain, bacilli resist decolorisation with sulphuric acid
Smears stained with auramine-rhodamine should not be exposed to ultraviolet illumination
Bacilli appear as bright rods against a dark background
Bacilli can be seen even under the high dry objective and hence this can be used for rapid smear screening

questions.solution:
Smears stained with auramine-rhodamine are visualized under ultraviolet light illumination to spot the fluorescent bacilli.

After staining with auromine-rhodamine stain, acid-fast bacilli resist decolorization with sulphuric acid. Smears that are stained with auramine-rhodamine fluorescent dyes are examined under ultraviolet illumination or a LED light source. Bacilli appear as bright rods against a dark background. 

Due to the clear contrast, the bacilli can be seen even under the high-dry objective, which helps to screen large areas of the smear rapidly. When large numbers of smears is to be examined daily, it is more convenient to use fluorescent microscopy.

Related Pearl: Various stains and their applications in microbiology

A. Simple stains: Provides color contrast but gives same color to all bacteria and cells.

Type of stain Applications
Acidic stains

These include eosin, acid fuchsin, rose bengal, congo red, etc.

Used to stain pathological specimens
Basic stains.

Loeffler’s methylene blue stain is used in Quellung reaction. 

Polychrome methylene blue is used in McFadyean’s reaction.
Neutral stains

Wright and Giemsa stains are Romanowsky stains used to stain peripheral blood and bone marrow smears.  

Giemsa stain is used for histopathological diagnosis of malaria and other protozoan blood parasites.  

 

B. Differential stains: Imparts different colors to different bacteria. (These contain more than one stain).

Type of stain Applications
Gram stain: To differentiate between gram positive (stain purple/violet) and gram negative bacteria (stain pink or red).
Acid-fast stain:  Used in Ziehl–Neelsen staining technique for identification of acid–fast microorganisms such as M. tuberculosis, M. leprae, and Nocardia.
Fluorochrome staining: Auramine-rhodamine is used in fluorochrome staining for screening for tuberculosis.

C. Special stains:

Type of stain Applications

questions.text: Which of the following media can be used for culturing the organism shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
The given image shows gram-positive rods with club-shaped ends, a beaded appearance, and a chinese-letter pattern of arrangement indicative of Corynebacterium diphtheriae. They are cultured in MacLeod's medium.

Macleod's medium is selective for C. diphtheriae. Potassium tellurite in McLeod's medium or potassium tellurite agar is reduced to metallic tellurium by C. diphtheriae to produce black colonies. Additionally, tellurite (0.04%) inhibits the growth of most other bacteria, acting as a selective agent.

Other options:

Option A: Wilson and Blair's medium is selective for Salmonella species. It is a type of selective and indicator media. Salmonella typhi reduces sulphite to sulphide in the presence of glucose and produces jet-black colonies with a metallic sheen due to the production of H2S on Wilson and Blair bismuth sulphite medium. It is also a differential media. While S. typhi forms large black colonies, with a metallic sheen S. paratyphi. A produces green colonies due to the absence of H2S production. 

Option B: BCYE agar or buffered charcoal, yeast extract agar is selective for Legionella species. Legionellae are nutritionally fastidious. Their growth is enhanced with iron salts and depends on the supplementation of media L-cysteine. 

Option D: Skirrow’s medium is selective for Campylobacter species. It contains vancomycin, polymyxin B, and trimethoprim to inhibit the growth of other bacteria. Plates were incubated at 43°C with 5 % oxygen, 10% carbon dioxide, and 85% hydrogen. Colonies may be observed after overnight incubation.

questions.text:
Which of the following tests would be helpful in determining whether a particular stain is due to seminal fluid?
  1. Creatine phosphokinase test
  2. Kastle Meyer test
  3. Barberio test
  4. Acid phosphatase test
  5. Takayama test
questions.solution:
The acid phosphatase test, Barberio test, and creatine phosphokinase test are used to detect seminal stains, hence option D is correct. 

Kastle-Meyer test & Takayama test are used to detect blood stains (not seminal stains).

Forensic tests for detection of seminal stains:

  • Florence test detects choline (secreted by seminal vesicles). Florence solution consists of potassium iodide, iodine, and water. If semen is present, dark-brown crystals of choline iodide is seen
  • Barberio’s test detects spermin (secreted by the prostate) and uses an aqueous or alcoholic solution of picric acid. Yellow needle-shaped rhombic crystals of spermine picrate in the presence of seminal fluid.
  • Acid phosphatase test is conclusive in case of absence of demonstrable sperms or Aspermia.
  • The absolute proof of semen is finding at least one unbroken spermatozoon or electrophoretic LDH isoenzyme detection of sperms.

 

 

Related Pearl: Tests to detect seminal and blood stains

Tests for seminal stains

  • Barberio's test
  • Florence test
  • Acid phosphatase test
  • Creatine phosphokinase test
  • Immunological test to detect Prostate Specific Antigen

Tests for blood stains  

  • Benzidine test
  • Phenophthalein (Kastle Meyer) test
  • Takayama hemochromogen crystal test
  • Teichmann’s hemin crystal test
  • Spectroscopic test

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrectly paired??
questions.solution:
In the given image, the orange curve represents the gamma-globin chain production. The gamma-globin chain is produced in the fetal period and drops to undetectable levels 6 months postpartum, which is the pattern represented by the orange curve. The alpha chain production is represented by the red curve.

Hemoglobin in blood has different variants throughout life, in different proportions. The type of hemoglobin essentially depends on the combination of globin chains. Adult hemoglobin is made of 2 alpha and 2 beta chains, whereas fetal hemoglobin is made of 2 alpha and 2 gamma-globin chains. Other combinations of chains can be found in embryonic hemoglobin.

Here,

  • Gamma chain - Orange curve
  • Alpha chain - Red curve
  • Beta chain - Green curve
  • Epsilon chain - Black curve
  • Delta chain - Blue curve

questions.text:
Which of the following conditions show a secular trend?
  1. Coronary heart disease
  2. Polio
  3. Lung cancer
  4. Diabetes
  5. Influenza
  6. Measles
questions.solution:
Coronary heart disease, Polio, Lung cancer & Diabetes show a secular trend. Measles shows a seasonal trend and influenza shows a cyclic trend.

Secular trend describes the occurrence of disease over a prolonged period, usually years. Even though it may have short-term fluctuations, there is a tendency for the disease occurrence to change consistently in a particular direction or a definite movement in one direction.

Examples of the secular trend include coronary heart disease, lung cancer, and diabetes, which have shown a consistent upward trend in incidence as well as prevalence, in developed countries. Similarly, there has been a consistent decline in the diseases such as tuberculosis, typhoid fever, diphtheria, and polio.

Seasonal trends reflect seasonal changes in disease occurrence following changes in environmental conditions that enhance the ability of the agent to replicate or be transmitted. For example, measles (usually occurs in early spring), varicella, etc. Non-infectious conditions like hay fever and snake bites may also show seasonal variations.

Cyclic trend is shown by some diseases that occur in cycles spread over short periods of time which may be, days, weeks, months, or years.  Examples include the influenza pandemic, which is known to occur at intervals of every 7–10 years due to antigenic variations.

questions.text: A diabetic man takes his insulin bolus and then takes his meal. This would cause activation of all of the following enzymes, except _____.
questions.solution:
Phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase is an enzyme that gets activated in low insulin situations, in a phosphorylated state, i.e., in a fasting state.

It is active in the high glucagon:insulin ratio scenario, which is typically seen in the fasting state and participates in the process of gluconeogenesis.

All other enzymes are active in the fed state when there are high insulin levels.

questions.text: The oxygen flow rate of a non-rebreather mask is
questions.solution:
The oxygen flow rate of a non-rebreather mask is 7-15 L/min

 

Conventional oxygen therapy includes all the devices that are used in routine practices. It includes nasal prongs, low-flow nasal cannula, or masks. It is the main supportive treatment administered to patients after planned extubation. 

Oxygen delivery devices Flow rate (liter/min)  Approximate FiO2
Nasal cannula  1-6  0.24-0.44 
Simple face mask  6-10 0.40-0.60
Non-rebreathing mask 10-15 0.90-1.00 
Venturi mask  2-15  0.24-0.60

Oxygen delivery devices can be broadly divided into low flow oxygen devices (eg: nasal cannula, simple face mask, non-rebreathing mask) and high flow oxygen devices (eg: venturi mask).

 

The below image shows a nasal cannula, which delivers oxygen at 1-6 L/min.

A conventional oxygen mask is a simple face mask that is used routinely in hospitals. It covers the nose and mouth of the patient. There are 2 exhalation ports through which the patient exhales carbon dioxide. This mask is held in place with elastic around the back of the head and a metal piece that fits over the nose. It provides 40% to 60% of O2 concentration and delivers O2 at the rate of 6 to 10 L/min.

The below image shows a venturi mask, which delivers oxygen at 2-15 L/min.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs should never be prescribed to a pregnant woman with SLE?
questions.solution:
Mycophenolate mofetil is teratogenic and hence is not safe during pregnancy. 

Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is a chronic autoimmune disorder involving the multisystem. It affects young women of childbearing age. The renal involvement of the disease can manifest in the form of active lupus nephritis or flare-ups during pregnancy.

The features include fever, weight loss, migratory joint pain, and myalgias. It can lead to preterm births, preeclampsia, and pregnancy loss while the infant can suffer from neonatal lupus and heart block. 

Antinuclear antibodies are useful to screen the disease. Double-stranded DNA (dsDNA) is highly specific in diagnosing SLE. Other antibodies such as lupus anticoagulant, antiphospholipid antibodies, anti-Ro, and anti-La antibodies are useful in diagnosis.

Management is as follows:

  • Preconceptional planning plays an important role. Conception during a period of quiescence for at least 6 months determines a successful outcome. Stable remission of renal disease for at least 6 months before conception is recommended.
  • Corticosteroids are useful during episodes of lupus flare and can be used safely in pregnancy. For patients on chronic corticosteroid therapy, intravenous hydrocortisone 100 mg, three doses are given 8 hourly during labor or at the time of cesarean delivery.
  • Immunosuppressants such as azathioprine can be continued during pregnancy. It may be used in case of severe SLE
  • Hydroxychloroquine is found to be the best for maintenance and is safe in pregnancy. It can prevent the need for prolonged corticosteroid therapy.

 

Drugs for treatment of pregnant women with SLE

  • Recommended during pregnancy
    • HCQ (Hydroxychloroquine)
    • Low dose Aspirin
  • Selective use allowed during pregnancy
    • NSAIDs
    • Glucocorticoids
    • Azathioprine
    • Cyclosporine
    • Tacrolimus
  • Selective use with caution in pregnancy
    • Rituximab
    • Belimumab
  • Contraindicated in pregnancy
    • Cyclophosphamide
    • Mycophenolate mofetil
    • Methotrexate
    • Leflunomide

Related Pearl: Classification of Lupus Nephritis (International Society of Nephrology and Renal Pathology Society)

Class 

Findings

Minimal mesangial lupus nephritis (class I)

Immune complex deposition in the mesangium without structural changes by light microscopy.

Mesangial proliferative lupus nephritis (class II)

Mesangial cell proliferation with mesangial immune deposits

Focal lupus nephritis (class III)

Focal, segmental glomerulonephritis involving less than 50% of all glomeruli.

Focal subendothelial deposits with or without mesangial changes

Diffuse lupus nephritis (class IV)

The most common and severe form of lupus nephritis

Diffuse glomerulonephritis involving more than 50% of all glomeruli

Diffuse subendothelial deposits with or without mesangial changes. “Wire loop” structures on light microscopy.

Membranous lupus nephritis (class V)

Global or segmental subepithelial immune deposits with or without mesangial proliferation

Advanced sclerosing lupus nephritis (class VI)

Sclerosis of more than 90% of the glomeruli 
  • Focal- Involves only a few glomeruli
  • Diffuse- Involves almost all the glomeruli
  • Segmental- Involves only a part of glomerulus
  • Global- Involves entire glomerulus

questions.text: For a given drug, animal reproduction studies have shown an adverse effect on the fetus, but there are no adequate and well-controlled studies on humans. However, potential benefits may warrant the use of the drug in pregnant women despite potential risks. Such a drug would be classified as _____.
questions.solution:
For a given drug, animal reproduction studies have shown an adverse effect on the fetus, but there are no adequate and well-controlled studies on humans. However, potential benefits may warrant the use of the drug in pregnant women despite potential risks. Such a drug would be classified as Category C.

 

The united states food and drug administration (FDA) system for teratogenic potential attempts to quantify teratogenic risk from category A (safe) to category X (definite human teratogenic risk).

Category A: The possibility of fetal harm is remote and studies on women have failed to demonstrate any evidence of risk to the fetus. Examples: doxylamine, folic acid, levothyroxine.

Category B: Either animal-reproduction studies have not demonstrated a fetal risk, but there are no controlled studies in pregnant women, or animal-reproduction studies have shown an adverse effect that was not confirmed in controlled studies in pregnant women. Example: Amoxicillin, loratadine, ondansetron.

Category C: Either studies in animals have revealed adverse effects on the fetus, that is, teratogenic or embryocidal, but there are no controlled studies in women, or studies in women and animals are not available. These drugs should be given only if the potential benefit justifies the potential risk to the fetus. Example: fluconazole, metoprolol, sertraline.

Category D: Though there is evidence of human fetal risk, the benefits from use in pregnant women may be acceptable despite the risk, for example, if the drug is needed in a life-threatening situation or for a disease for which safer drugs cannot be used or are ineffective. Example: lisinopril, lithium, phenytoin.

Category X: There is evidence of fetal risk based on human or animal experience and the risk of the use of the drug in pregnant women clearly outweighs any possible benefit. The drug is contraindicated in women who are or may become pregnant. Example: methotrexate, simvastatin, warfarin.

3. Giant cell tumor c. Radiofrequency ablation 
4. Osteoid osteoma  d. Intralesional steroid
questions.solution:
Option C is the correct answer. The given lesions and the correctly matched best modes of management are as follows:

Bone tumor Management

1. Osteosarcoma

 a. Wide excision
2. Simple bone cyst d. Intralesional steroid 
3. Giant cell tumor b. Curettage
4. Osteoid osteoma c. Radiofrequency ablation 

Osteosarcoma: It is a high-grade medullary osteoid-producing tumor. Osteosarcoma is the most common primary malignant tumor of the bone. The preferred method of treatment of osteosarcoma is wide resection and reconstruction. This is mainly owing to the possibility of limb salvage, and amputation is considered only when tumor-safe surgical margins are compromised.

Multi-agent neoadjuvant chemotherapy with agents like doxorubicin, cisplatin, ifosfamide, and methotrexate is started immediately after diagnosis for 8-12 weeks. The tumor is then re-staged followed by wide resection and limb reconstruction. 

Radiographic findings: The periosteal reaction is the typical finding and it may take the form of a Codman's triangle or it may have a sunburst (sunray) appearance on X-ray. It is shown in the image below.

Simple bone cyst: These are cystic bone cavities that are often solitary and unilocular filled with serous or serosanguinous material. The lesions usually regress with bone maturity. In cases where the lesions are active, injection of steroids is done. Only when there is a high risk of fracture, curettage, or fixation and stabilization may be required. 

It is seen as a well-outlined lytic centrally placed lesion with cortical thinning on X-ray. When there is a fracture, a small fragment may be visualized within the cavity, known as the fallen leaf sign. The image below shows a bone cyst in the humerus along with a pathological fracture and fallen leaf sign 

Giant cell tumor: It is a benign, locally aggressive tumor of the bone due to the proliferation of mononuclear cells with scattered macrophages. They are noticed mostly when there is cortical erosion with or without soft tissue compromise (stages 2 or 3). 

In stages 1 and 2, intralesional curettage with debridement of the lesional wall is effective. Stage 3 of the disease can be treated through curettage but some cases require en-bloc resection. Antibodies like denosumab (anti-RANKL) have been effective in controlling osteoclastic activity. 

Radiographic findings: 

  • Eccentrically located solitary lytic lesion in the metaphyses
  • Soap bubble appearance
  • Periosteal new bone formation is absent.

Below image shows Soap bubble appearance seen in giant cell tumor.

Osteoid osteoma: It is a benign tumor formed of osteoid and woven bone surrounded by a halo of reactive bone. The preferred method of treatment in this condition is CT-guided radiofrequency ablation to eradicate the lesion and improve symptoms.

Radiography shows a sclerotic peripheral rim with central radiolucent nidus.
