questions.text: Which of the following post-mortem changes is a result of hydrolysis of lipids under warm and humid weather?
questions.solution:
Hydrolysis of lipids under warm and humid weather would result in adipocere formation, which is seen in image 4. 

Postmortem changes are classified on the basis of time:

  • Immediate signs of death (at the time of somatic or clinical death):
    1. Insensibility and loss of voluntary power
    2. Cessation of respiration
    3. Cessation of circulation
  • Early signs of death. It is seen in cellular death:
    1. Pallor and loss of elasticity of the skin
    2. Eye changes
    3. Primary flaccidity of muscles
    4. Algor mortis/Postmortem cooling
    5. Postmortem lividity/Suggillation
    6. Rigor mortis
  • Late signs of death:
    1. Putrefaction
    2. Adipocere
    3. Mummification

Adipocere formation (Image 4) is a late sign of death. The transformation is brought about by the gradual hydrolysis and hydrogenation of pre-existing fats, including olein, into higher fatty acids. These higher fatty acids then join with calcium and ammonium ions to produce insoluble soaps, which since they are acidic, prevent putrefactive bacteria. The usual time for adipocere formation is between 3 to 6 months. Still, in countries like India, it is accelerated by the warm and humid weather, resulting in the beginning of adipocere formation as early as 4 to 5 days after death. 

Image 1. Marbling: It is seen when blood in the vessels is hemolyzed to sulfate-hemoglobin, which stains the vessel walls and the adjacent tissues, giving rise to a marbled appearance. The marbling of the skin begins at about 24 hours and becomes prominent  36–48 hours after death. It is a visible postmortem change that is characterized by linear branching patterns on skin that correspond to the course of superficial veins of the abdomen, shoulders, chest, and inguinal region.

Image 2. Cadaveric lividity: Postmortem hypostasis/Postmortem staining/Postmortem lividity/Livor mortis/Suggilation refers to bluish-purple or reddish-purple discoloration of the skin due to the collection of blood in most superficial layers of the dermis in the dependent parts of the body. Fixation of hypostasis occurs 6 – 12 hours after death and persists until putrefaction sets in.

Image 3. Mummification: It occurs in the absence of moisture in the air and continuous action of dry or warmed air. It is a process of dehydration or drying and shriveling of the cadaver that occurs from the evaporation of water. The natural appearances of the body and general facial features are preserved.

questions.text: Performing a myringoplasty would be contraindicated in all of the following, except:

choices.text: Presence of active discharge from middle ear

questions.solution:
Child of age <3 years (not 5 years) is a contraindication for performing myringoplasty.

Myringoplasty is the term given for the closure of perforation of pars tensa of tympanic membrane. It is done to check repeated infections from the external ear.

Contraindications for Myringoplasty:

  1. Active discharge from the middle ear.
  2. Uncontrolled nasal allergy.
  3. Otitis externa.
  4. Ingrowth of squamous epithelium into the middle ear. In such cases, excision of squamous epithelium from the middle ear or a tympanomastoidectomy may be required.
  5. When the other ear is dead or not suitable for hearing aid rehabilitation.
  6. Children below 3 years.

Myringoplasty techniques are based on the relation of the graft with lamina propria of tympanic membrane remnants and fibrous annulus.

In the underlay technique, the graft is placed medial to the annulus. Whereas, in the overlay technique, the graft is placed lateral to the annulus. The graft is medial to malleus in both techniques.

questions.text: A worried mother brings her 18-month-old son to OPD with complaints of repeated urinary tract infections. During diagnostic work-up, pelvic USG shows the following finding. What is the definitive management for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with the USG showing the key-hole sign suggests the presence of a posterior urethral valve (PUV). It is seen due to dilatation of the bladder and the proximal urethra. Transurethral ablation of leaflets is the definitive management for this condition.

The posterior urethral valves are membranes that have a small posterior slit, which lies just distal to the verumontanum. They function as flap valves and are obstructive to antegrade urinary flow.

The PUV is the most common congenital cause of bladder outlet obstruction in males. PUV is classified into three types based on Young's classification.

Diagnosis is made antenatally with ultrasound, which demonstrates bilateral hydronephrosis above a distended bladder. If the diagnosis is not made antenatally, then neonates typically present with urinary infection or uremia and renal failure. 

The investigation of choice for a posterior urethral valve is micturating cystourethrography (MCUG).

Initially, the obstruction is relieved by catheterization to preserve renal function. Definitive treatment is by urethroscopic destruction of the valves with lifelong supportive treatment. 

The following MCUG shows vesicoureteric reflux due to posterior urethral valves:

questions.text: Which of the following act via the Phospholipase C Second Messenger System?

choices.text: Angiotensin II on vascular smooth muscle and Vasopressin via V1 receptor on vascular smooth muscle
Angiotensin II on vascular smooth muscle and Vasopressin via V2 receptor on epithelial cells
Angiotensin II on epithelial cells and Vasopressin via V1 receptor on vascular smooth muscle
Angiotensin II on epithelial cells and Vasopressin via V2 receptor on epithelial cells

questions.solution:
Angiotensin II on vascular smooth muscle and Vasopressin via V1 receptor on vascular smooth muscle act via the Phospholipase C Second Messenger System.

Angiotensin II on epithelial cells and Vasopressin via V2 receptor on epithelial cells act via the Adenylyl Cyclase–cAMP Second Messenger System

3. While receptor tyrosine kinases have intrinsic tyrosine kinase activity, non-receptor tyrosine kinases have an external tyrosine kinase component that interacts with the receptor as and when required.

questions.text: Which of the following methods uses specialized RT-PCR  to amplify the ends of mRNA transcripts?
questions.solution:
Rapid Amplification of cDNA Ends PCR, or RACE-PCR, is used to amplify the ends of messenger RNA (mRNA) transcripts using a specialized reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction.

Polymerase chain reaction (PCR): PCR is a rapid automated method for the amplification of specific DNA sequences (or genes). 

Reverse transcriptase PCR: The enzyme reverse transcriptase (RT) is used to synthesize a complimentary copy of DNA (cDNA) from RNA, and this cDNA is then used as a template for PCR.

Using the known information from the center of the transcript, RACE-PCR allows the amplification of an unknown end portion of the transcript via a specialized reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR). RACE-PCR is also referred to as one-sided PCR or anchored PCR.

Other special PCR types:

Nested PCR: It involves the sequential use of two primer sets. The first primer set is used for amplification and the target sequence for the second primer is present only on the amplicon with the target sequence. Nested PCR is intended to reduce non-specific binding due to the amplification of unexpected primer binding sites.

 

 

Multiplex PCR: Multiple primers are used to amplify several DNA sequences simultaneously. As this process targets multiple genes at once, a single test run gives additional information that would otherwise require several times the reagents and technician time to perform. 

Droplet digital PCR (ddPCR): ddPCR is an advanced and more precise type of quantitative PCR, which gives more consistent and reproducible results. It can accurately quantify the target nucleic acid sequence within a sample. It is useful for determining somatic mutation with low allele frequency. Mutant alleles of frequency as low as 0.25% can also be detected using this technique.

questions.text: Identify the instrument given below.
questions.solution:
The instrument shown in the image is a proctoscope. 

A lubricated proctoscope to visualize lesions in the anus, anorectal junction, and lower rectum. Proctoscopy is done as an OPD procedure to detect hemorrhoids, polyps, or ulcers

Cusco’s speculum is a self-retaining bivalve speculum used for visualisation of the cervix, vaginal fornices and for performing pap smear.

Sims' speculum is used for the assessment of rectocele and cystocele. The speculum is applied against the vaginal wall and slowly retracted out until a bulge appears, indicating cystocele or rectocele.  It can also be used for visualization of the vaginal walls.

Doyen's retractor is used to retract the abdominal wall as well as the bladder to facilitate better exposure of the lower uterine segment during cesarian operation. It is also used to pull back the soft tissues to widen the surgical field during laparotomy.

The image below shows Doyen's retractor. 

Related Pearl: Instruments in OBG

questions.text: When should the screening for aggressive posterior retinopathy of prematurity be done for an infant born at 27 weeks of gestation?
questions.solution:
Screening for retinopathy of prematurity for an infant born at 27 weeks of gestation should be done at 3 weeks of postnatal age.

Usually the first screening examination for ROP should be carried out at 32 weeks Post Menstrual Age or 4 weeks Post Natal Age, whichever is later.

But, for infants less than 28 weeks, screening is done at 3 weeks PNA to detect APROP. Aggressive posterior ("rush" disease, AP-ROP) is uncommon, but if untreated, usually progresses to total retinal detachment (stage 5), sometimes within a few days. It is characterized by its posterior location, prominence of plus disease, and ill-defined nature of the retinopathy.

The critical phase during screening is 34 to 38 weeks, when the infant is likely to reach the threshold stage of the disease and may require treatment for the prevention of blindness.

 

Retinopathy of prematurity occurs in premature infants with low birth weight, with a typical history of exposure to oxygen in high concentrations leading to bilateral proliferative retinopathy. 

Stages of Retinopathy of Prematurity:

  • Stage 1- demarcation line formation at the edge of vessels, dividing the vascular from the avascular retina.
  • Stage 2- intraretinal ridge formation
  • Stage 3- ridge with extraretinal fibrovascular proliferation into the vitreous.
  • Stage 4- subtotal retinal detachment
  • Stage 5- total retinal detachment
  • 'Plus' disease is characterized by dilatation and tortuosity of blood vessels in at least two quadrants of the posterior fundus. It signifies the progression of the disease.

Location:

Zone I: Circular area with a radius twice the distance from disc to the fovea, with the disc as the center. (as shown in the image)
Zone II: It covers the area beyond zone I circumferentially till nasal ora serrata.
Zone III: It consists of residual temporal crescent anterior to zone II.

Treatment is based on guidelines set by the early treatment of retinopathy of prematurity trial (ETROP).

Type 1: Treatment within 72 hours (High risk)

  • Any ROP + plus disease
  • Stage 3 ROP in zone I
  • Stage 2/3 in zone II + plus disease.

Type 2: Observation (Low risk)

  • Stage 1/2 in zone I only and no plus disease
  • Stage 3 ROP within zone II and no plus disease.

This can be summarized in the table below:

    Stage 1   Stage 2   Stage 3
Zone I Observation Observation Treatment
Zone II - without plus disease   Observation  Observation
Zone II- with plus disease   Treatment Treatment

 

ROP of any stage in any zone, if associated with 'plus' disease, should receive treatment urgently.

Treatment includes laser ablation of the avascular peripheral retina, anti-VEGF medication (bevacizumab), and pars plana vitrectomy for advanced disease. The high-risk patients requiring treatment should receive it within 72 hours.

questions.text: As per the Drugs and Cosmetics Act, you would call a drug as misbranded in all of the following situations, except _____.

choices.text: If it is made to appear of better or greater therapeutic value than it really is
If its label or container or anything accompanying the drug bears any false claim for the drug
If it is not labelled in the prescribed manner
If it is imported under a name that belongs to another drug

questions.solution:
If a drug is imported under a name that belongs to another drug, it is considered a spurious drug.


As per the Drugs and Cosmetics Act, a drug shall be deemed to be misbranded if

  1. It is made to appear of better or greater therapeutic value than it really is
  2. It is not labeled in the prescribed manner
  3. Its label or container or anything accompanying the drug bears any false claim for the drug

 

As per the Drugs and Cosmetics Act, a drug shall be deemed to be spurious if

  1. It is imported under a name that belongs to another drug
  2. It imitates/ resembles another drug in a manner likely to deceive
  3. The manufacturer name is bogus (labeling a knock-off as a product of an established brand or manufacturing under a fake/non-existent identity)
  4. It has been substituted  by another drug or substance wholly or in part

Adulterated drugs include those drugs that contain filthy, or decomposed substances; substances that are injurious to health; or harmful substances that are added to reduce the quality or strength of the drug. It also includes drugs that were prepared in unsanitary conditions.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding ligature strangulation?

choices.text: Injury to muscles of the neck is commonly seen
Subcutaneous tissue underneath the ligature mark is usually hard, white, and glistening
Abrasions and  ecchymoses  are commonly present
Dribbling of saliva is very rarely seen in the victim

questions.solution:
Subcutaneous tissue underneath the ligature mark is usually hard, white, and glistening in cases of hanging, not ligature strangulation. In cases of ligature strangulation, the subcutaneous tissue appears ecchymosed.

Strangulation is a type of asphyxia where there is neck constriction without suspension of the body. The pressure on the neck is applied either by bare hands, a ligature or by any other instrument.

When strangulation is done by using a ligature, like a constricting band or rope, it is called ligature strangulation. The constricting band is tightened by a force other than the victim's body weight. It is characterized by the ligature mark which is transverse and completely encircling the neck below the thyroid cartilage. There is no dribbling of saliva. Bleeding may be present in the ears, nose, and mouth.

Ligature and manual strangulations are mostly homicidal. Marks of violence are usually seen on other parts of the body. 

Related Pearl: Difference between strangulation by Ligature and Hanging

ecchymoses

Less common

questions.text: Fibers of the fornix terminate at which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
Fibres of the fornix and its fibres terminate at the mamillary body. 

The fornix is a part of the connecting pathways of the limbic system. It arises from the hippocampus which wraps around the thalamus and ends in the mammillary body. It connects the hippocampus with distal brain sites. The fornix has two types of fibres:

  • Association fibres: They connect the various cortical regions within the same hemisphere 
  • Commissural fibres: They connect the corresponding regions of two hemispheres. It is seen in the hippocampal commissure of the fornix. 

The blood supply of fornix is by the anterior communicating artery which arises from the anterior cerebral artery. 

The limbic system is a group of structures seen between the cerebral cortex and the hypothalamus. It is involved in emotional and motivation activity, learning, and memory. 

Other options:

Option A: Amygdala is a part of the limbic system that consists of lateral, central and basal nuclei. It can Influence the body's response to enviromnental changes. In a fearful situation it can change the heart rate, blood pressure, respiratory rate etc. 

Option C: Caudate nucleus is a C-shaped mass of grey matter. It is divided into a head, body, and tail. Degeneration of the caudate nucleus is seen in Huntington's disease. 

Related Pearl: White matter tracts of the brain

Commissural fibers: connect corresponding regions of two hemispheres.

They include

  • Corpus callosum
  • Anterior and posterior commissure
  • Habenular commissure
  • Hippocampal commissure of fornix

Association fibers: connect various cortical regions within the same hemisphere.

They are classified as 

  • Short association fibers: lie immediately under the cortex and connect adjacent gyri. Eg- arcuate fasciculus
  • Long association fibers:
    • Uncinate fasciculus
    • Cingulum
    • Superior longitudinal fasciculus
    • Inferior longitudinal fasciculus
    • Fronto-occipital fasciculus
    • Fornix (except hippocampal commissure of fornix)

Projection fibers: fibers passing to and from the brainstem to the cerebral cortex. 

  • Internal capsule
  • Corona radiata

questions.text: A man presents with severe vomiting. Homicidal poisoning is suspected as the vomitus appears luminous and emits a garlicky odor. Which of the following is most likely to be the poisoning agent?
questions.solution:
Luminous vomitus that gives off a garlicky odor is highly suggestive of white/yellow phosphorous poisoning.

White/yellow phosphorous is a waxy and translucent material that becomes luminous in the dark. It has a garlicky odor and taste. It gets oxidized on exposure to air, emits white fumes, and gets ignited at 34°C. It is highly toxic.

It is used in fertilizers, vermin-killers, rodenticides, fireworks, and gunpowder.

Stages of acute poisoning:

First stage: Intake causes severe abdominal discomfort, throat and abdominal pain, extreme thirst, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. Excreta and breath have a garlic-like smell. Luminescent feces and vomit are characteristically seen. Skin contact results in second and third-degree burns that are deeply painful and take a long time to heal.

Second stage: This is a 2-3 days symptom-free period.

Third stage: There is hematemesis, enlargement of the liver, jaundice, pruritus, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and nausea. Shock, hepatic failure, injury to the central nervous system, hematemesis, and renal insufficiency are all potential causes of death.

Red phosphorus is characteristically odorless and is non-luminous.

Arsenic and thallium may also be associated with a garlicky odor; they are not characteristically associated with luminous vomitus.

Related Pearl: Arsenic poisoning

Summary of Arsenic poisoning

Source of exposure: Arsenic-containing pesticides, natural sources - drinking water and soil

Route of absorption: GI tract

Mechanism of action: binds to sulfhydryl groups and inhibits pyruvate dehydrogenase, gluconeogenesis, glutathione metabolism

Characteristic clinical findings are as follows: Mnemonic-ARSENIC

A- Aldrich mees lines

R- raindrop pigmentation, rash, red velvety mucosa

S- subendocardial haemorrhage

E- Excessive pigmentation- Blackfoot disease

N- Neuritis

I- Iron oxide + BAL –treatment

C- Cholera like illness

Diagnosis: 24-hour urine arsenic

Treatment: BAL; succimer(DMSA)

Clinicopathological findings in acute and chronic arsenic poisoning:

  • prolonged QT interval

There is platelet activation and hypercoagulability of blood in peripheral arteries leading to blackfoot disease

questions.text: All of the following structures form the floor of the 4th ventricle, except _____.
questions.solution:
All of the listed structures form the floor of the 4th ventricle, except superior and inferior medullary velum, which form the roof of the 4th ventricle.

Structures on the floor of the 4th ventricle (Rhomboid Fossa)

Ridges:

  • Transverse fibers: Striae medullares
  • Striae medullares divides rhomboid fossa into 2 parts: Rostral pontine and Caudal medullary 

Medial to lateral in rostral pontine part:

  • Midline longitudinal sulcus: Median sulcus
  • Bilateral eminences: Medial eminence
  • Bilateral longitudinal sulcus: Sulcus limitans
  • Bilateral areas: Vestibular area (deeper to it is the vestibular nucleus)

Upper and lower ends of sulcus:

  • Bluish-colored, uppermost area where sulcus limitans ends: Locus coeruleus
  • Depression, the upper area of sulcus limitans: Superior fovea
  • Depression, the lower area of sulcus limitans: Inferior fovea

Cranial nerve nucleus elevations:

  • Elevation on the medial eminence: Facial colliculus
  • Elevations in the lowermost area in the shape of 2 triangles: Hypoglossal and vagal triangles

Circumventricular organ:

  • Between the vagal triangle and gracile tubercle below: Area postrema

questions.text: Which among the following drugs is an Anti-CTLA-4 antibody used in the treatment of advanced melanoma?
questions.solution:
Anti-CTLA-4 antibody Ipilimumab was the first drug to significantly improve advanced-stage melanoma's survival. Cytotoxic T lymphocyte antigen 4 (CTLA-4) plays an important inhibitory role in the control of T-cell activation.

Ipilimumab is a fully humanized IgG1 monoclonal antibody that inhibits cytotoxic T lymphocyte antigen-4 (CTLA-4).

Other options:

Option A - Pembrolizumab acts by inhibiting programmed death receptor - 1 (PD-1) and was used for the treatment of advanced melanoma. Now, the FDA has approved the use of pembrolizumab for any cancer with mismatch repair (MMR) deficiency or high microsatellite instability (MSI-H).

Option C - Nivolumab is an immune checkpoint inhibitor that acts by inhibiting programmed death receptor - 1 (PD-1) and is used for the treatment of advanced melanoma and relapsed/refractory classical Hodgkin lymphoma.

Option D - Trastuzumab is a monoclonal antibody that inhibits the HER2 receptor. It is used in the treatment of HER2-positive breast cancer.

questions.text: A pregnant lady at 20 weeks of gestation comes with acute-onset fever and pain in the right lumbar region. Chills, nausea, and vomiting are also present. Urinalysis reveals the presence of E. coli, and a diagnosis of acute pyelonephritis is made. You should titrate the volume resuscitation so as to target an urine output of _____________.
questions.solution:
Aggressive intravenous hydration to maintain adequate urine output is the mainstay in the treatment of pyelonephritis. A urinary output ≥50 mL/h is maintained with intravenous crystalloids.

Acute pyelonephritis is one of the frequent and serious medical complications occurring in the second trimester of pregnancy. The most common causative organism is Eshcherichia coli. Clinical features include sudden-onset fever, chills, and aching pain in the lumbar region (usually unilateral). Nausea, vomiting, and anorexia are also present. Tenderness in the costovertebral angle can be elicited on examination.

The diagnosis is confirmed by the collection of urine (preferably from catheterization) and analysis to look for leukocytes and bacteria. 

Management protocol for pyelonephritis during pregnancy: 

  • Hospitalization is recommended for all patients. Very rare cases of uncomplicated pyelonephritis can be managed on an outpatient basis.
  • Urine and blood (if the temperature is >39°C) samples are collected for culture.
  • Aggressive intravenous hydration to maintain adequate urine output is the mainstay of treatment. A urinary output ≥50 mL/h is maintained with intravenous crystalloids.
  • Vital signs such as blood pressure, pulse, temperature, and oxygen saturation along with urine output should be monitored for signs of worsening sepsis.
  • Empirical intravenous antibiotic therapy is started with ampicillin plus gentamicin, cefazolin, or ceftriaxone. It is switched to oral antibiotics once the patient is afebrile.
  • In case of persistent infection or lack of clinical improvement by 48 to 72 hours, renal sonography is recommended to look for urinary tract abnormalities (like obstruction or calculi).

Related Pearl: Asymptomatic bacteriuria

 
Asymptomatic bacteriuria: Urinary tract infection without any symptoms. Criteria for diagnosis are as follows:

Midstream clean-catch urine specimen

For women: 2 consecutive samples

For men: single sample

 1,00,000 of the same bacterial species 
Catheterized urine specimen  Single sample

100 for asymptomatic bacteriuria (CA-ASB)

1000 for catheter-associated urinary tract infection (CA-UTI)
Suprapubic aspirate Single sample Any growth of microorganisms in the culture

questions.text:
Food poisoning due to which of the following organisms is typically associated with 8-16 hours of incubation period?
  1. Staphylococcus aureus
  2. Bacillus cereus - Emetic type
  3. Bacillus cereus - Diarrheal type
  4. Vibrio cholerae
  5. Clostridium perfringens
questions.solution:
Food poisoning occurring due to Clostridium perfringens & Bacillus cereus - Diarrheal type are typically associated with 8-16 hours of incubation period.

Food poisoning caused by B. cereus is of two types:

Bacillus cereus Diarrheal type Emetic type
Incubation period 8-16 hours 1-5 hours
Toxin Secreted in intestine Preformed
Heat Heat labile Heat stable
Food items Meat Rice
Clinical feature Diarrhea, abdominal cramps Vomiting, abdominal cramps

 

C. perfringens food poisoning usually occurs following the ingestion of contaminated meat dishes. The toxin is formed when the organisms sporulate in the gut. Diarrhea usually occurs without vomiting or fever. Usually, the illness lasts only 1–2 days.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about diabetic chieroarthropathy?

choices.text: Limited joint mobility results due to periarticular fibrosing syndrome
Occurs due to enzymatic glycosylation of collagen
Seen in both type1 and type2 diabetes

questions.solution:
Diabetic cheiroarthropathy/diabetic stiff hand syndrome is due to the non-enzymatic glycosylation of collagen

Diabetic cheiroarthropathy/diabetic stiff hand syndrome is due to limited joint mobility as a result of the periarticular fibrosing syndrome. This is due to the non-enzymatic glycosylation of collagen. It is seen in both diabetes type1 and type2. Its prevalence increases with age and poor glycemic control.

questions.text: Injury to which of the following nerves would result in impaired sensation over the marked region?
questions.solution:
Regimental badge sign is seen in injury to axillary nerve.

An area of hypoaesthesia or anaesthesia is seen over the distal part of the deltoid muscle; this is referred to as the ‘regimental badge patch’ of the skin or regimental badge sign. This reflects loss of function in the upper lateral cutaneous nerve of the arm, a branch of the axillary nerve.

questions.text:
Which of the following features are typically associated with delirium?
  1. Impaired consciousness
  2. Sundowning
  3. Normal EEG
  4. Carphologia or floccillation
  5. Autonomic Dysfunction
questions.solution:
Delirium is associated with impaired consciousness, carphologia or floccillation, autonomic dysfunction, sundowning, and an abnormal EEG. 

Delirium is characterized by

  • An acute decline in the level of awareness 
  • Global impairment of cognitive functions (particularly attention)

It also involves

  • Perceptual disturbances like illusions and hallucinations
  • Abnormal psychomotor activity
  • Sleep cycle impairment

Formication is a tactile (not visual) hallucination in which the patient experiences a feeling of insects crawling under the skin.

Related Pearl: Delirium vs Dementia

Features

Delirium

Dementia

Hallmark is impaired consciousness

Loss of memory and intellectual abilities

Commonly seen in 

Children and elderly 

Elderly

  • Acute medical illness 
  • Autonomic dysfunction
  • Abnormal EEG 
  • Carphologia or floccillation (picking movements at cover-sheets and clothes) 
  • No medical illness
  • Little autonomic dysfunction
  • Normal EEG 

Psychological findings
  • Impaired consciousness
  • Illusion, delusion 
  • Sundowning (symptoms much worse at night) 
  • Normal consciousness
  • Depressed mood 
  • Personality changes in early stages in Pick’s disease 
  • Sundowning (symptoms much worse at night) 

Course
  • Develops quickly
  • Fluctuating course with lucid intervals (waxing and waning) 
  • Insidious-onset
  • Progressive downhill course
 

Etiology
  • CNS disease (E.g: Huntington or Parkinson disease)
  • CNS trauma
  • CNS infection (E.g: Meningitis)
  • Systemic disease (E.g., hepatic, cardiovascular)
  • Substance abuse/withdrawal
  • HIV infection
  • Prescription drug overdose (E.g: atropine) 
  • Alzheimer's disease
  • Vascular disease (15-30% of all dementias)
  • CNS disease (E.g., Huntingtons or Parkinsons disease)
  • CNS infection (HIV, Prion diseases)
  • Lewy body dementia
  • Pick's disease (Frontotemporal dementia) 
 

Treatment:

 

Treat the underlying medical cause

Acetylcholinesterase inhibitors (donepezil, rivastigmine) and NMDA antagonist (memantine)

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about selective mutism due to childhood anxiety disorder?

choices.text: The first-line treatment is using benzodiazepines
Children usually speak freely at home but exhibit symptoms when under social pressure
Develops in children 4 to 8 years of age
Maternal overprotection reinforces selective mutism behaviors.

questions.solution:
Individual cognitive behavioral therapy is recommended as a first-line treatment for selective mutism.

Selective mutism refers to the lack of speaking (being mute) in one or more specific social situations, commonly in school, but speaking well in other situations, commonly at home. The child may be either completely silent at school or maybe just whispering. Rarely, a child may be silent at home but communicating normally at school.

The disorder may develop in children between 4 to 8 years of age and is associated with a social anxiety disorder. They may have symptoms of separation anxi­ety disorder, school refusal, and delayed language acquisition. Maternal overprotection and anxiety disorders in parents may reinforce selective mutism behaviors.

The first-line treatment is individual cognitive behavioral therapy.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female patient with easy fatiguability and pallor presented to the OPD. An image of her hands is given below. Which of the following findings is least likely to be seen in her peripheral smear?
questions.solution:
Skin hyperpigmentation especially on the dorsum of hands involving the knuckles is seen in cyanocobalamin or vitamin B12 deficiency which is a causative factor of megaloblastic anemia. The peripheral smear in this patient would show a reduction in reticulocyte count, not an increase.

In megaloblastic anemia, there is an impairment of DNA synthesis that leads to ineffective hematopoiesis. It also causes distinctive morphologic changes, including abnormally large erythroid precursors and red cells.

Clinical features of megaloblastic anemia (cyanocobalamin and folate deficiency):

System Clinical features
Oral

Glossitis

Angular cheilosis
Gastrointestinal

Anorexia

Weight loss

Diarrhea

Constipation
Skin Hyperpigmentation (reversible)
Hematological

Thrombocytopenia

Leucopenia

Ineffective erythropoiesis and unconjugated jaundice
Cardiovascular

Atherosclerosis leading to PVD, CAD (due to elevated homocysteine)
Neurological (only B12)

Peripheral neuropathy

Subacute combined degeneration (degeneration of the posterior and pyramidal tracts of the spinal cord)
Pregnancy (only folate)

Recurrent fetal loss

Neural tube defects
Others

Mild fever in severe cases

Psychiatric disturbances

Peripheral smear findings:

  • Macro-ovalocytes are seen.
  • Most macrocytes lack the central pallor of normal red cells and even appear hyperchromic, but the MCHC is not elevated.
  • Reticulocyte count is low.
  • Nucleated red cell progenitors occasionally appear in the circulating blood when anemia is severe.
  • Neutrophils are also larger than normal (macro polymorphonuclear) and show nuclear hypersegmentation, with five or more nuclear lobules.

The image given below shows hypersegmented neutrophils seen in megaloblastic anemia.

Bone marrow findings:

  • Markedly hypercellular as a result of increased hematopoietic precursors
  • Sieve-like pattern of chromatin of immature precursors (Megaloblasts)
  • Granulocytic precursors display dysmaturation in the form of giant metamyelocytes and band forms
  • Megakaryocytes abnormally large and have bizarre, multilobate nuclei
  • Derangement in DNA synthesis causes most precursors to undergo apoptosis in the marrow (ineffective hematopoiesis) and leads to pancytopenia

Related Pearl: Causes of Megaloblastic Anemia

Vitamin B12 Deficiency causes:

  • Decreased Intake
    • Inadequate diet
    • Vegetarianism
  • Impaired Absorption
    • Intrinsic factor deficiency
    • Pernicious anemia
    • Gastrectomy
    • Malabsorption states
    • Diffuse intestinal disease (e.g., lymphoma, systemic sclerosis)
    • Ileal resection
    • Ileitis
  • Competitive parasitic uptake
    • Fish tapeworm infestation
    • Bacterial overgrowth in blind loops and diverticula of bowel

Folic Acid Deficiency causes:

  • Decreased Intake
    • Inadequate diet
    • Alcoholism
    • Infancy
  • Impaired Absorption
    • Malabsorption states
    • Intrinsic intestinal disease
    • Anticonvulsants
    • Oral contraceptives
  • Increased Loss
    • Hemodialysis
  • Increased Requirement
    • Pregnancy, infancy
    • Disseminated cancer
    • Markedly increased hematopoiesis
  • Impaired Utilization
    • Folic acid antagonists
    • Unresponsive to vitamin B12 or folic acid therapy
    • Metabolic inhibitors of DNA synthesis and/or folate metabolism

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given image, concentric folds of the prolapsed rectum are seen, which implies that the most likely diagnosis is rectal prolapse.

Rectal prolapse occurs when a mucosal or full-thickness layer of rectal tissue protrudes through the anal orifice. Rectal prolapse is of two types:

  • Partial rectal prolapse: In this type, only the mucosal layer of the rectum is prolapsed. It is seen in children. The first episode is managed by digital repositioning. If there is a recurrence, then Theirsch's wiring or sclerotherapy is done. 
  • Complete rectal prolapse: In this type, all the layers of the rectum are prolapsed. It is seen in adults due to the weakening of the pelvic floor. It is managed by using the following approaches:

The perineal approach

The perineal approach is often preferred in patients with high operative risk and limited life expectancy, i.e. in the elderly. It is associated with less morbidity but has a higher recurrence rate. Procedures based on this approach are as follows:

  • Thiersch's wiring: A steel wire/nylon tape is placed around the anal canal. This procedure is largely obsolete and rarely used now due to problems with chronic perineal sepsis, anal stenosis, and obstructed defecation. 
  • Delorme's mucosectomy: In this procedure, the rectal mucosa is stripped circumferentially from the rectum over the length of the prolapse. The underlying muscle is plicated with a series of sutures. The excess rectal mucosa is excised and a mucosal anastomosis is performed.
  • Altemeier's rectosigmoidoscopy: In this procedure, the rectum is prolapsed through the anal canal and a full-thickness resection is performed, incorporating any associated colonic prolapse. Restoration of colorectal continuity can be performed by hand-sewn/stapled anastomosis. This is the procedure of choice in patients presenting with incarcerated and strangulated prolapse.

Abdominal approach

The abdominal approach is difficult, has more complications, but has a lower recurrence rate. Procedures based on this approach are as follows: 

  • Ripstein's procedure: Involves the placement of a prosthetic mesh around the mobilized rectum, with the attachment of the mesh to the presacral fascia (anterior) below the sacral promontory
  • Well's procedure: Involves posterior rectopexy 
  • Suture rectopexy

questions.text: Which of the following is unlikely to be seen as a side effect of lithium therapy?
questions.solution:
Dry mouth and not sialorrhea, is a known side effect of lithium therapy.

Related Pearl: Lithium in bipolar disorder

questions.text: For how long should you maintain records of medical termination of pregnancy?

choices.text: For at least 7 years, from the end of the calendar year of MTP
For at least 10 years, from the beginning of the calendar year of MTP
For at least 3 years, from the beginning of the calendar year of MTP
For at least 5 years, from the end of the calendar year of MTP

questions.solution:
A register for recording the details of medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) must be kept for at least 5 years, from the end of the calendar year it relates to. The patient's name must not be entered; only the reference number is used.

Unlawful disclosure of a patient's details is punishable with 1-year imprisonment with or without fine. Only the patient's consent is required for MTP; her male partner's consent is not required. Consent of parent/guardian is needed if the age of the patient is <18 yrs or if the patient is mentally ill.

 

 

 

Related Pearl: Medical Termination of Pregnancy Act - MTP Act 1971

MTP Act with 2021 amendments 

Indications:

  • Therapeutic - to save the life of the mother
  • Eugenic - to prevent the risk of the child being born with serious mental or physical abnormality i.e. first-trimester viral infections, teratogenic drug intake, radiation exposure
  • Humanitarian - pregnancy resulted from rape or incest
  • Social - pregnancy resulted from failure of contraceptives 

Rules:

  • Only a registered medical practitioner who is qualified (one who has assisted in the performance of 25 cases of MTP in a recognized hospital) can terminate a pregnancy.
  • MTP should be carried out in a government or government-recognized hospital. Private hospitals may take up MTP if they obtain a license from the chief medical officer of the district.
  • The termination of pregnancy by a person, who is not a registered medical practitioner (the person concerned), or in an unrecognised hospital (administrative head) shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term not less than 2 years, but which may extend to 7 years. 

Consent:

The consent of the woman is required for conducting an abortion. The written consent of the guardian is required if the woman is minor or mentally ill. Consent of the husband or partner is not necessary. 

If the woman is not willing, abortion cannot be performed at the request of the husband alone. The woman need not produce proof of her age. It is enough for the woman to say that she was raped, and it is not necessary that a complaint was lodged with the police.

Opinion of doctors:

  • Till 20 weeks - 1 doctor's opinion
  • 20 to 24 weeks - 2 doctors' opinion
  • For substantial fetal anomalies - approval from the medical board consisting of obstetrician, paediatrician, radiologist and a person appointed by the state

Upper limit of MTP:

  • Up to 24 weeks of gestation in victims of rape and incest, fetal anomalies, or congenital malformations
  • Up to 20 weeks in case of contraception failure (any female with her partner)
  • At any gestational age for substantial fetal anomalies decided by the medical board

Confidentiality:

A register for recording the details of MTP must be kept for at least 5 years. The patient's name must not be entered, only the reference number is used. Unlawful disclosure of patient's details is punishable with 1-year imprisonment ± fine.

questions.text: All of the following are true about macula densa except:

choices.text: It causes afferent arteriolar constriction in response to increases Na+ concentration
It functions as a chemoreceptor for K+
It is located at the end of the thick ascending limb of Henle and at the beginning of the distal tubule

questions.solution:
Macula densa serves as a chemoreceptor for Na+, not K+

At the end of the thick ascending limb of Henle, and at the beginning of the distal tubule, the tubular epithelial cells are specialized to form the macula densa. They detect the sodium concentration of the fluid in the tubule (chemoreceptor). Though changes in K+ also seems to have an effect on renin levels, even that seems to be mediated via Na+.  

In response to elevated sodium, the macula densa cells trigger the contraction of the afferent arteriole, reducing the flow of blood to the glomerulus and the glomerular filtration rate. This happens as follows: When there is increased sodium, there is increased sodium-potassium ATPase activity which leads to increased ATP hydrolysis causing more adenosine formation. The adenosine receptors on the macula densa cells stimulate it to release more calcium, so that there is vasoconstriction of the afferent arteriole, thereby decreasing the GFR.

Macula densa secretes PGE2 along with RMICs(Renal Medullary Interstitial Cells) and cells in the collecting ducts.

Apart from macula densa, the juxtaglomerular apparatus contains

  • Lacis cells: Extraglomerular mesangial cells situated between afferent and efferent arteriole.
  • Granular cells/JG cells: Modified smooth muscle cells of the afferent arteriole, they secrete renin. Fall in pressure in afferent arteriole stimulates renin release (mechanoreceptor), which, in turn, increases blood pressure.

Related Pearl: Factors that affect renin secretion

Stimulatory

  • Increased sympathetic activity via renal nerves
  • Increased circulating catecholamines
  • Prostaglandins
  • Na+ depletion
  • Diuretics
  • Upright posture
  • Hemorrhage
  • Hypotension
  • Dehydration
  • Cardiac failure
  • Cirrhosis
  • Constriction of the renal artery or aorta
  • Various psychological stimuli

Inhibitory

  • Increased Na+ and Cl- reabsorption across macula densa
  • Increased afferent arteriolar pressure
  • Angiotensin II
  • ADH (vasopressin)

questions.text: At what age of gestation is an amniocentesis generally done?
questions.solution:
The best time for performing amniocentesis is 15-20 weeks of gestation

Amniocentesis is the most common prenatal diagnostic procedure. It is performed using an aseptic technique, under direct sonographic guidance, using a 20–22 gauge spinal needle. The needle is directed perpendicularly into a clear pocket of amniotic fluid while avoiding the fetus and umbilical cord. Sonography is used to observe the uterine puncture site for bleeding and fetal cardiac motion is documented at the end of the procedure. Approximately 20 to 30 mL of fluid is collected for fetal karyotyping or chromosomal microarray analysis. 

Study material

Amniotic fluid with amniocytes

Time

15-20 weeks

Early amniocentesis

11-14 weeks (associated with increased fetal loss, foot deformities)

Indications
  • Congenital infections
  • Fetal genetic disorders
  • Alloimmunization
Complications
  • Fetal loss
  • Amniotic fluid leakage
  • Transvaginal spotting

Below is an image showing the procedure of amniocentesis vs chorionic villus sampling.

Note:

Amniocentesis is generally done between 15-20 weeks but may be performed at any point later in gestation.

Related Pearl: Prenatal screening for Down’s syndrome

  • USG findings
    • Intrauterine growth retardation (so decreased blood flow)
    • Choroid plexus cysts
    • Increased nuchal translucency >3 mm
    • Hypoplastic nasal bone
    • Congenital heart defects
    • Increased intestinal echogenicity
    • Duodenal atresia
  • Maternal serum markers
    • Decreased: Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP), unconjugated estriol, pregnancy-associated plasma protein-A (PAPP-A)
    • Increased: Human chorionic gonadotrophin (HCG), inhibin, neutrophil alkaline phosphatase
  • Amniocentesis: 14th-18th week of pregnancy
  • Chorionic villus sampling
    • 10th to 12th week of pregnancy: Gives the diagnosis in the first trimester

questions.text: Which of the following tumor markers is least useful in assessing dysgerminoma?
questions.solution:
Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) is not a useful marker for dysgerminoma; it is a marker for endodermal sinus tumors. Dysgerminoma secretes placental alkaline phosphatase, lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), and β-hCG.

Dysgerminoma is a type of germ cell tumor corresponding to the testis's seminoma. It does not secrete either male or female sex hormones. It secretes placental alkaline phosphatase (ALP), lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), and β-hCG. Serum lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) is usually used to monitor these patients for disease recurrence.

Endodermal sinus tumor/ Yolk sac tumor is a type of ovarian germ cell tumor that is seen in premenarchal girls. Schiller-Duval bodies are pathognomonic in histopathology. Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) is commonly produced by this tumor and is used as a tumor marker.

Related Pearl: Markers of Ovarian Neoplasm

Ovarian tumor Tumor marker Pathognomonic finding

Epithelial ovarian tumors

 CA-125,  CA-19-9, CEA Psammoma bodies (Serous epithelial tumor)
Endodermal sinus tumor AFP Schiller-Duval bodies
Dysgerminoma LDH, PLAP Lymphocytic infiltration
Embryonal carcinoma AFP, HCG -
Mature teratoma AFP Rokitansky protruberance
Granulosa cell tumor Inhibin Call–Exner bodies
Hilus cell tumor - Reinke's crystal
Brenner tumor - Walthard cell nest
Krukenberg tumor - Signet-ring cell
Clear cell tumor - Hobnail cell

Dysgerminoma (Mnemonic: DPL= Delhi Premier League)

  • D: Dysgerminoma
  • P: PLAP (placental alkaline phosphatase)
  • L: LDH (lactate dehydrogenase)

questions.text: Workers of a chemical factory are suing the company, claiming compensation for unsafe working conditions that increase their risk of cancer. The cancer incidence data compared with the general population are provided below. What is the risk ratio?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, risk ratio or relative risk (RR) is 5.

Relative Risk/ Risk Ratio  (RR) = [ a/(a+b) ]/ [ c/(c+d) ] where, 

  • a - Number of people with cancer amongst the factory workers
  • b - Number of people without cancer amongst the factory workers
  • c - Number of people with cancer amongst the general population
  • d - Number of people without cancer amongst the general population

RR = [50/(50+950)] / [100/(100+9900)]

=0.05/0.01

=5

 

Related Pearl: Relative and Attributable Risk

Relative Risk:

  • Ratio of incidence of disease or death among exposed to that among the non-exposed is called relative risk (RR).
  • It is also called risk ratio.
  • It is the direct measure of the strength of association between suspected cause and effect in cohort studies.
  • RR < 1 indicates inverse association(protective effect)
  • RR = 1 indicates no association.
  • RR > 1 indicates positive association.
  • RR of 2 indicates a 100% increase in risk.
  • Relative risk calculation (RR) = [ a/(a+b) ]/ [ c/(c+d) ] where, 
  Cancer
Exposure   yes no
yes a b
no c d

 

Attributable Risk:

  • Attributable risk (AR) is the difference in incidence rates or proportions of disease or death between an exposed and non-exposed group.
  • It is expressed in percentage and gives the extent to which the disease can be attributed to the exposure in a cohort study.

questions.text: Which of the following is expressed on macrophages and monocytes?
questions.solution:
CD68 is expressed on macrophages and monocytes.

The marker of the natural killer cells is CD94. It is expressed in natural killer cells and a small subset of T lymphocytes. 

 

CD 3 is a T-cell receptor marker. It is involved in the transduction of signals to the T cells when an antigen binds to the T cell receptor.

CD 25 is a component of the IL2 receptor and is important in T cell proliferation and activation.

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 10 weeks gestation, presents to the outpatient department with complaints of curdy white vaginal discharge, dysuria, and intense itching. Candidal vaginitis is suspected. As per the CDC, what will be the best management in this scenario?

choices.text: Oral fluconazole 150 mg two doses 1 week apart
Metronidazole 200 mg oral TDS for 7 days

questions.solution:
The patient has candidal vaginitis. The best management in a pregnant woman is topical azoles like clotrimazole or miconazole, applied intravaginally for 7 days.

Although the treatment of vulvovaginal candidiasis involves oral fluconazole 150 mg single dose or topical azole therapy for 7 days in a non-pregnant woman, only topical azoles are recommended during pregnancy. Since the use of fluconazole has been associated with embryotoxicity and increased risk of cardiac malformations, it is recommended to be avoided during the first trimester.

Risk Factors For candidal infection include

  • Immunosuppression
  • HIV
  • Pregnancy
  • Steroid therapy
  • Following long-term broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy
  • Oral contraceptive pills
  • Diabe­tes mellitus
  • Poor personal hygiene
  • Obesity

The clinical symptoms of vaginal candidiasis include curdy white vaginal discharge, dysuria, and intense itchin with vaginal pH <4.5. The diagnosis can be confirmed by microscopic examination of smear of vaginal discharge with 10% KOH solution. The smear shows budding yeast cells and pseudohyphae.

Related Pearl: Vaginal infections

  Bacterial vaginosis Trichomonas vaginitis

Candidal vaginitis

Discharge Fishy, thin, yellow Frothy, green Curdy, white
Symptoms Fishy odour, no itching Itching and burning Itching, burning
pH >4.5 >4.5 <4.5
Speculum No vaginal epithelium inflammation Strawberry cervix Inflamed-epithelium
KOH Positive Whiff test The whiff test can be positive. Pseudohyphae seen.
Wet mount Clue cells. No WBCs seen Motile trichomaonads, WBCs seen WBCs seen
Treatment Metronidazole or Clindamycin Metronidazole, treat partner also Oral or vaginal azole, no need to treat partner.

questions.text: A 43-year-old lady who had recently undergone a renal transplant comes with complaints of recurrent retrosternal chest pain and swallowing difficulty. As part of her workup, an upper GI endoscopy is done and it appears as below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Cytomegalovirus lesions appear as serpiginous ulcers in an otherwise normal mucosa, particularly in the distal esophagus.

 

Transplant recipient patients are at higher risk of developing CMV infections. The typical presentation is with complaints that are associated with CMV infections of the other system as well. Complaints that are seen in patients with CMV esophagitis for include

  • Dysphagia & odynophagia
  • Retrosternal pain/ Abdominal pain
  • Nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea
  • Fever
  • Weight loss
  • Hemoptysis

Related Pearl: Endoscopic Findings in Esophagitis

 

Conditions Endoscopic findings

HSV esophagitis Vesicles and small punched-out lesions (volcano ulcers)
CMV esophagitis Serpiginous ulcers
Peptic esophagitis Solitary and distal  
Eosinophilic esophagitis Multiple esophageal rings, linear furrows, or white punctate exudates (feline esophagus)
Pill esophagitis Singular and deep at points of luminal narrowing with sparing of the distal esophagus
Candida esophagitis White friable plaques, in advance form - adherent, grey-white pseudomembranes.

The image below shows feline esophagus in eosinophilic esophagitis.

questions.text: A 23-year-old man presents to your PHC with a Category III dog bite. But, Rabies Immunoglobulin (RIG) is not available at your center. How would you manage the patient?

choices.text: Administer 1st dose of vaccine and refer to higher center for administration of RIG
Skip RIG as there is no use in administering it after the first dose of vaccine is administered
Withhold vaccine till RIG becomes available as RIG should be administered prior to first dose of vaccine
Withhold vaccine till RIG becomes available as they should be administered simultaneously

questions.solution:
Administer 1st dose of vaccine and refer to higher center for administration of Rabies Immunoglobulin.

Rabies immunoglobulin (RIG) is passive immunization. It is administered only once, preferably within 24 hours of the exposure, i.e., on day 0 of the anti-rabies vaccine (ARV). If RIG was not given with the ARV 1st dose, it can be given up to the 7th day after the first dose of ARV. It is not given after 7 days of receiving the 1st dose of ARV.

The dose is 20 IU/kg body weight for human rabies immunoglobulin (HRIG) and for equine rabies immunoglobulin (ERIG), the dose is 40 IU/kg body weight. When HRIG is not available, ERIG can be used. They are potent, safe, and less expensive. 

The entire RIG dose or as much as anatomically possible should be infiltrated into the wound or as close as possible. If it is likely that there are additional small wounds, the remaining RIG should be given IM as close as possible to the site of wound or exposure.

All patients with category III exposures should be given RIG. This includes

  • single/multiple transdermal bites/scratches,
  • licks on broken skin,
  • contamination of mucous membranes with saliva,
  • contact with bats.

In immunocompromised patients, RIG should be given to both category II and III exposures.

Related Pearl: Rabies vaccines and immunoglobulins schedules

According to the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, Government of India:

WHO category II or III exposures should receive post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) immediately.

One intradermal (ID) dose is 0.1 mL of vaccine and one intramuscular (IM) dose is an entire vial of vaccine, irrespective of the vial size.

Should a vaccine dose be delayed for any reason, the PEP schedule should be resumed (not restarted).

Rabies Immunoglobulin(RIG): 

  • Passive immunization
  • Single-dose; after initiation of PEP and not beyond 7 days after the first dose of vaccine
  • Max dose: hRIG - 20IU/kg , eRIG - 40IU/kg body weight
  • Vaccines should never be withheld regardless of the availability of RIG.
  • Alternatives for RIG- WHO recommends monoclonal antibodies (mAb) as a 'cocktail' containing at least two antibodies against the rabies virus.

Administration of RIG:

  • RIG should be administered into or around the wound site or sites.
  • The remaining RIG, if any, should be injected IM at a site distant from the site of vaccine administration.
  • RIG may be diluted to a volume sufficient for all wounds to be effectively and safely infiltrated.

Prioritization of RIG allocation (numbered according to priority order):

  1. Multiple bites
  2. Deep wounds
  3. Bites to head, neck, and hands
  4. Patients with severe immunodeficiency
  5. Confirmed/probable rabies in biting animal
  6. Bites, scratches, and exposure of mucous membranes caused by a bat

Pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP)

PrEP is considered in the following conditions:

  • High-risk groups- laboratory staff, wildlife wardens, veterinarians, animal handlers, and travelers to endemic regions.
  • Remote, rabies-endemic areas where access to PEP is difficult
  • Areas where dog bite incidence is >5% per year
  • Areas where vampire bat rabies is known to be present.

Pre-exposure rabies vaccination consists of 3 intramuscular (IM) or 3 intradermal (ID) doses. These are given on days 0, 7 and 21 or 28.

  • Adults - the vaccine should always be administered in the deltoid area of the arm
  • Young children (under 1 year of age)- Administration into the anterolateral area of the thigh is recommended.
  • Rabies vaccine should never be administered in the gluteal area. Administration in this manner will result in lower neutralizing antibody titers.

For exposed or re-exposed patients who can document previous completion of PEP or PrEP the following guidelines would be applicable:

  • Proper wound management should be done.
  • There is no need for the administration of RIG.
  • One site ID or IM vaccine administration on days 0 and 3.

Only adequate wound washing would be required in case of re-exposure where the animal bite victim has documented proof of complete PEP within the last three months.

The following cases are treated as fresh cases and given full PEP:

  • Those who have previously received full post-exposure treatment with neural tissue vaccines (NTV) or vaccines of unproven potency
  • Those who cannot document complete PEP or PrEP treatment

questions.text: A woman comes to the OPD claiming that she was bitten by the insect shown in the image below, while out trekking. She may develop any of the following diseases due to this, except _____.
questions.solution:
The given image is of a soft tick. The diseases transmitted by soft ticks are Q fever, Relapsing fever & Kyasanur Forest disease. Rocky Mountain spotted fever is transmitted by hard ticks, and hence is unlikely in this patient.

Hard ticks are covered by a chitinous shield on their dorsal surface, which is called the scutum. They have a head or capitulum present at the anterior end, which is visible from above. 

Diseases transmitted by hard ticks:

  • Tick typhus (Rocky Mountain spotted fever)
  • Viral encephalitis (Russian spring-summer encephalitis)
  • Viral fevers (e.g., Colorado tick fever)
  • Viral hemorrhagic fevers (e.g. Kyasanur Forest disease in India)
  • Tularaemia
  • Tick paralysis
  • Human babesiosis.

Note: KFD in India can be transmitted with hard and soft ticks both.

An image of a hard tick is shown below.

Related Pearl: Ticks

  • The two types of ticks are hard ticks and soft ticks.
  • The general morphology of ticks includes an oval-shaped body, four pairs of legs, and no antennae.
  Hard tick Soft tick
Scutum A chitinous shield that covers the entire back in males. Females have a small portion in the front. Absent.
Head Situated at the anterior end. Lies on the underside of the body (ventrally). Not visible from above.
Eggs Several hundreds or thousands laid at once Laid in batches of 20 – 100 over a long period
Nymphal stages One Five
Habits Cannot withstand starvation; feed night and day. Can withstand starvation for more than a year.
Vectors for Tick typhus, viral encephalitis, viral fevers, tularemia, Kyasanur forest disease, babesiosis, tick paralysis. Ixodes type transmits Lyme disease. Soft tick is a reservoir for Q fever and a vector for relapsing fever.
Life span Short Longer
Habits Always found on their hosts. They hide in cracks and crevices during the day and come out to feed during the night.
  • Insecticidal control of ticks includes DDT, chlordane, dieldrin, lindane, malathion, and toxaphene. Environmental control and protection of workers must also be done to prevent disease transmission from ticks.

questions.text: Which among the following is wrong about DIC?
questions.solution:
In disseminated intravascular coagulopathy (DIC), the platelet count is decreased.

The most common site of thrombi in DIC is the brain. The most common cause of DIC is Infections.

Laboratory investigations in DIC:

  • Decreased platelet count 
  • Prolonged PT/TT
  • Prolonged activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT)
  • Decreased fibrinogen
  • Elevated fibrin degradation products (D-dimers)
  • Peripheral smear: microangiopathic hemolytic anemia in DIC with schistocytes (fragmented red blood cells) 

Cryoprecipitate can be used to rapidly raise the fibrinogen and factor VIII levels, particularly when bleeding is part of the DIC and the fibrinogen level is less than 1 g/L.

questions.text: A patient has normal fluency and repetition of speech but impaired naming and comprehension. He has _______.
questions.solution:
The symptoms described in the question suggest that the patient has posterior transcortical aphasia, also called fluent transcortical aphasia.

In posterior transcortical aphasia, the clinical features are similar to that Wernicke's aphasia, but here the repetition is intact. The lesion site disconnects the intact core of the language network from other temporoparietal association areas. Hemianopia may be an associated finding in some cases.

Common Causes:

  • Cerebrovascular lesions including infarctions in the posterior watershed zone
  • Neoplasms involving the temporoparietal cortex posterior to Wernicke’s area

Related Pearl: Aphasias and Related Conditions

  Comprehension Repetition of Spoken language Naming Fluency

Broca's Preserved Impaired Impaired Decreased
Global Impaired Impaired Impaired Decreased
Conduction Preserved Impaired Impaired Preserved
Anterior (nonfluent) transcortical Preserved Preserved Impaired Impaired
Posterior (fluent) transcortical Impaired Preserved Impaired Preserved
Isolation Impaired Echolalia Impaired No purposeful speech
Anomic Preserved Preserved Impaired Preserved except for word finding pauses
Pure Word Deafness Impaired only for spoken language Impaired Preserved Preserved
Pure Alexia Impaired only for reading Preserved Preserved  Preserved

 

Related Pearl: CNS deficits and site of lesions

Term Defnition Site of lesion
Agnosia Inability to accurately perceive objects through normally functioning sensory mechanisms Posterior parietal cortex

Dyslexia

(word blindness)

Inability to interpret their meanings

(the person may be able to see words and even know that they are words but not be able to interpret their meanings)

 Angular gyrus
Aphasia inability to produce and/or understand language

All components of the language network are interconnected with each other and with

surrounding parts of the frontal, parietal, and temporal lobes. Damage

to this network gives rise to language impairments resulting in aphasia.

questions.text: Damage to the genitofemoral nerve during surgery would result in all of the following, except ______.

choices.text: Loss of sensation over the mons pubis and labium majus in females
Loss of sensation over the root of penis in males
Loss of sensation over the anteromedial skin of the thigh

questions.solution:
Injury to the femoral branch of the genitofemoral nerve causes hypoesthesia over the anterior thigh below the inguinal ligament.

Injury to the genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve results in loss of sensation of the mons pubis and labia majora in females and loss of sensation in the skin of the scrotum of males. The genitofemoral nerve also innervates the cremaster muscle via the genital branch and is responsible for the cremasteric reflex.

Injury to the ilioinguinal nerve causes loss of sensation at the root of the penis and adjacent parts of the scrotum. It is most commonly injured within the inguinal canal in open hernia repair due to traction or thermal injury. 

 

The iliohypogastric nerve carries the sensory supply from the suprapubic area. Injury to this nerve in the right iliac fossa rarely causes sensory disturbances, as the suprapubic area has a rich nerve supply from other sources too. If the nerve is severed above the anterior superior iliac spine, it can lead to the weakened posterior wall of the inguinal canal, resulting in a direct inguinal hernia. The iliohypogastric nerve can also get injured following appendicectomy.

questions.text: Which of the following is wrongly paired?
questions.solution:
CLL/ Small lymphocytic lymphoma shows t(14;19). Follicular lymphoma shows t(14;18). 

Its hallmark is a translocation that juxtaposes the IgH locus on chromosome 14 and the BCL2 locus on chromosome 18. It is seen in up to 90% of follicular lymphomas and leads to overexpression of BCL2.

BCL2 inhibits apoptosis and promotes the survival of follicular lymphoma cells.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a characteristic feature of hypomanic episodes in patients with bipolar disorder?

choices.text: There is social and occupational impairment.
The patient does not show psychotic symptoms.
The episode lasts for at least 4 days.
Patient has a elevated, expansive, or irritable mood.

questions.solution:
A hypomanic episode does not cause social and occupational functioning impairment. Impairment is seen only in mania.

A manic episode is defined as a persistent elevated, expansive, or irritable mood for at least 1 week which requires hospitalization. A hypomanic episode is also similar to a manic episode except it does not cause social and occupational functioning impairment. It lasts for at least 4 days, and the patient does not show psychotic symptoms. 

A person is said to be depressed if he has at least four of the following symptoms for at least 2 weeks:

  • Change in appetite and weight
  • Change in sleep and activity
  • Lack of energy
  • Guilty feeling
  • Recurring thoughts about death or suicide

Lithium is used for the pharmacological management of bipolar disorder.

Related Pearl: Lithium in bipolar disorder

Guidelines for Lithium therapy
Indications:
Mania, hypomania, bipolar disorder, etc.

Blood levels of lithium:

For therapeutic purpose (treatment of acute mania) : 0.8-1.2 mEq/L

For prophylaxis (to prevent relapse of bipolar disorder): 0.5-0.8 mEq/L

Toxic levels of lithium: >/= 1.5 mEq/L
Contraindications:
  • CKD
  • Heart disease
  • Hyponatremia or diuretic use
Baseline studies:
  • BUN (Blood Urea Nitrogen), Creatinine, Calcium, Urine analysis
  • Thyroid function test
  • ECG in patients with coronary risk factors
Acute adverse effects:
  • Tremor, ataxia, weakness
  • Polyuria, polydipsia
  • Vomiting, diarrhea
  • Cognitive impairment
Chronic adverse effects:
  • Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus
  • Thyroid dysfunction
  • Hyperparathyroidism

Related Pearl: Bipolar disorder

Bipolar & related disorders

Manic episode

  • Symptoms more severe
  • 1 week unless hospitalized
  • Marked impairment in social or occupational functioning or hospitalization necessary
  • May have psychotic features; makes episode manic by definition

Hypomanic episode  

  • Symptoms less severe
  • 4 days to less than 7 days
  • Unequivocal, observable change in functioning from patient's baseline
  • Symptoms not severe enough to cause marked impairment or necessitate hospitalization
  • No psychotic features

Bipolar I

  • Manic episode(s)
  • Depressive episodes common (but not required for diagnosis)

Bipolar II

  • Hypomanic episode(s)
  • Major depressive episodes (required for diagnosis)

Cyclothymic disorder

  • At least 2 years of fluctuating, mild hypomanic & depressive symptoms that
    do not meet criteria for hypomanic episodes or major depressive episodes

questions.text: Sagar was being tried in court for the attempted murder of Mohan in the park. Shikhar appeared in court and said that he was told by Raju that Sagar tried to kill Mohan. What is this evidence known as?
questions.solution:
This evidence is known as hearsay evidence. 

Hearsay evidence is given by someone about something that he/she did not personally witness. Sometimes, it might be obtained from a third party. It is presented in the court to claim that the facts contained in the statement are true, i.e. as a means of corroboration. 

Other types of oral evidence:

Direct evidence is the evidence of a fact that is actually in the issue. Examples: a witness saw A shooting B, prescription, consent form.

Indirect evidence is also known as circumstantial evidence. It is not the direct testimony of an eyewitness. It has an effect on other facts and subsidiary facts which are depended upon as consistent. 

Documentary evidence is of three types:
  • Medical certificates
  • Medicolegal reports
  • Dying declaration
 A witness is a person who gives evidence regarding facts. There are 2 types of witnesses:
  • Common witness is a person who gives evidence about those facts that are observed or perceived by him/her.
  • Expert witness has the technical knowledge and is capable of drawing conclusions from facts presented (Section 45 of IEA).

A witness can be considered a hostile witness when he/ she has a vested interest or motive for concealing part of the truth or for giving false evidence (Section 191 of IPC).

questions.text: Transport of iron from enterocytes into the blood is done by which of the following proteins:
questions.solution:
Transport of iron from enterocytes into the blood is done by ferroportin.

Iron absorption occurs in the duodenum. Iron in our gut exists in 2 forms, they are non-heme and heme iron. Luminal non-heme iron is mostly in the Fe3+ (ferric) state and is reduced to Fe2+ (ferrous) iron by ferrireductases. Fe2+ iron is then transported across the apical membrane by divalent metal transporter 1 (DMT1).

Given below is an image of iron absorption that shows divalent metal transporter-1 protein in intestinal mucosal cells.

Heme iron is moved across the apical membrane into the cytoplasm through heme transporters.

In the duodenal cells, Fe2+ iron can follow one of two pathways: transport to the blood or storage as mucosal iron. The nonstorage form of Fe2+ iron is transported from the cytoplasm into circulation by the protein ferroportin. A protein called hephaestin (Hp) is associated with ferroportin 1. It is not a transporter itself, but it facilitates basolateral transport

Once in circulation, Fe2+ is again oxidized back to Fe3+ iron by hephaestin and ceruloplasmin. The newly absorbed Fe3+ iron binds rapidly to transferrin, which delivers iron to red cell progenitors in the marrow.

Hepcidin is a protein secreted from the liver that plays a major role in the regulation of iron absorption. When the body’s iron stores are adequate, it downregulates the expression of ferroportin and thereby decreases iron absorption.

 

Related Pearl: Factors affecting iron absorption

Enhancers:

  • Ascorbic acid
  • Citric acid
  • Amino acid
  • Sugars in the diet

Inhibitors:

  • Tannins
  • Carbonate
  • Oxalate
  • Phosphate

questions.text: Licked candy stick appearance of the joints is seen in all of the following conditions, except ________.
questions.solution:
Melorheostosis has a characteristic dripping wax appearance or flowing candle wax appearance. 

The term licked candy stick appearance refers to the characteristic appearance of tapering of the tips of the metacarpal bones, metatarsal bones, phalanges, or clavicles. It is usually associated with the following conditions:

  • Psoriatic arthropathy
  • Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Leprosy
  • Neuropathic joint (including conditions like diabetic foot)

 

Melorheostosis is also known as Leri's disease. It is a rare mesenchymal dysplasia manifesting as regions of sclerosis of cortices with a characteristic dripping wax appearance or flowing candle wax appearance. The presentation is usually monostotic and unilateral. Symptoms include pain, deformity, skin and circulation problems, and contractures.

questions.text: Identify the fetal position.
questions.solution:
The image shows a fetus in a longitudinal lie, with face presentation, in a right mento-anterior position.

Definitions of various terminologies used for the fetus in utero:

  • Lie: Relationship of the long axis of the fetus to the long axis of the maternal spine
  • Presentation: Part of the fetus occupying the lower pole of the pelvis
  • Presenting part: Part of the presentation that overlies the internal os
  • Attitude: The relation of the different parts of the fetus to one another
  • Position: Relation of the denominator to the different quadrants of the pelvis

Fetal denominator refers to the bony fixed point of reference on presenting part with respect to different quadrants of the pelvis. The denominators for various presentations are as follows:

Presentation Denominator
Breech Sacrum
Vertex Occiput
Face Mentum (chin)
Brow Frontal eminence
Shoulder Acromion

 

The image below shows various positions possible in a face presentation.

questions.text: A worker found in a burning chemical factory is brought to the emergency in a state of hypotension and is suspected to have been exposed to hydrogen cyanide gas. Which of the following is best avoided during his management?
questions.solution:
Nitrites should be avoided in patients with cyanide toxicity presenting with hypotension, especially in the setting of concomitant carbon monoxide exposure.

Burning buildings are a source of carbon monoxide exposure and can result in carboxyhaemoglobin. Nitrites are used in cyanide poisoning because of their ability to form methemoglobin, which binds cyanide more avidly than the ferric iron of cytochrome oxidase. Nitrite therapy should be avoided for those with both cyanide and CO poisoning because these compounds work by inducing methemoglobin formation, which further reduces the oxygen content of blood in patients with carboxyhemoglobin accumulation.

Treatment of Cyanide Poisoning in Adults

  1. 100% oxygen
  2. IV crystalloids and vasopressors for hypotension
  3. Sodium bicarbonate for acidemia
  4. Either Cyanide antidote kit
    • Amyl nitrite inhaler - crack vial and inhale over 30 s.
    • 3% solution Sodium nitrite  -300 mg IV given over no less than 5 min.
    • 25% solution Sodium thiosulfate: 12.5 g IV. 
  5. Or Hydroxocobalamin - 5 g IV over 15 min, up to 10 g. 

Hydroxocobalamin(Vitamin B12a) is a metalloprotein with a cobalt center that binds cyanide, thereby removing it from cytochrome oxidase and forming cyanocobalamin. It is FDA-approved for the management of cyanide poisoning and is considered ideal in cases where the diagnosis of cyanide poisoning is uncertain or in cases where the methemoglobinemia induction would be detrimental, i.e., concomitant exposure to carbon monoxide as in building fires.

questions.text: Laboratory test results indicate normal levels of calcium, PTH, and phosphate, but raised alkaline phosphatase level. Which of the following conditions has such a biochemical profile?
questions.solution:
Patients with Paget's disease have normal levels of serum calcium, PTH, and phosphate, but raised serum ALP level. It is due to increased bone formation.

Hypocalcemia can be rarely seen in patients with Paget's disease. It is due to the active bone formation with insufficient calcium and vitamin D intake.

questions.text: A newborn with the given deformity is referred to you. Which of the following statements is false regarding this condition?

choices.text: The infant must always be examined for associated disorders such as congenital hip dislocation and spina bifida.
Relapse is uncommon in children managed with casts until the age of 1 year.
The order of correction according to Ponseti method is cavus-adduction-varus-equinus.
Foot abduction brace can be used to prevent relapse in these children.

questions.solution:
The given image shows congenital talipes equinovarus (CTEV) or clubfoot and option B is the false statement. As relapse is common, continued bracing is required for the first 4 years of life to minimize this risk.

CTEV is a congenital malformation of the foot. It is predominately seen in male children. The components of deformity are as follows:

  • Cavus: This deformity occurs due to exaggerated arching of the foot at the mid-tarsal joint.
  • Adduction: This deformity occurs at the talonavicular joint.
  • Inversion: This deformity occurs at the subtalar joint. The calcaneum is inverted and along with it, the whole foot is inverted. This leads to a medially facing sole. 
  • Equinus: This deformity occurs at the ankle joint and tarsal joints.

Ponseti method is a successful method of manipulation in CTEV. It should begin as early as the first 2 weeks after birth. Weekly manipulation of the foot is done with the help of plaster casts. 

To begin with, the first metatarsal is elevated to correct the cavus. This creates a flat longitudinal medial border of the foot. Then, the forefoot is abducted in the plane of the metatarsals. This everts the hindfoot and corrects the forefoot out of supination. Finally, equinus is corrected by dorsiflexing the foot at the ankle joint. In most cases, a percutaneous Achilles tenotomy is required later for complete correction of the equinus.

Following the complete correction of the club foot by serial casting, the deformity must be held using a foot abduction brace (FAB) to prevent relapse. For the first 3 months, it is used full-time (23 hours per day) and then at sleep time for 4 years.

The infant must always be examined for associated disorders such as congenital hip dislocation and spina bifida, as there is an association between these conditions.

Related Pearl: Age wise management of CTEV

Initial treatment starts with Ponseti's POP cast as early as possible, but within 1 year of age.

If deformity gets corrected:

  • Dennis Brown splint is used till 1 year of age
  • After 1 year upto 5 years CTEV shoes are used in day, and Dennis Brown splint is used at night

If deformity is not corrected or untreated previously:

  • 1-3 years: Posteromedial soft tissue release (PMSTR) 
  • 3-5 years: Dillwyn Evans procedure
  • 5-8 years: Dwyer osteotomy
  • 8-10 years: Wedge tarsectomy
  • >10 years: Triple arthrodesis, external fixators

questions.text: A 28-year-old lady seeks your advice regarding vaccination against warts. As per the WHO-SAGE guidelines, what should you advise her to take?
questions.solution:
Recommended HPV vaccination schedule for persons aged >21 years, according to WHO SAGE guidelines, is 2 doses 6 months apart.

The recommendations for different age groups are as follows:

  • 1 or 2 doses schedule for the primary target of girls aged 9–14 years.
  • 1 or 2 doses schedule for young women aged 15–20 years.
  • 2 doses with a 6-month interval for women older than 21 years.
  • 3 doses (or atleast 2 doses) for immunocompromised individuals.

Available vaccinations for HPV: 

  • Gardasil 9 (HPV9) is a nonavalent vaccine active against HPV types 6, 11, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52, and 58.
  • Gardasil 4 (HPV 4) is a quadrivalent vaccine against HPV types 6, 11, 16, and 18. This is now replaced by Gardasil 9 (HPV 9).
  • Cervarix (HPV 2) is a bivalent vaccine active against HPV types 16 and 18.
 

Related Pearl: Human Papilloma Virus (HPV) and Associated Lesions

HPV 6 and 11

questions.text: Which of the following parameters is abnormal in a patient with relative polycythemia?
questions.solution:
Relative polycythemia/ spurious polycythemia is an apparent increase in the hemoglobin level due to a decrease in plasma volume.

Polycythemia denotes an abnormally high red cell count, usually with a corresponding increase in the hemoglobin level (> 16 ±2 g/dL). It is 2 types:

  • Relative - hemoconcentration due to decreased plasma volume
  • Absolute - increase in the total red cell mass

Causes of relative polycythemia include:

  • Dehydration - deprivation of water, prolonged vomiting or diarrhea, excessive use of diuretics
  • Gaisböck syndrome - stress polycythemia where affected individuals are usually hypertensive, obese, and anxious

Causes of absolute polycythemia include:

  • Primary - intrinsic abnormality of hematopoietic precursors 
    • Polycythemia vera
    • Inherited erythropoietin receptor mutations
  • Secondary - red cell progenitors responding to increased levels of erythropoietin
    • Compensatory due to cyanotic heart and lung disease, high altitude
    • Paraneoplastic erythropoietin secreting tumours

Note: In dengue hemorrhagic fever, increased vascular permeability causes plasma leakage and volume loss. Hence, relative polycythemia is seen.
