questions.text:
Which of the following conditions of the oral cavity are considered premalignant?
  1. Granular Cell Myoblastoma
  2. Erythroplakia
  3. Pregnancy Granuloma
  4. Mucosal hyperpigmentation
  5. Pyogenic Granuloma
  6. Leukoplakia
questions.solution:
Erythroplakia, Leukoplakia, and Mucosal hyperpigmentation are considered premalignant lesions.

Leukoplakia is defined as a clinical white patch that cannot be characterized clinically or pathologically as any other disease. Oral hairy leukoplakia is caused by the Epstein–Barr virus. Smoking, tobacco chewing, and alcohol consumption are linked etiological factors. The most common sites involved are buccal mucosa and oral commissures. Males are affected two to three times more often.

Erythroplakia is a red patch or plaque on the mucosal surface. The red color is due to decreased keratinization and as a result, the red vascular connective tissue of the submucosa shines through. The most common sites are lower alveolar mucosa, gingivobuccal sulcus, and the floor of the mouth.  There is no sex predilection. Malignant potential is 17 times higher than in leukoplakia.

Melanosis and mucosal hyperpigmentation are benign pigmented lesions of the oral mucosa. They may transform into malignant melanomas. About one-fourth of mucosal melanomas may resemble benign lesions, and hence, biopsy may become mandatory.

Benign lesions of the oral cavity include:

  1. Papilloma
  2. Fibroma (Fibroepithelial polyp)
  3. Hemangioma
  4. Lymphangioma
  5. Torus
  6. Pyogenic granuloma
  7. Pregnancy granuloma
  8. Granular cell myoblastoma or Granular cell tumor
  9. Minor salivary gland neoplasms
  10. Solitary fibrous tumor
  11. Mucocele
  12. Ranula
  13. Dermoid

questions.text: The contrast-enhanced CT of a middle-aged woman shows a complicated renal cyst with thickened septae and solid non-enhancing nodules. You grade it as Bosniak III. What is the likelihood of malignancy?
questions.solution:
According to the Bosniak classification, renal cysts with thickened septae and solid non-enhancing nodules are classified as Bosniak III, and Bosniak III lesions have a ~50% likelihood of malignancy.

Class Appearance Malignancy Management
Bosniak 1 Simple cyst: Rounded with imperceptible wall Not malignant No further workup required
Bosniak 2

Minimally complex: 

Size <1 mm with septa and thin calcifications

 

 Not malignant No further workup required
Bosniak 2F

Minimally complex:

Size >3 cm with increased number of septa

Minimally thickened with nodular or thick calcifications

 5% chance of malignancy Needs ultrasound/CT follow-up every 6 months
Bosniak 3

Complicated cysts:

Thickened septa with nodular areas of calcification or solid non-enhancing areas

Appears hyperdense on CT

 55% chance of malignancy

Partial nephrectomy

Radiofrequency ablation in elderly or poor surgical candidates
Bosniak 4 Solid enhancing mass with a large cystic or necrotic component

Clearly malignant (100%)

 Partial or total nephrectomy

questions.text: As per the Milan criteria for liver transplantation in patients with cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma, which of the following would disqualify a patient for liver transplantation?

choices.text: Presence of a single tumor with diameter 4.2 cm
Presence of three tumors with diameters 2.5 cm, 2.2 cm, and 1.5 cm
Presence of two tumors with diameter 2.2 cm and 1.5 cm

questions.solution:
The presence of major vessel involvement would disqualify a patient for liver transplantation, as per the Milan criteria.

The Milan criteria are used to assess the suitability of patients with cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma for liver transplantation. In order to be suitable for liver transplantation, the patient should have

  • a single tumor with a diameter of ≤5 cm
  • up to 3 tumors, each with a diameter ≤3 cm
  • no extra-hepatic involvement
  • no macrovascular invasion

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the WHO recommendation for antibiotic prophylaxis, in areas with ≥10% active trachoma prevalence in children of age 1-9 years?

choices.text: Tetracycline eye ointment is recommended for those that have allergy to macrolides
Oral azithromycin must be administered to all children less than 9 years only
The mass antibiotic therapy should be given thrice a year for three years
The annual treatment should be continued till the TF prevalence in children of 1-9 years of that area becomes less than 2%.

questions.solution:
Tetracycline eye ointment is recommended for those that have allergy to macrolides.

ln areas with ≥10% prevalence of active trachoma (TF in children 1-9 years), the WHO recommends the following measures: 

  • Antibiotic therapy
    • Oral azithromycin to all community members (not only children)
    • Tetracycline eye ointment for all pregnant women, children<6 months, and those allergic to macrolides.
  • Follow-up
    • The mass antibiotic therapy should be given once a year for three years continuously, after which reassessment of prevalence should be made.
    • The annual treatment should be continued till the TF prevalence in 1-9 years children of that area becomes less than 5%.(not 2%)

Trachoma is a form of chronic infective conjunctivitis and is one of the leading causes of blindness. It has an ‘active’ inflammatory stage and a ‘cicatricial’ chronic stage.

The active inflammatory stage is more prevalent in children and presents with nonspecific symptoms of ocular irritation, foreign body sensation, and discharge (often mild symptoms). Examination findings at this stage show: 

  • Conjunctival follicles containing Leber cells (multinucleated lymphocytes)
  • Corneal Herbert's follicles (similar to conjunctival follicles)

Cicatricial chronic stage is seen in middle age. And when the chronic infection with sequelae sets in, the patient complains of pain, lacrimation, photophobia and later blurring, and finally loss of vision. Conjunctiva shows concretions (whitish deposits of inspissated mucus in depressions called glands of Henle). Corneal signs include: 

  • Herbert pits (pitted scars in the limbal, which are remnants of healed Herbert follicles)
  • Corneal opacity is seen in later stages.

There can be associated trichiasis (when at least one eyelash rubs the eyeball) and entropion.

At present WHO grading with `FISTO’ is in use.

Trachoma is treated according to the WHO classification using the SAFE strategy (Surgery, Antibiotics, Facial hygiene, and Environmental improvement). Azithromycin is the antibiotic of choice, and surgery involves the correction of trichiasis and entropion. In case of significant corneal scarring, penetrating keratoplasty is done.

Related Pearl: WHO classification of trachoma (FISTO)

WHO grading of trachoma

  • TF = trachomatous inflammation (follicular): five or more follicles (>0.5 mm) on the superior tarsal conjunctiva.
  • TI = trachomatous inflammation (intense): diffuse involvement of the tarsal conjunctiva, obscuring 50% or more of the normal deep tarsal vessels; papillae are present
  • TS = trachomatous conjunctival scarring: easily visible fibrous white tarsal bands
  • TT = trachomatous trichiasis: at least one lash touching the globe
  • CO = corneal opacity sufficient to blur details of at least part of the pupillary margin

Related Pearl: WHO Programme to Control Trachoma: SAFE Strategy

  • S—Surgery: Trichiasis and entropion correction surgery → 3° prevention.
  • A—Antibiotics: Oral azithromycin, topical 1% tetracycline, topical 1% azithromycin → 2° prevention
  • F—Facial hygiene → 1° prevention.
  • E—Environmental cleanliness → primordial prevention

The strategy depends on the prevalence of trachoma follicle in children (aged 1–9 yrs)

  • >10% → Mass antibiotic treatment at the community level and FE measures
  • 5 to 10% → Targeted antibiotic treatment (affected families) and FE measures
  • < 5% → FE measures

questions.text: All of the following measures are correct regarding the management of frostbite except:

choices.text: Rewarming by asking the patient to exercise is not advised
Rapid rewarming can be accomplished by immersing the foot in a warm water bath
Rubbing/friction can be used to hasten up the process of rewarming
Tetanus prophylaxis must be given as there is increased risk of tetanus in frost bite

questions.solution:
Rewarming by exercise, rubbing, or friction is not advised. 

In frostbite, tissue damage results from severe environmental cold exposure or from direct contact with a very cold object. Tissue injury results from both freezing and vascular stasis. It usually affects the distal aspects of the extremities or exposed parts of the face, such as the ears, nose, chin, and cheeks.

Clinical features include decreased sensation (especially for pain, and temperature sensations) in the acral tips and extremities. Affected area appears waxy, mottled, or violaceous. Patients may have a wood-like sensation in the affected area.

Treatment:

  • Initial treatment is by rapid rewarming (or thawing), which is accomplished by immersion of the affected part in a water bath at temperatures of 37°–40°C (99°–104°F) for 30–60 min. Rewarming by exercise, rubbing, or friction is not advised. 
  • Analgesics such as ibuprofen are often required during rewarming.
  • Antithrombotics, thrombolytics and vasodilators such as prostacyclin can be given to improve circulation after rewarming.
  • Frost bites are associated with an increased risk of infections and tetanus. Therefore, the injured area should be cleaned with soap or antiseptic, and sterile dressings should be applied. Tetanus prophylaxis must be given, but, empirical antibiotics are not recommended.
  • The patient must be monitored for the development of compartment syndrome.
  • Elective late amputation after imaging may be required in severe cases.

Image showing frost bite of the toes

questions.text: Which of these first-line antitubercular drugs is proposed to be acting by collapsing the transmembrane proton motive force, thereby killing the bacteria?
questions.solution:
Pyrazinamide is the first-line antitubercular drug that is proposed to be acting by collapsing the transmembrane proton motive force, thereby killing the bacteria

Pyrazinamide is a prodrug that is activated by the enzyme pyrazinamidase(encoded by the pncA gene). It is converted into an active metabolite pyrazinoic acid. This metabolite makes the intracellular environment acidic which collapses the transmembrane proton motive force, thereby killing the bacteria. Hepatotoxicity and hyperuricemia are the common side effects.

Isoniazid is a first-line bactericidal drug that is used for the treatment of tuberculosis. This drug enters bacilli by passive diffusion. It then gets activated to its toxic form by the enzyme catalase-peroxidase(the enzyme encoded by the Kat gene). Normally, InhA and KasA are involved in the synthesis of mycolic acid. Upon activation, the reactive metabolite of isoniazid forms complexes with NAD that inhibit InhA and KasA. Hence, isoniazid inhibits the production of mycolic acid.

The reactive isoniazid metabolite also forms complexes with NADP. This complex inhibits mycobacterial dihydrofolate reductase which results in the interruption of DNA synthesis.

Side effects of isoniazid include peripheral neuritis. Therefore, pyridoxine 10mg/day (vitamin B6) is given prophylactically along with isoniazid to prevent neurotoxicity. Hepatitis, rashes, anemia, and arthralgia are also seen. Toxicity of isoniazid results in metabolic acidosis and seizures. 

Rifampin is the first-line antitubercular drug. It binds to DNA-dependent RNA polymerase to form a stable drug-enzyme complex. This complex suppresses RNA synthesis. Side effects of rifampin are hepatitis, flu-like illness, and urine and secretions may become orange-red but this is harmless.

Ethambutol inhibits arabinose transferase III, thereby decreasing arabinogalactan biosynthesis. This results in, disruption in mycobacterial cell wall synthesis. The important side effect of ethambutol is optic neuritis, resulting in decreased visual acuity and loss of red-green discrimination.

questions.text: In which condition would a histopathological examination of the small intestine reveal infiltration of the lamina propria with macrophages containing PAS-positive inclusions?
questions.solution:
Histopathological examination of the small intestine showing infiltration of the lamina propria with macrophages containing PAS-positive inclusions is seen in Whipple's disease. 

Exposure to the gram-positive Tropheryma whipplei can lead to an asymptomatic state; acute disease; or chronic infection, which is also known as Whipple's disease. It is characterized by a triad of diarrhea, weight loss, and arthralgia. Malabsorptive diarrhea of Whipple's disease is due to bacteria-laden macrophages that accumulate within the small intestinal lamina propria and mesenteric lymph nodes causing lymphatic obstruction. Extraintestinal symptoms may precede malabsorption.

Histopathological findings: 

  • A dense accumulation of distended, foamy macrophages is seen in the small intestinal lamina propria; these macrophages contain PAS-positive, diastase-resistant granules, which indicate partially digested bacteria with lysosomes—a hallmark of Whipple's disease.
  • With disease progression, there is villous atrophy, crypt hyperplasia, and apoptosis of surface epithelial cells in the intestine, which can cause diarrhea due to decreased absorption and increased efflux of water and solutes. 
  • Non-caseating granulomas may also be seen. 
  • Bacteria-laden macrophages can accumulate within mesenteric lymph nodes, synovial membranes, cardiac valves, brain, or other sites.


The treatment regimen for Whipple's disease includes ceftriaxone 1 g intravenously twice daily or meropenem 1 g intravenously three times daily for 2 weeks. It is followed by trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole 160/800 mg twice daily for 12 months.

Other options:

Option B: Celiac disease presents as a malabsorption syndrome secondary to the introduction of gluten in the diet.

It is characterized by the presence of IgA antigliadin, anti-endomysial, and anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies. 

Histology shows a flat appearance of the intestine with crypt hyperplasia, villous atrophy, an increase in the number of intraepithelial lymphocytes, and increased numbers of lymphocytes and plasma cells in the lamina propria.

The image below shows the intestinal biopsy of a patient with celiac disease.


Option C: Tropical sprue is an acquired malabsorptive condition of probable infectious etiology. Histopathology shows partial villous atrophy with increased inflammatory cells in the lamina propria.

The image below shows a duodenal biopsy of a patient with tropical sprue. Partial villous atrophy (arrow) and lymphoplasmacytic infiltration in the lamina propria (asterisk) are visible.


Option D: Bacterial overgrowth syndromes present as malabsorption syndrome with diarrhea, steatorrhea, and macrocytic anemia due to the proliferation of colonic-type bacteria within the small intestine.

questions.text: The brain of a 32-year-old HIV-positive man, who died following a CNS infection, is sent for examination. Histopathological section reveals a gelatinous mass growing in perivascular Virchow-Robin spaces within the gray matter, producing soap-bubble lesions. What is the likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
In immunosuppressed people, Cryptococcus infection evokes virtually no inflammatory reaction. As a result, gelatinous masses of fungi grow in the meninges or in the perivascular Virchow-Robin spaces within the gray matter, and expand it, producing the so-called soap-bubble lesions. Cryptococcus mostly causes lesions in the CNS, involving the meninges, cortical gray matter, and basal nuclei. 

Cryptococcus is an opportunistic fungus that is found worldwide as a saprophyte in soil enriched with pigeon droppings.

Pathogenesis:

  • Infection is initiated by inhalation of the yeast cells.
  • The primary pulmonary infection may be asymptomatic or may mimic an influenza-like respiratory infection, often resolving spontaneously.
  • In immunocompromised, the yeasts may multiply and disseminate to other parts of the body, but preferentially to the CNS, causing cryptococcal meningoencephalitis.
  • Other common sites of dissemination include the skin, adrenals, bone, eye, and prostate gland.

Clinical findings:

  • Chronic meningitis (Headache, nuchal rigidity, disorientation)
  • CSF pressure, protein concentration and cell count are elevated
  • Cutaneous ulcers, granulomata

Diagnosis:

  1. Specimens - CSF, tissue, exudates, sputum, blood, urine, skin scrapings
  2. Microscopy - 
    • Gram staining shows gram-positive round budding yeast cells
    • India ink preparation reveals capsulated budding yeast cells; capsules are prominent in this staining.
  3. Culture - 
    • Colonies on SDA at 37°C appears as smooth, mucoid and creamy white.
  4. Serology
    • Demonstration of cryptococcal antigen by latex agglutination test is a sensitive, specific and rapid method for identificcation of cryptococcal meningoencephalitis.

Treatment:

  1. Cryptococcosis without CNS involvement: Fluconazole is the drug of choice
  2. HIV patient with CNS involvement: 
    • Induction: Liposomal Amphotericin B with Flucytosine for at least 2 weeks 
    • Maintenance: Oral Fluconazole 

The below image shows Cryptococcus neoformans stained with India ink. Note the prominent capsule.

Related Pearl: CNS infections and regions commonly affected

questions.text:
Match the following inclusion bodies with the respective disease conditions in which they may be seen.
A. Torres bodies 1. Granuloma inguinale
B. Levinthal-Cole-Lillie bodies (LCL bodies) 2. Trachoma
C. Miyagawa’s granulocorpuscles 3. Psittacosis
D. Halberstaedter-Prowazek bodies 4. Yellow fever
  5. Lymphogranuloma venereum
questions.solution:
The correct pairs are as follows:

  1. Torres bodies - Yellow fever
  2. Levinthal-Cole-Lillie bodies (LCL bodies) - Psittacosis
  3. Miyagawa’s granulocorpuscles - Lymphogranuloma venereum
  4. Halberstaedter-Prowazek bodies - Trachoma
  5. Donovan bodies - Granuloma inguinale 

Inclusion bodies are structures with distinct sizes and shapes that are seen in infected cells under light microscopy. 

Torres bodies are amorphous eosinophilic nuclear inclusions associated with yellow fever, a disease caused by the Flavivirus.

The Miyagawa corpuscles are inclusion bodies seen in lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV). They are intracytoplasmic microcolonies of Chlamydia trachomatis seen on microscopy of the aspirated material from the buboes.

Levinthal-Cole-Lillie bodies are inclusion bodies of Chlamydia psittaci seen in infected cells including alveolar macrophages from patients suffering from psittacosis. They are present in cell cultures also. Distinguishing features from inclusion bodies of C. trachomatis are that they are more diffuse and irregular and are not stained by iodine.

Halberstaedter-Prowazek (HP) bodies are demonstrated in conjunctival scrapings of patients with trachoma, after staining by Giemsa, Castaneda, or Macchiavello methods. They stain well with iodine as they contain glycogen.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true?

choices.text: Patients with severe anemia and even marked arterial desaturation may not display cyanosis as absolute quantity of reduced hemoglobin produces cyanosis
Patients with severe anemia and even mild arterial desaturation will display severe cyanosis as relative quantity of reduced hemoglobin produces cyanosis
Patients with severe anemia and even mild arterial desaturation will display severe cyanosis as absolute quantity of reduced hemoglobin produces cyanosis
Patients with severe anemia and even marked arterial desaturation may not display cyanosis as relative quantity of reduced hemoglobin produces cyanosis

questions.solution:
Patients with severe anemia and even marked arterial desaturation may not display cyanosis as absolute quantity of reduced hemoglobin produces cyanosis.

The absolute quantity of reduced hemoglobin is important in producing cyanosis. Thus, in a patient with severe anemia, the relative quantity of reduced hemoglobin in the venous blood may be very large when considered in relation to the total quantity of hemoglobin in the blood. However, since the concentration of hemoglobin is markedly reduced, the absolute quantity of reduced hemoglobin may still be low, and, therefore, patients with severe anemia may not display cyanosis even in situations with marked desaturation.

The converse of this is that at higher total hemoglobin content, there is a greater tendency toward cyanosis. Thus, patients with marked polycythemia tend to be cyanotic at higher levels of SaO2 than patients with normal hematocrit values.

questions.text: Which of the following plots shows a Lineweaver-Burk plot corresponding to noncompetitive inhibition?
questions.solution:
Image 3 corresponds to a double reciprocal plot (Lineweaver-Burk plot) for non-competitive inhibition.

Non-competitive inhibition occurs when the substrate and the inhibitor are chemically not similar and have different shapes. The inhibitor binds away from the active site, i.e., at the allosteric site. This type of inhibition is known as non-competitive inhibition.

Ex: Pyruvate kinase reaction is inhibited by alanine.

In non-competitive inhibition

  • Vmax decreases
  • Km remains constant 

In a Lineweaver-Burk plot, the addition of a non-competitive inhibitor causes plots with the same x-intercept (Km is unaffected) but different slopes and y-intercepts.

Although image 4 also corresponds to noncompetitive inhibition, the graph shows a plot of 1/V(Reaction Velocity) vs. concentration of inhibitor across various concentrations of substrate. Hence, it is a Dixon Plot. 

  • Km is the substrate concentration at which velocity is half of its maximum velocity.
  • Vmax is the maximum velocity of a reaction.
Inhibition Km Vmax
Competitive Increases Same
Non Competitive Same Decreases
Uncompetitive Decreases Decreases

 

Competitive inhibition is when the inhibitor binds reversibly to the substrate-binding site and competes with the substrate for the active enzyme binding site. This effect of competitive inhibition can be overcome by increasing the substrate concentration by which maximum velocity can still be achieved. Therefore, Vmax is unaltered in this type of inhibition. However, the concentration of the substrate required to achieve half of the maximum velocity is increased. Therefore, Km is increased in this condition.

The graph shows the changes in Vmax and Km in competitive inhibition.

 In uncompetitive inhibition, inhibitors bind with the enzyme-substrate intermediate complex, and inhibit it. This leads to decrease in both Vmax and Km. An example is the inhibition of placental alkaline phosphate (ALP) by phenylalanine. 

Related Pearl: Difference between Competitive & Non-Competitive inhibitors

Reversible inhibitors are of two types:

  • Competitive inhibitors
  • Non-Competitive inhibitors

Difference between Competitive & Non-Competitive inhibitors

Competitive inhibitors

Non-Competitive inhibitors

Succinate dehydrogenase is inhibited by Malonate

Pyruvate kinase is inhibited by alanine

Substrate & inhibitor are chemically similar & have same shape

Substrate & inhibitor are chemically not similar & have different shape

Inhibitor binds to active site

Inhibitor binds away from active site, i.e., at allosteric site

Inhibitor does not change the shape of the active site

Inhibitor changes the shape of the active site

Increase in substrate concentration reduces the inhibition

Increase in substrate concentration does not affect the inhibition

Vmax remains constant

Vmax decreases

Km Increases

Km remains constant

questions.text: You notice an online campaign to help pay for nusinersen(Spinraza) for a patient with spinal muscular atrophy. All of the following are true about the drug except:

choices.text: It is survival motor neuron - 2 (SMN2)-directed antisense oligonucleotide
Onasemnogene abeparvovec(Zolgensma) also shares the same mechanism
It can be used in both in pediatric and adult patients
After initial loading doses, it requires a maintenance dose once in four months

questions.solution:
Onasemnogene abeparvovec (Zolgensma) is an adeno-associated virus vector-based gene therapy, while nusinersan(Spinraza) is a survival motor neuron-2 (SMN2) directed antisense oligonucleotide.

Onasemnogene abeparvovec is indicated for children<2 years of age with spinal muscular atrophy due to bi-allelic mutations in the survival motor neuron 1 (SMN1) gene. It is administered as a single intravenous dose. 

Nusinersen is indicated for the treatment of spinal muscular atrophy (SMA) in pediatric and adult patients. It is administered intrathecally. After initial loading doses, it requires a maintenance dose once in four months.

Spinal muscle atrophy is a lower motor neuron disease with early-onset and occurs as a result of the loss of a protein called survival motor neuron (SMN). Features of lower motor neuron disease include flaccid paralysis, muscle atrophy, fasciculations characterized by visible muscle twitches appearing as flickers under the skin, hypotonia (decreased muscle tone), hyporeflexia, or areflexia. 

Clinical forms of SMA are

  • In infantile SMA, the onset is very early and rapid. It is characterized by decreased fetal movements in the third trimester. In infancy, features include weak and floppy infant (hypotonic) and they lack muscle stretch reflex. Tongue fasciculations are typically seen in a severe form of SMA known as Werdnig-Hoffman disease. It can affect infants between 0-6 months.
  • Chronic childhood SMA has a slow onset and a progressive course.
  • Juvenile SMA is seen in late childhood with a slow course.

 

Related Pearl: Features of Motor Neuron Lesions

Upper Motor Neuron Lesion

Lower Motor Neuron Lesion

Upper motor neuron typically refer to corticospinal tract neurons that innervate spinal motor neurons, but they can also include brainstem neurons that control spinal motor neurons

Lower motor neurons are those whose axons terminate on skeletal muscles

Little or no muscle wasting → weakness of relatively large group of muscles

Muscle atrophy → muscle weakness of an individual and specific muscle

Hypertonia

Hypotonia

Increased or exaggerated deep tendon reflexes (hyperreflexia)

Hyporeflexia or areflexia

Spasticity

Flaccidity

Positive Babinski sign (abnormal plantar extensor reflex)

Fasciculations

questions.text:
What is the qSOFA score in a patient whose examination findings are as shown below?
  • GCS - 13/15
  • RR - 26/min
  • Pulse - 112/min
  • BP - 96/62 mm Hg
  • SpO2 - 89%
  • Abdomen - soft, nontender
questions.solution:
qSOFA score for this patient would be 3. Only 3 parameters are considered for its calculation, and the respective scores are as follows:

  • BP: 96/62 mmHg → Low blood pressure (SBP ≤100 mmHg) → Score 1
  • Respiratory rate: 26 breaths/min → High (≥22 breaths/min) → Score 1
  • Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score: 13/15 → Altered mentation (GCS score, <15) → Score 1

qSOFA score (quickSOFA) is a bedside prompt that may identify patients with suspected infection who are at greater risk for a poor outcome outside the intensive care unit (ICU). It uses three criteria, assigning one point each for

  • low blood pressure (SBP≤100 mmHg),
  • high respiratory rate (≥22 breaths/min)
  • altered mentation (Glasgow Coma Scale score, <15).

The score ranges from 0 to 3 points. The presence of 2 or more qSOFA points is a simple prompt to identify infected patients outside the ICU who are likely to develop sepsis. This is a simplified derivative of SOFA score. The primary method to evaluate the risk of organ dysfunction (sepsis) in patients with suspected infection is by determining the  Sequential (sepsis-related) organ failure assessment (SOFA) score; which includes assessment of:

  • Circulation - Systolic BP & need for vasopressors; platelet count
  • Respiration - PaO2/FiO2 & need for mechanical ventilation
  • Mentation - Glasgow Coma Scale score 
  • Hepatic function - Bilirubin level
  • Renal function - Creatinine level

Organ dysfunction is defined by a SOFA score of ≥2.

The SOFA score is limited by its requirement of multiple laboratory tests which makes it complex and time-consuming. In order to simplify the scoring process, the "Sepsis - 3" task force recommended the quick sepsis-related organ dysfunction assessment "qSOFA" score.

SOFA vs. qSOFA:

  • SOFA is a more comprehensive and accurate scoring system, which is particulary superior to qSOFA in the ICU setting. 
  • qSOFA is a simplified derivative of SOFA for bedside assessment of individuals at risk for sepsis particularly useful outside the ICU. setting (i.e. ward / emergency department). However, note that it was originally designed as predictive tool that calculates the risk of death from sepsis rather than a diagnostic tool.

Thereby, the best description of sepsis based on "Sepsis -3" task force recommendations would be as follows:

  • Suspected or documented infection with SOFA score of ≥2  Or
  • Suspected or documented infection with qSOFA score of ≥2

Another score that has been used is the National Early Warning Score (NEWS). It ranges from 0 to 20 and is based on respiratory rate, oxygen saturation, use of supplemental O2, temperature, systolic blood pressure, pulse rate, and level of consciousness. ≥5 out of 20 is considered a positive score. 

Other scoring systems for sepsis:

The Systemic Inflammatory Response Syndrome (SIRS) score is no longer recommended as is it not specific to infection.

Related Pearl: SOFA and qSOFA Scores

Sepsis is defined as a state of life-threatening organ dysfunction that occurs due to an unregulated host immune response to an infection. To objectively define the beginning of organ dysfunction, sequential organ failure assessment (SOFA) scoring is used. The variables in the SOFA score include:

  • Circulation - Systolic BP & need for vasopressors and platelet count
  • Respiration - PaO2/FiO2 & need for mechanical ventilation
  • Mentation - Glasgow coma score (GCS)
  • Hepatic function - Bilirubin
  • Renal function - Creatinine
Sequential Organ Failure Assessment (SOFA) score
  0 1 2 3 4

MAP = mean arterial pressure. Epi = epinephrine. Nonrepi = norepinephrine. ¤ = Adrenergic agents administered for at least 1 h (doses in μg/kg per min).

 

Organ dysfunction is identified by a SOFA score of ≥ 2

A simplified version, recommended by the 'Sepsis 3' taskforce, is known as the quick sepsis-related organ dysfunction assessment "qSOFA" score. It includes:

  • Systolic BP ≤100 mmHg
  • Respiratory rate ≥ 22/min
  • Altered mentation/sensorium

Each criterion carries 1 point. A qSOFA score of ≥ 2 is associated with increased mortality due to sepsis.

SOFA vs qSOFA:

  • SOFA is a more comprehensive and accurate scoring system that is particularly superior to qSOFA in the ICU setting.
  • qSOFA is a simplified derivative of SOFA for bedside assessment that is particularly useful outside the ICU setting (i.e. ward/emergency department).

Thereby, the best description of sepsis would be :

  • Suspected or documented infection with SOFA score ≥ 2
    OR
  • Suspected or documented infection with qSOFA score ≥ 2

However, note that these scores were originally designed as a predictive tool that calculates the risk of death from sepsis rather than a diagnostic tool.

questions.text: An ophthalmological examination of a patient shows the following findings. This is likely to be the result of:

choices.text: Blunt trauma to the eye causing pigment deposition
Age-related lipid degeneration of the cornea

questions.solution:
The finding given in the image is that of a Vossius ring.

Vossius ring is a circular ring of faint or stippled opacity, seen on the anterior surface of the lens due to brown amorphous granules of pigment lying on the capsule of the lens. It is usually seen after blunt trauma to the eye and orbit.

It usually has about the same diameter as the contracted pupil. The force of the blow drives the cornea and iris backward and thus producing an impression of the iris on the lens. The resorption of the pigment results in discrete subcapsular opacities.

Corneal epithelial iron deposits are seen in keratoconus and are called Fleischer's ring. It is seen best with a cobalt blue filter. Slit-lamp examination reveals Fleischer's ring at the base of the cone formed.

Intraocular deposition of copper is seen in Wilson's disease and would result in a KF ring/ Kayser-Fleischer ring on the cornea. A brownish-yellow zone is seen in the peripheral Descemet membrane of the cornea. Anterior capsular cataract, also knowns as a sunflower cataract may be seen in some patients.

Age-related lipid degeneration of the cornea would result in Arcus lipoides/ Arcus senilis/ Gerontoxon. Arcus senilis (AS) is usually an age-related lipid degeneration of the peripheral cornea that forms a light grey or bluish ring. It is the most common peripheral corneal opacity and is usually found in the elderly where it is considered a benign condition.

When AS is found in patients less than 40 years old it is termed arcus juvenilis. It represents an increased risk for cardiovascular disease and warrants screening for an underlying lipid disorder. AS is caused by leakage of lipoproteins (phospholipids and cholesterol) from limbal capillaries into the corneal stroma.

  • Deposition begins at the superior and inferior aspects and progresses to encircle the entire peripheral cornea which is about 1 mm wide.
  • The peripheral border of this ring opacity is sharp while the central border is diffuse.
  • The exterior border of AS and the limbus is separated by a clear zone of the cornea called the interval of Vogt. (limbal sparing)

Noticing that the image shows the deposition within the area of the pupil, and hence indicated a likely deposition on the lens and not the cornea, would have helped rule out the other three options.

questions.text: Identify the pathology from the given flow-volume loop:
questions.solution:
The graph shows airflow limitation and flattening in the expiratory limb of the loop seen in variable intrathoracic obstruction.

Variable (nonfixed) intrathoracic obstruction is seen in conditions like bronchogenic cysts, tracheal lesions, etc.

The image below shows air flow limitation and flattening in the inspiratory limb of the loop. It is seen in nonfixed variable extrathoracic obstruction. eg. vocal cord paralysis, extrathoracic tracheomalacia, polychondritis, etc.

The graph depicts air flow limited during both inspiration and expiration leading to flattening of both the inspiratory and expiratory limbs, which is seen in fixed obstruction of the central or upper airway.

The image given below shows a concave upward, pattern in the expiratory limb. This is also called the "scooped-out" or "coved" pattern. Eg. asthma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, bronchiectasis, and bronchiolitis.

Saw tooth pattern of the loop consists of small, rapid oscillations in flow during both expiration and inspiration. It is seen in neuromuscular diseases, Parkinson disease, laryngeal dyskinesia, pedunculated tumors of the upper airway, tracheobronchomalacia, upper airway burns, and obstructive sleep apnea.

Related Pearl: Flow-volume graph/Loop

questions.text: Which of the following is least likely to be seen in a patient with McArdle's disease?

choices.text: Presentation in the first year of life

questions.solution:
McArdle disease, also known as type V glycogen storage disorder is an autosomal recessive condition. It typically presents during late childhood or in the second decade of life. The muscle glycogen phosphorylase enzyme deficiency interferes with ATP generation by glycogenolysis in the muscles. This causes muscle glycogen accumulation.

Symptoms are exercise intolerance associated with muscle cramps. A second-wind phenomenon where the symptoms subside after a short period of rest can also be seen. Myoglobinuria secondary to rhabdomyolysis leads to the passage of burgundy-colored urine in some patients. 

Rarely, it can present during infancy as hypotonia, muscle weakness, and respiratory complications. It is generally fatal. Muscle biopsy to measure glycogen content is the standard diagnosis. Avoiding strenuous exercise prevents symptoms. Glucose administration before exercise can improve tolerance. Vitamin B6 is also recommended.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents to the ENT OPD with complaints of recent onset right-sided hearing loss and tinnitus. On investigation, he was found to have a mass in his brain as shown below. Histological examination of the mass is likely to show all of the following features, except:
questions.solution:
The MRI scan image shows a tumor arising at the cerebellopontine angle. The most likely diagnosis based on the image and the clinical features of unilateral hearing loss and tinnitus would be vestibular schwannoma. A bag of worms appearance is seen in the case of plexiform neurofibroma and not vestibular schwannoma. They are a result of the expanded, ropy thickening of multiple nerve fascicles.

Vestibular schwannomas are commonly known as acoustic neuromas. The term vestibular schwannoma is preferred as these tumors most frequently arise from the vestibular portion of the vestibulocochlear nerve and arise from Schwann cells.

Vestibular schwannomas are the most common cerebellopontine angle tumors. Bilateral vestibular schwannomas are highly suggestive of neurofibromatosis type 2.

Clinical features: Patients present with adult-onset sensorineural hearing loss, with non-pulsatile tinnitus. There is no relationship between the size of the tumor and the degree of hearing loss. 

Microscopically, they are compromised of dense and loose areas called ‘Antoni A’ and ‘Antoni B’ respectively. Antoni A is a dense eosinophilic area containing spindle cells with rod-shaped nuclei lying in the palisading pattern. The resulting structures with central ‘nuclear-free zones’ ratified by the palisading of nuclei are termed ‘verocay bodies’.  The loose hypocellular Antoni B area contains spindle cells spread apart by the myxoid extracellular matrix.

Diagnosis: MRI is the imaging technique of choice. High-resolution T2-weighted imaging is the most commonly used sequence.

questions.text: Which of the following is a Y-shaped ligament that connects the calcaneum to the cuboid and navicular bone?
questions.solution:
Chopart's ligament is a Y-shaped ligament related to both calcaneocuboid and calcaneonavicular joints. It is a strong Y-shaped band, having a proximal stem and 2 distal limbs.

  • The proximal limb is attached by a stem to the anterior part of the upper calcaneal surface.
  • The distal limb divides into calcaneocuboid and calcaneonavicular parts.

Other options:

Option A: The Lisfranc ligament connects the medial cuneiform to the base of the 2nd metatarsal. It is a cuneometatarsal interosseous ligament. It is the strongest ligament among the three cuneometatarsal interosseous ligaments. It passes from the lateral surface of the medial cuneiform to the adjacent angle of the second metatarsal bone. 

Deformity of this ligament can lead to instability and deformity of the tarsometatarsal joint.

 

Option B: Spring ligament, also known as the plantar calcaneonavicular ligament, connects the sustentaculum tali to the navicular. It ties the calcaneus to the navicular and maintains the medial longitudinal arch of the foot. It is made up of the superomedial calcaneonavicular portion and the inferior calcaneonavicular portion.

 

Option D: Deltoid ligament also called the medial collateral ligament is attached to the apex, anterior and posterior borders of the medial malleolus. It has 2 layers, superficial and deep:

  • The superficial layer consists of tibionavicular fibers anteriorly, tibiocalcaneal fibers in the middle, and superficial posterior tibiotalar fibers posteriorly.
  • The deep layer consists of anterior tibiotalar fibers, tibiocalcaneal in the middle, and deep posterior tibiotalar posteriorly.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child who has never received a vaccination for pertussis is brought by her parents. As per the IAP guidelines, what should you advise?

choices.text: Tdap, Td, and Td at 0, 1, and 6 months
Tdap, and Td at 0, and 6 months

questions.solution:
DTwP/DTaP at 0, 1, and 6 months is advised for catch-up vaccination in children below 7 years of age. 

DPT is a combined vaccine given for immunization against the three diseases: diphtheria, pertussis, and tetanus.

Routine vaccination:

  • Three primary doses at 6, 10, and 14 weeks and two boosters at 15–18 months and 4–5 years
  • Minimum age: 6 weeks
  • The first booster (4th dose) may be administered as early as age 12 months, provided at least 6 months have elapsed since the third dose
  • DTaP or DTwP vaccine/combination may be used for the primary immunization series

 Catch-up vaccination:

  • The second childhood booster is not required if the last dose has been given beyond the age of 4 years
  • Catch up below 7 years: DTwP/DTaP at 0, 1, and 6 months
  • Catch up above 7 years: Tdap, Td, and Td at 0, 1, and 6 months

questions.text: An association between ordinal position on one ranking and ordinal position on another ranking can be determined by which of the following techniques?
questions.solution:
Spearman's rank-order correlation is used to determine the association between ordinal position on one ranking and ordinal position on another ranking.

It is one of the two most commonly used correlation coefficients. It is used for ordinal scale data. The other one is Pearson product-moment correlation, which is used for interval or ratio scale data.

The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric (non-numeric) test, and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.

  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed, but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increase.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is<5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

A paired t-test compares paired data, or pre-intervention and post-intervention data, of the same group.

The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means), and here, the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

Related Pearl: Scales of data measurement

Data can be quantitative (numerical values) or qualitative (types, labels).

Quantitative data can be discrete variables or continuous variables.

 

Description

Example

Discrete data

Can take certain values and none in between

Number of cancer patients in a hospital. 

Continuous data

Can take any value usually in between limits or a range. 

Most biomedical data is continuous.

Height, weight, blood pressure, etc.

 

Data always forms one of four scales of measurement – nominal, ordinal, interval, or ratio scales (mnemonic: NOIR):

 

Nominal Scale Data

Ordinal Scale Data

Interval Scale Data

Ratio Scale Data

Example

Male/female; red/green; sub-urban/rural

Students ranked 1st/2nd/3rd in their class. 

A customer feedback survey using terms like very good, good, poor and very poor or the Likert Scale.

Severity of a disease as mild, moderate, severe

 

 Measurements on the celsius scale. Pulse rate; 

Notes

Have no quantitative value.

They have no order or ratio. 

Arranged in a meaningful order.

No size interval is defined

Arranged in a meaningful order with a well defined size interval.

Example: Temperature in Celsius. If temperature in A is 40 deg Celsius and that in B is 20 deg Celsius, then A is 20 deg Celsius hotter than B (taking difference)

Does not have an absolute zero.

For example, Celsius scale has no such thing as “no temperature”. So the value cannot be zero.

Arranged in a meaningful order with a well defined size interval.

Eg: A pulse rate has well defined intervals and is meaningful in comparison. A 100/min pulse is exactly twice of 50 beats/min.

 

Has an absolute zero.

Eg: There can be a value of zero for pulse.

Type

Qualitative

Qualitative

Quantitative

Quantitative

questions.text: A 59-year-old patient presents with right-sided nasal obstruction and occasional blood-stained nasal discharge. His CT and endoscopy findings are shown in the image below. What is the treatment of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
On the basis of the given images and the presenting history, inverted papilloma is the most likely diagnosis. The treatment of choice for inverted papilloma is medial maxillectomy.

Inverted papilloma (Ringertz tumor or transitional cell papilloma or Schneiderian papilloma) is a benign neoplasm of the non-olfactory mucosa of the nose (also called the Schneiderian membrane) and paranasal sinuses.

The lateral wall of the nose in the middle meatus is the most common site of origin. The hyperplastic papillomatous tissue grows into the stroma.
It is common in the 4th to 7th decades of life with a male preponderance. It is almost always unilateral and presents with unilateral nasal obstruction, nasal discharge, and epistaxis. It can invade sinuses or the orbit, the latter of which causes proptosis, diplopia, and lacrimation.
 
On examination of nose or endoscopy, it presents as a polypoidal mass resembling simple nasal polyps, as depicted by arrows in the endoscopic image above. A computed tomography(CT) scan and/or magnetic resonance imaging(MRI) show the location and extent of the lesion. MRI provides additional help to differentiate associated secretions in the sinus from the actual tumor mass. A biopsy is essential for diagnosis.
 
Medial maxillectomy is the treatment of choice, done preferably via endoscopy. Recurrence is common and malignancy has been observed in up to 15% of the cases. Radiotherapy may induce malignancy and hence is not advised.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is ineffective for the management of infection with Pseudomonas aeruginosa?
questions.solution:
Cefixime does not possess antipseudomonal activity. 

Antipseudomonal cephalosporins include ceftazidime, ceftolozane, cefepime, and cefpirome.

Drug Class Antibacterial spectrum

First generation :

Cefazolin, cephalexin, cefadroxil, cephradine

 Streptococci; Staphylococcus aureus, some Proteus spp., E. coli, Klebsiella 

Second generation :

Cefuroxime

Cefuroxime axetil

Cefprozil

Cefoxitin

Cefotetan

Cefmetazole 

 Escherichia coli, Klebsiella, Proteus, Haemophilus influenzae, Moraxella catarrhalis. Not as active against gram-positive organisms as first-generation agents.   Inferior activity against S. aureus compared to cefuroxime but with added activity against Bacteroides fragilis and other Bacteroides spp. 

Third generation

Cefotaxime

Ceftriaxone

Cefdinir

Cefditoren pivoxil

Ceftibuten

Cefpodoxime proxetil

Ceftizoxime 

 Escherichia coli, Klebsiella, Proteus, Haemophilus influenzae, Moraxella catarrhalis, Citrobacter, Enterobacter; Serratia; Neisseria gonorrhoeae;  Activity for S. aureus, Streptococcus pneumoniae, and Streptococcus pyogenes comparable to first-generation agents.  Activity against Bacteroides spp. inferior to that of cefoxitin and cefotetan. 

Antipseudomonal-Cephalosporins 

Ceftazidime  

Ceftazidime/avibactam   

Ceftolozane/tazobactam

Cefepime 

   Gram-negative activity similar to that of the third generation, with addition of activity against Pseudomonas; poor activity against gram-positive organisms.   Expands ceftazidime’s activity against Pseudomonas and multidrug-resistant Enterobacteriaceae, but not against gram-positives.   Similar to ceftazidime, with enhanced activity against Pseudomonas and extended-spectrum β-lactamase-producing Enterobacteriaceae.   Comparable to third generation but more resistant to some β-lactamases (especially those of Pseudomonas and Enterobacter); gram-positive activity similar to cefotaxime. 

Anti-MRSA-Cephalosporins 

Ceftaroline

Ceftobiprole 

    Similar activity to third generation but with activity against methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus 

Note: The FDA has approved cefepime-enmetazobactam, a combination of a fourth-generation cephalosporin and beta-lactamase inhibitor for use in complicated UTIs (including pyelonephritis).

Related Pearl: Methicillin-Resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA)

MRSA Definition: Methicillin MIC 8 μg/ml or more, Oxacillin MIC 4 μg/ml or more.

Resistance in MRSA is mediated by mecA gene which is chromosomally coded. It alters PBP (penicillin-binding protein) present on S.aureus cell wall to PBP-2a which has less affinity for beta-lactam antibiotics.

Penicillin Binding Protein:

  • Normal protein present in all bacterial cell wall.
  • Transpeptidase in nature.
  • Required for cross-linking of the peptidoglycan layer (essential for cell wall synthesis).
  • It is also the site of attachment for- beta-lactam drugs to bind & inhibit.

Types of MRSA:

  • Community-acquired - mediated by mec A subtype IV and Possess PV Toxin(Panton-Valentine Toxin), monodrug resistance,more virulent
  • Hospital-acquired - mediated by mec A subtype I, II, III, multidrug resistance,less virulent.

Detection of MRSA:

  • Antibiotic susceptibility test on Muller Hilton agar (Disk diffusion test) by using Methicillin or Oxacillin disc or cefoxitin disc.
  • PCR for detection of mecA gene.

Treatment:

  • Vancomycin is Drug Of Choice (should be used only if other drugs are resistant ).
  • Others- Teicoplanin, Linezolid, streptogramin, cipro/levofloxacin, cotrimoxazole, clindamycin, mupirocin, minocycline.
  • Newer Drugs – Daptomycin, ceftobiprole, tigecycline, oritavancin, dalbavancin, telavancin, delafloxacin.
  • Ceftobiprole and ceftaroline are 5th generation β lactams effective against MRSA.

questions.text: What is the unit of study in a cohort study?
questions.solution:
Cohort studies have individuals as the unit of study.

Types of epidemiological studies:

  • Observational studies - allow nature to take its own course, the investigator measures but does not intervene.
    1. Descriptive studies - limited to the description of the occurrence of a disease in a population.
    2. Analytical studies - go further by analyzing the relationship between health status and other variables.
      • Ecological studies
      • Cross-sectional studies
      • Case-control studies
      • Cohort studies

All analytical studies have individuals as the unit of study, except ecological study which has population as the unit of study.

  • Experimental studies or intervention studies involve an active attempt to change a disease determinant or the progress of a disease and are similar in design to experiments in other sciences.
    1. Randomized controlled trials(RCT) - Patients are the unit of study
    2. Field trials - healthy people are the unit of study
    3. Community trials - Community is the unit of study

questions.text:
Arrange right lung hilar structures from superior to inferior.
  1. Superior lobar bronchus
  2. Pulmonary artery
  3. Principal bronchus
  4. Inferior pulmonary vein
questions.solution:
The right lung hilar structures from superior to inferior:

  • Superior lobar bronchus
  • Pulmonary artery
  • Principal bronchus
  • Inferior pulmonary vein

The medial surface of the lung is connected to the heart and trachea by a group of structures that enter or leave the hilum. It is called the pulmonary root. It is anteriorly related to the phrenic nerve, pericardiacophrenic vessels, and anterior pulmonary plexus. The vagus nerve and posterior pulmonary plexus form the posterior relation and the pulmonary ligament the inferior relation. 

The superior vena cava and right atrium are seen in front of the right root and terminal part of the azygos vein superiorly.

The aortic arch is seen superiorly and descending thoracic aorta posteriorly of the left root. The left hilar structures are vertically arranged as:

  • Pulmonary artery
  • Principal bronchus
  • Inferior pulmonary vein

Related Pearl: Structures related to the mediastinal surface and hilum of the lungs

Right lung:

  • Anterior to the hilum - superior vena cava and right brachiocephalic vein.
  • Posterior to this groove-  azygous vein.
  • Behind the hilum and pulmonary ligament- oesophagus.
  • The cardiac impression - right auricle, right atrium and right ventricle
  • Posteroinferiorly - inferior vena cava

Left lung:

  • The cardiac impression - left ventricle and auricle and right ventricle
  • Large groove that arches over the hilum and descends behind -  Arch of aorta and descending aorta.
  • Arrow groove that ascends to the apex- left subclavian artery
  • Superior to the aortic groove-  thoracic duct and esophagus.
  • Anterior to subclavian groove - left brachiocephalic vein.

questions.text: A 20-year-old came to the emergency after a fall on an outstretched hand. He presents with the elbow in slight flexion and the forearm appears shortened. On examination, crepitus is absent and the three-point bony relation is disrupted. Which vessel is most likely to be damaged in this condition?

choices.text: Vascular damage is not seen as lack of crepitus indicates there is no fracture.

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of elbow dislocation. Brachial artery injury is likely to be associated with it.

Elbow dislocation commonly occurs after a fall on an outstretched hand. The elbow is held in slight flexion, and on examination, crepitus is absent. The three-point bony relations are disrupted. 

 

Related Pearl: Three point bony relationship in elbow:

The three bony points in the elbow are :

  • Tip of the medial epicondyle
  • Tip of the lateral epicondyle
  • Olecranon

When the elbow is in 90 degrees of flexion, these points form an isosceles triangle. When the elbow is extended, they lie transversely in a straight line.

The three-point bony relationship is maintained in the case of supracondylar fracture of the humerus as the fracture occurs above the level of these bony landmarks.

Conditions where it is distorted:

  • Fracture medial condyle and epicondyle
  • Fracture lateral condyle and epicondyle
  • Intercondylar fracture of humerus
  • Fracture olecranon
  • Elbow dislocation

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is incorrectly paired?

choices.text: Bartter syndrome - Descending  loop of Henle

questions.solution:
Bartter syndrome occurs due to a defect in the Na+/K+/Cl- channel in the thick ascending loop of Henle.

A defect in the Na+/K+/Cl- channel impairs the transport functions of the thick ascending loop of Henle. It results in the following features:

  • Polyuria and polydipsia
  • Natriuresis with high aldosterone (due to RAAS activation)
  • Hypokalemia
  • Metabolic alkalosis
  • Hypomagnesemia 
  • Hypocalcemia and hypercalciuria

The clinical features of this condition are similar to the effects of loop diuretics. These drugs also act on the Na+/K+/Cl- channel. Hence, response to loop diuretics may be blunted. Treatment is with potassium-sparing diuretics like spironolactone and amiloride.

Option A: Defect in the proximal tubule results in Fanconi's syndrome. These patients have acidosis, with glycosuria, generalized aminoaciduria, and phosphaturia.

Option B: Defect in the Na+/Cl- cotransporter in distal convoluted tubule (DCT) results in Gitelman syndrome. These patients also present with hypokalemic alkalosis and hypomagnesemia. However, they also develop, hypocalciuria, and chondrocalcinosis.

Option D: Increased activation of the epithelial sodium channels (ENaC) channels results in Liddle syndrome. This causes increased reabsorption of Na+ exchanged for K+ causing hypokalemia. Increased Na absorption leads to hypertension.

Related Pearl: Renal Tubular Syndromes
